031606792X|2.0|I think it is certainly worth buying if you already own the other three books. Might as well finish the series. If you can get away with just borrowing the book, you'd probably feel a little better after reading it, knowing that you saved money.<br /><br />As a previously serious Twilight series fan, I felt terrible for disliking this book, terrible for criticizing Meyer, but I couldn't like the book no matter how much I try.<br /><br />Girls might have been able to relate with Bella Swan in earlier books...but with Breaking Dawn, I can't imagine anybody who can relate to her. Bella Swan desperately needed a change in her character development and she didn't get it. Rather than a role model, she just magically turns into a perfect girl, which is rather frustrating. Fairy tales are supposed to be full of magic, good coincidences, and lovely endings. However, Breaking Dawn just seems to work out all too perfectly. Problems are solved by a simple coincidence or by simple perfection.<br /><br />Despite the book's monstrous length, Meyer ends her series with a very anticlimactic ending. What could have been a big bang was more like a tiny pop. I can't help but think perhaps Meyer was too rushed to finish the series or perhaps she wanted to end things a little too cleanly & conveniently without having to think too hard about it. There are loopholes and gaps everywhere you turn.<br /><br />On a final note: you will either be very satisfied with Breaking Dawn, or you will despise it. Ultimately, I think it is worth reading to know how the series ends, but that doesn't mean you'll be left with a better ending than the one in your head. And when fans are left thinking of better endings than the one the author provided...that just isn't a good thing.ic love story between Edward, Bella, and Jacob. Solution? Edward and Bella have a baby together, Jacob imprints on that baby, and they get to be one big happy family.     Girls might have been able to relate with Bella Swan in earlier books...but with Breaking Dawn, I can't imagine anybody who can relate to her. If you ask any girl who reads the Twilight series about Bella, there is a 90% chance that the girl will say \\"Oh, I LOVE Twilight, but I think Bella is actually kind of annoying. I read the series for [insert other person here, such as Edward, or Jacob, or the Cullens]. Who knew it was possible to love a series but hate the main character? I think Bella Swan needs a change in character development. Besides, who can relate to Bella Swan now, now that she has had every single desire (plus more) fulfilled so perfectly without any loss?    Also, you may hear from other Twilight fans that the final scene with the Volturi was extremely disappointing. Even though I wasn't too fond of the overall story, I was looking forward to the fight. Meyer even described the vampires who came to witness for the Cullens enough for us to understand their skills and personalities. I grew to like these vampires. All for what? The Volturi turning back and running away? Wow. Perhaps she should have just cut out all the pages about the extra vampires. They weren't really needed anyway.    On a final note: you will either be very satisfied with Breaking Dawn, or you will despise it. Ultimately, I think it is worth reading to know how the series ends, but that doesn't mean you'll be left with a better ending than the one in your head. And when fans are left thinking of better endings than the one the author provided...that just isn't a good thing.

B0019HQIGS|5.0|I've been lucky enough to see Mayer in concert.  Add to that a couple appearances on Austin City Limits and two at Eric Clapton's Crossroads Festivals. It would be easy to dismiss him as a purveyor of commercial accoustic romantic ballads if the only only material one ever heard were from Room for Squares.  In fairness a couple of those tracks were overplayed to the point of causing an allergic reaction.      Taking in his live appearances and the various concert shows one soon realizes that Mayer is a virtuoso.  The only personal analogy that I can make is Winton Marsalis.  The complete command of technical capability is eclipsed only by an instinctive 'feel' that transcends the notes on a page.      Mayer was wonderful with Double Trouble.  His Austin City Limits cover of Empty Arms was a worthy tribute to Steve Ray.  His performance with Buddy Guy was probably the surest sign I have ever seen that race no longer has a place in sports, politics or even music.  Was that really a kid from Connecticut outdueling the legendary bluesman?    Where The Light Is delivers.  Production quality is good, the play list is expansive and extends well beyond the customary radio roster.    The cover of Tom Petty's Free Fallin' made the DVD for me.  It's a simple three chord song.  I was just stunned that Mayer could develop a different and interesting arrangement, play it so perfecftly and exhibit such enthusiasm doing it.      Don't wait.  Idolize this guy now.  Most of the artistic geniuses labor in relative anonymity until way past their prime.  This guy is the read deal and this DVD shows him in his element.      As evidence of my objectivity, I have to remark that the vocal on Belief is a little flat.  It's one of my favorite songs and the version on the most recent Crossroads disk is much better.  It's a little like a bad hair day for Heather Locklear.  Hard to imagine throwing her out for a momentary lapse!    Enjoy

0739367676|5.0|I really enjoyed this book - and was surprised from the beginning right to the end. I felt the pain through the pages as Bella experienced them.      In response to the 1 star reviews with anti child expressions - I had a child at 18.  I never babysat and never wanted to be a parent - so my husband and I were not excited when the first signs of pregnancy hit.  However, I too felt this love grow for this strange little thing inside me - and it was tied to the great love I felt for my husband and father of this child.  The first kick was when I knew there was life - it was amazing.  I get it.      Bella chose Rose as an ally because she knew Rose would be more concerned for the child, everyone else would have taken action to protect her first.  Bella is smart - and intuitive - she knew exactly what she needed to do to save her child and if Rose was cold and non-caring towards her - then perfect.  I loved how caring Edward was to Bella - and through it all, that he would sacrifice everything to save her.  His pleading and planning with Jacob was painful to go through - and I had less respect for Jacob that he could keep his less than noble feelings and thoughts for Bella even in these circumstances.       Bella went to deaths door for this child - and I was impressed at the brilliance of Edward for being prepared with the venom to her heart to bring her into the only life that would preserve her.  Carlisle expressed my feelings well in his pride for his son.    Bella wasn't typical for a newborn - but she was never typical as a human.  She matured in this book - and going through the extreme pregnancy experience would do this.  It was also interesting to me that the strong connection she had to Jacob - left her once the child was born.   It was as if the bond was only there for this purpose.  However, her love for Edward was strengthened with the change - and that strong desire for him did not leave her when she left her human - it was even better.  Maybe this was another gift - her love for Edward stronger than her lust for blood.   I found it beautiful.    Aro needed exactly the gift that Bella had - to put his opponents on a level playing field.  He was the bully and surrounded himself with cruel vampire people.  He sought powerful evil gifts for his court - Carlisle attracted good.       Moreover, even though I did not like the name Renesmee - I loved the child.  Edward and Bella were never typical in any way - and it is fitting that they should be blessed with this extreme gift of this child.   Nothing I imagined would have been better than what was written.
031606792X|4.0|...and read this book with zero expectations. *NO SPOILERS BELOW*    I think you will either love or hate this book (or I suppose, like it enough to not hate it). From the dozen reviews I've read so far here, the people who hated this had a lot of expectations of what SHOULD have happened, they wanted to see the story go a certain way or that the story is Stephenie's message to readers or young girls everywhere. Honestly, I think Stephenie just wrote this story as she intended, it went where her characters demanded it go. Not every writer has a message in mind, they're just telling a story as it comes. 031606792X|5.0|I personally loved the book. I couldn't put it down, the same as the first three. There were parts that I was quite shocked, saddened, maddened and also very happy, a books main purpose is to make one feel alive, be it in another world, and some how these books were written in just the right way to let all that emotion through, leaving enough room for ones own imagination to shape it in their own eyes. I recommend it to anyone who likes a good story but isn't afraid to have an open mind or a little bit of imagination. That being said...     Everyone is freaking out about how none of the  things that happened are realistic, but hello its a fiction book, it does not have to be realistic, its a imaginary world, and thats the point of imagination, anything can happen. When one reads fantasy or science fiction or even just normal fiction you have to have a certain sense of suspended disbelief. How could you not see it coming? A human falls in love with a vampire and vise versa, that is a sure sign that things may not be a very normal. People are taking this way too hard, and many obviously had already drawn their own conclusions way before the book ever came out on what they thought should happen. But guess what? None of you wrote the book. So it was a different pace than the first three, Big deal! Why write 4 books all exactly alike just because they are part of a series? I like to feel that things are a little new, a little different. Bella grew up in her own sense and so did SM's writing. Things do change, that was part of the whole book! So Bella was different after she became a Vampire, who didn't see that coming? Yeah sure I would have loved more Edward and Bella romance, but at the same time, that was something we all understood, We all know how much they love each other, no need to throw it in our faces for 700 pages, there were other story lines that need fleshing out and finishing off. And honestly, Why is everyone so upset about the name Renesmee? It's weird,it's different and a little hard to take in at first, but that's what makes it a good name because it perfectly describes her, she is both human and vampire, and it is a cross between Bella's Vampire mother (Esme) and her human mother (Renee). And she is hard to take in at first, be it when she was killing Bella before she was born(I'm sure no one was too fond of her at that point)or like when she was being introduced to the witnesses. But once one takes the time to understand that shes something completely different but not necessarily some evil spawn, than she kinda grows on you, for after all, she is the out come of Edward and Bella's love for each other, it would be hard to think of her as anything other than a very lovable child. Just like when she won the witnesses on her side. So in the end the name fits and people need to deal with it. You want her to have some normal name like Jessica? That would be much stranger.     But in the end people need to stop analyzing it so much and just say okay, in Bella's world all of this exists, it is plausible. That is the point of fiction, to see a life or story or world that isn't ours but for that short time that we read the novel we are part of it and get to believe that it is real. Maybe you would have written it differently but you didn't write it. A writer has a certain bit of freedom to do what ever the hell they want. For a wiser take on it I think Ray Bradbury Said it correctly at the end of his book Fahrenheit 451 \\"The Real world is the playing ground for each and every group, to make or unmake laws. But the tip of the nose of my book or stories or poems is where their rights end and my territorial imperatives begin, run and rule. If Mormons don't like my plays, let them write there own. If the Irish hate my Dublin stories, let them rent typewriters. If teachers and grammar school editors find my jawbreaker sentences shatter their mushmilk teeth, let them eat stale cake dunked in weak tea of their own ungodly manufacture. For Lets Face it, digression is the soul of wit. Take philosophic asides away from Dante, Milton or Hamlet's father's ghost and what stays is dry bones.\\" He sums it up as \\"In sum, do not insult me with the beheadings, finger-choppings or the lung-deflations you plan for my works. I need my head to shake or nod, my hand to wave or make into a fist, my lungs to shout or whisper with. I will not go gently onto a shelf, degutted, to become a non-book.\\"          SM had a story she wanted to tell, and lets not forget that it is Young Adult reading so yes it is a easy read, It also allows you to easily lose your self in the story too. But it is her story and if people would get over themselves they might enjoy the story she was trying to tell.     Good job Stephenie. I would never be able to write a book, let alone 4. Everyone forgets that she's relatively new to this game. While there may have been a few ruff edges, in the end it was a wonderful story and I was happy to go along for the ride.    (I know that was really long! Sorry my thoughts took control of my hands!)

B000VLE3GA|1.0|How many times does Led Zeppelin need to be remastered?  Zeppelin has long been a high-water mark for audio mastering... screwing with it to make it \\"louder\\" is sacrilege.  It's called \\"dynamic range,\\" people.  That \\"fatter sound\\" that you love to hear from today's radio crap is compression killing sonic clarity.  There's no way around the trade off between dynamic range and compression.    But the worst part about this CD, despite all the great tracks it includes, is all the great tracks that it's missing.  I could do without \\"Communication Breakdown\\" (a great song, but one that has been superseded by other better songs), \\"Babe I'm Gonna Leave You,\\" \\"Since I've Been Loving You,\\" \\"Stairway to Heaven\\" (as if we haven't heard it enough already), \\"No Quarter\\" (a song I've always hated), \\"Trampled Under Foot,\\" and \\"Achilles Last Stand.\\"  I know some of these are inexplicably popular enough to throw on a greatest hits CD, but they're not my first choices.    If I had to choose 24 Zeppelin tracks, here's what I would pick:    \\"Good Times Bad Times\\"  \\"You Shook Me\\"  \\"Dazed and Confused\\"  \\"How Many More Times\\"  \\"Whole Lotta Love\\"  \\"What Is and What Should Never Be\\"  \\"The Lemon Song\\"  \\"Ramble On\\"  \\"Bring It On Home\\"  \\"Immigrant Song\\"  \\"Black Dog\\"  \\"Four Sticks\\"  \\"When the Levee Breaks\\"  \\"Over the Hills and Far Away\\"  \\"Dancing Days\\"  \\"The Ocean\\"  \\"In My Time of Dying\\"  \\"Kashmir\\"  \\"Nobody's Fault But Mine\\"  \\"We're Gonna Groove\\"  \\"I Can't Quit You Baby\\" (Coda)  \\"Traveling Riverside Blues\\"  \\"White Summer - Black Mountain Side\\"  \\"Hey Hey What Can I Do\\"    I would have listened to that all the way through instead of skipping half the tracks the first time around like I did with \\"Mothership.\\"  My list is surely different than some people's taste in Zeppelin, but the fact is that several of the songs included are great, but have been ruined by overexposure.  For instance, after \\"Rock and Roll\\" became mentally attached to a car commercial in my head, I lost all desire to listen to itagain (which is a shame because it's a good song).    I know people are going to hate me for putting down this CD and some of their favorite songs, but these just aren't all the best Zeppelin songs in my opinion, and I think it's a mistake for Jimmy Page to keep screwing with his material over and over again, the way George Lucas ruined the Star Wars films.  You want Zeppelin louder?  Turn the volume up!  There's a reason why the \\"punchier\\" music of today sounds so much more duller than music from the 60's and 70's.    Plus, I already own all of these songs.

031606792X|5.0|I loved this book. Bella grows and matures from an adolescent to an intelligent young woman. The love she still feels for Edward - and the amazing love for her child - is so authentic.     As far as Jacob imprinting on a baby - well I expected it. I'm not an \\"obsessed Twilight fan\\" - and I had a lot of space between reading the last Twilight book and this one. Meyer continues to impress me - standing out in a sea of mediocre paranormal romances with one that is brilliantly written, alive with emotion, and thoroughly authentic. 031606792X|1.0|The first three books of the series were enjoyable for what they were--I did not pick up the books expecting a deep, thought provoking take on the typical vampire tale. They are marketed towards teenaged girls, written on that level, and thus should be judged on that same level. For that genre and level, they were an amusing story.    I'm a completionist, however, so I felt compelled to know the end of the series. Were that not the case, I likely would have put down the book and walked away in exhasperation fairly early into it.    I expected a happy ending. It is a fairy tale for teenaged girls, the happy ending is part and parcel to that genre. What I did not expect was a plot so thin on content that it went past cliche and into utter ridiculousness.    Unexpected, impossible mixed-species accelerated teenaged pregnancy of unknown creature. Truly? A cross between the spoof episodes of X-Files and Passions, but presented in a way that took itself entirely seriously despite itself.     Soap Opera Rapid Aging Syndrome extended to propel the storyline, as it did right past the pregnancy, past all of those pesky in-between stages from infant to walking and talking secondary character.     Bella was already somewhat thin on personality and backbone, and was defined by her dependancy on Edward and Jacob. It was enough that critics of the series were already screaming Mary Sue at her, pointing out that she met the criteria of being a character with \\"a major role in the plot . . .  particularly characterized by overly idealized and clichd mannerisms, lacking noteworthy flaws, and primarily functioning as wish-fulfillment fantasies.\\"     However, I would posit that Bella was replaced by Nessie within the series as the ultimate Mary Sue of Twilight just by her mere existance and for the fact that no one, obviously, could fail to love her.    No, I did not go into this series looking for a powerful positive message for teenaged girls as many of the others seem to have. I didn't go into it expecting completely original story ideas. I did, however, open Breaking Dawn expecting expecting some sort of coherent story drawing the series to a close in a way that satisfied the need for a happy ending, while keeping in line with the backstory provided in the previous three installments.    Instead I recieved a book that did nothing but draw from the most cliched, most ridiculous possibilities available at every turn, jammed them together in such a manner as to leave the reader bewildered and dissapointed, and created an ending that managed to undermine all enjoyment from the previous books.
B000QUCNOK|4.0|Despite being jaded by the thousands of scenes of violence that you have seen in films up to now, nothing can prepare your for the heartbreaking opening scene of this poor fellow (the movie's antihero) being born and abandoned on a filthy Paris street in a pile of fish remains.    From this moment on you are aware that this human being's life will be different from the average person's. After years of suffering abuse in a harsh orphanage and being forced into slave labour as a young adult, the question of whether criminals are born or nurtured begs to be asked.    While the film reveals early on that this boy is \\"gifted\\" with a superior sense of smell, leading to olfactory obsession, it is wrong to assume that this automatically leads to criminal (murderous) proclivities. The film is thankfully vague about this.     In this way the film, like all true art, does not beat you over the head with easy answers, nor does it pontificate an agenda, rather it lets you witness events as the proverbial fly on the wall, and encourages you to ponder whether criminals are born or nurtured by and EXTREMELY harsh and unforgiving society.    Despite his crimes, I felt that given his past, I am more empathetic to criminals and may be less prone to judge.  For me, good films challenge my world-view, great films challenge my morals.  This one does both.    Although this is not a \\"popcorn\\" film, or something that you would automatically sit down to watch with your family, it is powerful and provocative nontheless.  Despite its bizaare perfume-fetish-theme, it is socially relevant.  It is unfair to say the film is poor because it makes you feel depressed or horrified.  Not all films are meant to serve that purpose. Some films are meant to entertain, amuse or alternatively to challenge and provoke.    Although it is possible that some scenes could have been shortened, I never found myself bored but rather felt myself mesmerized by the powerful images.

There were several sections where I was taken by surprise. One of them was that SM split the book into 3 books. I thought that was a nice change. We also got to see Jacob's point of view and how he felt about the situation. Then, it went back to Bella's point of view and we got to see the Vampire Bella. I thought that was pretty cool. That was probably the most surprising thing in the book besides Bella getting pregnant. I had a feeling that the Volturi were going to be involved in the book, so it wasn't AS surprising.    There have been many comments about the name Renesmee. I agree that it is a little long, but I still liked it. It was cute, it made sense, and it was very original.     I have seen multiple comments about how people thought:  1. They were on drugs when reading Breaking Dawn  2. SM was on drugs when writing Breaking Dawn  3. They got a fake book  4. That is your opinion  5. No. It was not a joke. It was a wonderful book that was well written  6. If you think it was a waste of your time, then don't waste any more time telling others that you wasted your time  7. Why did you buy it if it was a waste of your money?    Sorry if this a long post, but I had alot of things on my mind  So, overall, I think you should buy the book. I thought it was great. There were many surprises. If you're not sure, then go to a local bookstore and read a couple pages. If you like it, then buy it. If you don't leave the book alone a get on with your life.
031606792X|1.0|I'm just going to add my one star in the hopes that one day Stephenie Meyer will realize what a huge mess she's made.    Younger readers are more likely to be up in arms over the negative reviews because they're satisfied with the conclusion. Thank God, happy ending, right? Bella gets Edward and a perfect life, so what's the problem?    How about throwing all logic from the previous books out the window? How about the bizarre idea that getting pregnant will make you want the child, regardless of how you felt about having children previously?     Part of the problem is that despite its nice clean pages free of graphic sexual description, Breaking Dawn is not really a book for tweens.     Stephenie Meyer was quoted as saying that she was writing the series for herself, not for her fans. That should tell you something right there. She's in her 30s, married, and has several children. Of course it's a perfect series for her. She's gone through normal, everyday experiences like dealing with newborns, having arguments with her not-perfect husband, and dealing with her own personal self-image.     What woman in the middle of a marriage wouldn't want a man who is endlessly devoted to her, with eight-pack abs and a model's face? Gosh, and how about that bottomless sex drive Bella suddenly discovers? And let's see, for good measure, let's throw in something about children. A baby, of course! One that everyone instantly falls in love with; who grows to the perfect size almost immediately; who can easily communicate what she wants at a touch (wouldn't want the confusion and embarrassment that comes with a baby screaming hysterically, now would we?); who sleeps all night (something new parents can only fantasize about) and who wasn't really wanted at first, but gee, now that she's here, she's just so darn perfect, who could possibly give her up?     It's a fantasy in Stephenie Meyer's little mental world and it should have stayed there.
031606792X|2.0|Less than 100 pages in, I started wondering how the series I've enjoyed immensely for three books could go so wrong. \\"Breaking Dawn\\" is so clichd and hackneyed it doesn't seem to belong to the same series. The wedding/pregnancy reads like a stereotypical plot device from a B-movie. The Bella we've grown to know and love is unidentifiable, and the intense emotional bonds between the characters that made the first three books so great are hardly developed and acknowledged at all. The book relies too much on weak plot points (don't hold your breath waiting for an epic battle - there isn't anything here that qualifies) and not enough on further character development.   The book also seems to be pushing an unsubtle agenda - teenage girls don't need an education, they just need a man and to have babies. This seems very different from the Bella of the first three books, who was in love but wasn't remotely interested in motherhood. Although her transformation would make it impossible for her to see them, I find it a little hard to believe she would drop her human friends without as much as a second thought. She doesn't even wonder what they are doing.  Without any ties to the human world, this book is all supernatural all the time. I, for one, missed the balance between the two worlds the earlier books created. Without that, this book is ungrounded and too free to follow wacky plot twists that make no sense. The author would have been better off making the wedding sequence the epilogue to \\"Eclipse\\" and letting readers imagine what Bella would be like as a vampire than publishing this mediocre rubbish.

Get weird!!!!

031606792X|5.0|I got hooked on the Twilight series thanks to my granddaughter.  We were all pins and needles, along with millions of fans, for Breaking Dawn, the last book, to be released.  We ended up buying two copies so we wouldn't have to wait for someone else to finish it.      Well, I'd barely started the book when I began to see scathing comments online about how Stephanie Meyers had let fans down with the story.  It was simply too unbelivable.  One person speculated on whether SM had actually written it and another was shocked because abortion was suggested in a young adult novel.      I'll admit, they had me worried, but I'd waited too long to read this book and wasn't going to put it down based on someone else's critique.  And I'm so glad I didn't.  In my opinon, Breaking Dawn was the perfect ending for the series.  Meyers not only tied up all the loose ends, she exceeded my expectations for Bella, Edward and Jacob.    I can only assume some people are unhappy with the story for two reasons.  1.) They expected the story to be about Bella becoming a vampire and nothing else.  And 2.) They were unwilling to suspend belief and simply enjoy the story.    Now, I can kinnda understand the first reason, since I thought the same thing.  But I was pleasantly surprised to see that I'd gotten way more than that.  It's the second reason that stumps me.  And here's why:    People were willing to believe in an entire family of vampires.    They were willing to believe that one of those vampires fell in love with a human.    They were willing to believe in werewolves.    They were willing to belive a triangle could form between the human, the werewolf and the vampire.    They were willing to believe that Edward would arrange for his own death when he thought Bella had died.    And yet, they can't seem to believe that:    Bella would get pregnant with a half human/half vampire child.    That the child would grow faster than normal.    That Edward and Jacob would be frantic for Bella's life and want to save her even if it meant getting the child \\"out\\".      That Jacob would imprint on said child. (like we couldn't see that one coming from the time Bella got preggers.)    Frankly, nothing in Breaking Dawn was anymore \\"out there\\" than all the other events in the previous books.  And we writers have a saying.  \\"My world, my rules\\".  In other words, we can get away with almost anything, no matter how outlandish, if we have a logical explanation for it.  And Meyers does.  I absolutely loved and applaud the way she handled Bella's transformation, and the fact that Bella ended up saving the day.  It was a perfect ending, a statisfying conclusion.      So, if anyone out there is hesitating over the buying book, rest assured, it's well worth dollars you'll spend.  Stephanie Meyers has created a masterpiece of vampire fiction.

But anyone who has read the first three novels will understand the story enough to find \\"Breaking Dawn\\" unrealistic. The story is unrealistic for many more reasons, including the following:     -Edward does not stop himself from having sex with Bella even though it hurts her (she wakes up the next morning with bruises all over her body).    -Edward, as a vampire, impregnates Bella.  -Bella names her child Reneesme.  -Jacob imprints on Reneesme.  -Edward pretty much leaves the story after the first 100 pages.  -Bella has absolutely no trouble with her vegetarian vampire diet.  -Jacob shows Charlie he is a werewolf and Charlie easily accepts it.  -Charlie thinks Bella is some sort of supernatural creature, and does not really care.   -Alice tells her family the Volturi are coming to eliminate them all, and then leaves, letting them think that she and Jasper escaped to save only themselves.     But perhaps the most frustrating thing about \\"Breaking Dawn\\" is that the characters are nothing like the characters we fell in love with in the earlier \\"Twilight\\" novels. Not even Edward and Bella. It was as if I was reading \\"Twilight\\" fan fiction. Bella and Edward had the same back story, yet they were nothing like the human and vampire we met and loved in \\"Twilight\\", \\"New Moon\\", and \\"Eclipse\\".    I gave \\"Breaking Dawn\\" 3 stars because I love Stephenie Meyer and this world she has created. I was still hooked enough to race through each page to find out what would happen in the end.        My only hope is that Stephenie Meyer continues on the story (there is a huge opportunity for that through the Volturi story line), and that the continuation stays true to the characters that were created in the beginning, and the story lines there.

031606792X|5.0|Being with Edward Cullen has never been easy, as Bella Swan well knows, after nearly two years of brushes with death with her adopted vampire family. But she and Edward are finally ready to take the next step in their relationship by getting married, and then turning Bella into a vampire. It all rolls out without a hitch, and Bella and Edward are the picture of a blissful couple, until their honeymoon is rudely interrupted by a shocking event, putting not only Bella's life in danger, but the lives of the Cullen family and their werewolf friends as well.    The fourth and final installment of the Twilight Saga does not disappoint. Though it lacks much of the mystery and elegant descriptions of the dreary setting of Forks that entranced readers in Twilight, Breaking Dawn is overflowing with romance, action, and danger that sufficiently do their job in keeping the reader enthralled. However, certain parts of the story do feel a bit rushed, such as the wedding, and could have stood to be beefed up a little bit. Also, wedged almost midway through this weighty 750 page tome is a block of about 200 or so pages told from Jacob's perspective. While the story is served much better from his point of view at this point in the story, it does seem to break up the general flow a bit, making it harder to concentrate on the plot, and easy to countdown the pages until we can get inside of Bella's head again.    Once the story picks up again with Bella, it's hard to keep up. Bella's transformation from human to vampire is not quite as dramatic as many readers originally imagined, but is almost glossed over in light of a bigger surprise that will intrigue and delight readers. Meyers skillfully builds up suspense to the climax where Bella and Edward's lives inevitably will be put in danger, encouraging a niggling sense of doubt that was always lacking in its prequels. However, like many problems that have been presented throughout the Twilight saga, this one seems to resolve itself tooeasily. But these flaws are understated by breathless excitement, jaw-dropping surprises, maddening suspense, and enduring romance, which have become staples of the Twilight Saga, and will leave you dreaming long after the book is finished.

031606792X|4.0|Really, I don't even want to get into this whole debate. Yes, Stephenie Meyer could've explained this whole thing better- a lot better, in fact. Mhm, we're well aware that you feel that the climax was... Anticlimax in the extreme.    And yes, these accusations are based in fact, but, generally speaking, there seems to be a bandwagon or mob mentality thing going here. This book was not so poorly written that it deserves to be burned, or locked away in some musty drawer, never to be read again by nearly half of her fans (or should I say ex-fans?). There are redeeming qualities.    As it is, I'm no literary expert, but I'm no idiot either. I can appreciate that some of you didn't enjoy the book, but there is absolutely no reason to rag on it to this extent... Personally, I found it an enjoyable read.    Perhaps this review will make me an object of personal attack, with people criticizing my supposed \\"literary arts retardation\\", or perhaps my age status as a \\"typical hormone-ruled teenager\\", or maybe you'll just think of me as \\"a mindless tool who bows to popular fiction writers just because it's the in thing to do\\".    All I can say is that I'm a different type of Team Switzerland- the fan who can emphasize with both parties, and who is neutral to this heated debate. But personally, I will always enjoy this book, regardless of its shortcomings and others' blatantly pessimist views.
031606792X|5.0|Bella is nervous and anxious about her upcoming wedding.  Her mother, Renee, raised her to be wary of the actual wedding ceremony, although not afraid to love and be in a committed relationship.  But in order for Edward to live up to his end of the bargain, Bella must marry him.  And there is nothing she wants more than for Edward to live up to his end of the bargain - to turn her into a vampire before her 19th birthday.  Bella is still wrestling with how she will deal with both Renee and her father Charlie, nevermind her best friend and werewolf, Jacob.      To say much more about the plot is to completely ruin surprise after surprise.  Questions that readers had in books 1-3 will finally be answered.  Things fans have wanted to see happen will happen.  But horrifying twists lurk behind each page as well.      This book is, in many ways, a very satisfying conclusion to the series.  But in true form, it is so entertaining that readers will still clamor for more.  Bella is extremely self depricating and annoying for most of the book.  It isn't until the end that she finally gains some self confidence and becomes a sympathetic person.  Despite this, the rest of the characters live up to their reputation and are fun to read.  More than anything, this fantasy world continues to grab a hold of the imagination and make for a fantastic read.  It probably only deserves 3.5 or 4 stars, but out of sheer loyalty and enjoyment it shoots up to 5.

031606792X|3.0|SPOILERS ARE IN THE REVIEW          Before I prepared to tackle on 'Breaking Dawn', I read the first 3 books in the series - a 'Twilight' reading marathon, and when I got to Breaking Dawn...    The beginning was enjoyable, I enjoyed the wedding because Bella's feelings of leaving the human world were still poignant. However, when it got to the pregnancy, I had flashbacks of reading an unpleasant fanfiction. I would have never thought that would happen. I agree with the reviews about Bella's daughter's name... I almost expected her to say 'Just Kidding!\\" in the middle of it.     I was also disappointed with Jacob's imprinting - even though it isn't gross in the context of the book, I found it as a copout - to explain that how Jacob will still stay at Bella's side and make friends with all her vampires. I also couldn't believe it when Jacob told Charlie the truth - what about all the reasons NOT to tell the truth in the previous books? When I actually figured it out in the middle of reading I laughed incredulously at the idea.    I was also disappointed at the lack of a confrontation with the Voltari, this book will make for a boring 4th movie - that's for sure.     I also thought that the change of character of Bella compared to before and after she had her daughter was a bit unbelievable. I also agree here with what the other reviewers had said about the message... and especially now, with teen pregnancy rising even more than before.     I also don't think that its fair to give Bella so much self control over her bloodlust. Too the extent where she could interact with her human father normally still. No wonder Jasper seemed kinda put off.     OKAY - now that's all the bashing is aside....    I still chose to gave this book 2.5 because over the course of the 2 years I've been reading this series, I've grown attached to the characters, so I could understand why Stephenie Meyer chose to give them happy endings - they are the happy endings that I would wish forthem too.     But unfortunately, life ISN'T a happy ending... and even though 'Breaking Dawn' is a magnificent fairy tale (as much as one with vampires and werewolves could be), it just broke the realism of the Twilight universe.    To sum it up: This book is everything that one would wish for Bella, but it fails to be a great literary piece of work... it still feels like a very long piece of fanfiction... It's just TOO sweet... its so sweet that it hurts my teeth.
031606792X|3.0|**HUGE SPOILERS**  Just finished BD and overall I was a little disappointed but not for the same reasons as many of the reviewers here. Allowing male vampires to have viable sperm seemed like a huge stretch to me and it was hugely disappointing to have the above problems resolve so easily.  It didn't feel earned    I'm also very aware that babies are a natural result of sex and marriage but to me it just didn't fit into the story. I wish the author would have spent more time resolving all the above conflicts instead of introducing a new one that just didn't fit into the series.  A great fight scene wouldn't have hurt either.    I give it 3 stars because I think Stephenie Meyers is enormously creative and talented and hey- this is her first series.  It's worth reading but definitely not my favorite.

0743243153|3.0|Parts of this book are simply incredible.  Peck's thoughts on the role of problems, the content of genuine love, the nature of miracles and grace are truly phenonemnal.  Peck is certainly a brilliant man who brings remarkable insight to the table.  While this is true, parts of this book lack cogency.  For example, his thoughts on the problem of evil, original sin and the religion of science are neither convincing nor compelling.  Part of the problem is that he deals with these subjects in a cursory way, not giving them the attention they demand.  It is as if he quickly offers his thoughts to these age-old issues as panaceas that save the day, allowing the human race to exhale a sigh of relief.  I doubt that this is how Peck intended to be read, but this is my perception of these sections.  Overall, this book is worth reading for the sections when Peck shines.  However, be warned that there are also parts that will fail to satisfy.

031606792X|3.0|I am a huge fan of the twilight series as a 25 year old, being a hopeless romantic at heart and a huge believer that real love conquers all.  While growing up can change those feelings, the twilight saga was a nice reminder of the idealism i had when i was a teenager.  i read all three books in one week and have been stalking the internet since waiting for breaking dawn.<br />so here's what i think: nice tidy ending to satisfy everyone, but its almost like this book isn't part of the series.<br />let me explain: the first three books were great allegories for the awkwardness of high school, first love, and how family fit into all of that.  the hope and fearlessness we all felt as teenagers played out in this forbidden relationship between bella and edward.  the relationship we all dream of: devotion, unwavering devotion.  in a world filled with divorce and people giving up on relationships for a flavor of the week, it was nice to see two individuals that found true love and knew it.  does it work for everyone?  no.  but sometimes your first love is your true love and thats whats best.  these books sent great messages to young women, experiencing first love and changing hormones, that its ok to be in love and not need to express it physically.  it can be chaste and beautiful and allow you time to find out who you are.  bella had spent her life taking care of her mother and herself, and i find it nice that she finds someone to take care of her.  we should all strive for it.  these books were about love and family, real family, not just the one you're born to, but the one you make, discover, as you go through life.  i liked the message that family is more than just blood, its emotions and experiences.<br />and then you have breaking dawn.<br />ok, so bella and edward go traditional and have sex after marriage.  thats fine.  she's only 18 still, ok, young marriage, i can deal with that too.  is not like thats uncommon.  but at this point the novel, to me at least, stops being a young adult book (as they are marketed) and becomes a little too adult.  if i was a teenager i might be a little confused.  and as a grown woman i am not sure i would want this book to be in my teenage daughter's hands (if i had one).  while the exploration of more adult themes is ok, encouraged even, i don't feel bella developed enough as a person to convey these themes properly.  she has been extremely altruistic throughout these books and now she gets everything she wants without fighting for it.  life doesn't magically become easier after marriage.  marriage isn't a fairy tale all the time, and if people knew that and worked through it there would be less divorce.  anyway, everything just kind of shifts in the story from what the previous books stood for.  bella is no longer a character to relate too, not some shy teen with a keen sense of sacrifice and self, and our \\"normal\\" girl is suddenly a supermodel married to an adonis with a baby she only had to carry for one month?  this is not the character we have all admired on some level.  this is a perversion of the bella we love.  everything was just tidied up and everyone was happy but NO ONE had to sacrifice anything for that happiness.  the universe is not so kind.<br />but theres that part of me, the young girl before reality came along, that looks at this as a dream come true.  maybe not a good dream for an 18-year-old, but at 25, now through college and grad school and many heartbreaks and setbacks, wouldn't it be nice to have everything i wanted?  yes it would.  while breaking dawn isn't want we might have wanted, and despite its many flaws, the general message of love and family is still there, however diluted.  It could have been better, could have been worse, but lets all face it: if it hadn't ended this neatly these reviews would be much more angrily written.  its not wrong to want it all, just make sure you take the message away that its what YOU want, whats best for YOU, because lets face it:we are not going to find a vegetarian vampire and live immortally ever after.find a vegetarian vampire and live immortally ever after.

B001AEF6D6|5.0|`The Big Lebowski' has been hailed as one of the greatest cult classic films of our time, and I just might have to agree.  The Coen brothers rarely disappoint (honestly, `Intolerable Cruelty' was a mess but aside from that they usually strike gold) and `The Big Lebowski', while not their smartest film, may be one of their most entertaining.  In all honesty, `Fargo' is a better film, but nothing in `Fargo' can match the brilliance that is Jeff Bridges as the iconic `Dude'.<br /><br />So, `The Big Lebowski' centers around two men with the same name.  There is Jeffrey `The Dude' Lebowsky; a pot-smoking, White Russian drinking, unemployed slacker, and then there is Jeffrey `The Big' Lebowski, a handicapped multi-millionaire with a trophy wife named Bunny who has gotten herself in debt with some very dangerous men.  Those men, attempting to get their money, come after `The Dude', mistaking him for Bunny's husband.  Thus starts the tumble that is the Dude's involvement in a kidnapping scheme that pits him against some very strange (and albeit hilarious) people.  Teamed with his bowling buddies Walter and Donny, not to mention Lebowski's (the `Big' man) estranged daughter Maude, the Dude attempts to make some quick cash by playing as the go between for Lebowski and his wife's kidnappers.<br /><br />The plot is simple and doesn't work too hard to embellish itself, but the brilliant script work and the flawless acting help make for some of the funniest moments and most memorable dialog in recent memory.  John Goodman really works well with the Coen brothers.  His performance in `Barton Fink' is seriously one of my favorite supporting performances of all time, and here in `The Big Lebowski' he dominates as the Dude's best buddy Walter.  Buscemi (who is also a perennial Coen star) doesn't have as much to do as he did in `Fargo' but he makes the most of it.  Philip Seymour Hoffman is hilarious as Brandt; his facial expressions in the limo with the two Lebowski's is one of my favorite scenes in the film.  Tara Reid plays a variation of herself as Bunny, and Peter Storemare is hilarious as the Nihilist member of the techno pop band `Autobahn'.  The character of `The Big' Lebowski is a tad clich&eacute;d, but David Huddleston is hilarious enough to make up for that.  Julianne Moore is fantastic, and I mean that, as Maude.  I seriously am starting to change my opinion of this actress.  She has been lauded over and over and seriously up until this past week I didn't understand why, but her performance here (and more notable in `Short Cuts') is starting to change my mind.  Everything about her character play here is hilariously on point.<br /><br />But nothing compares to `The Dude'...nothing.  Jeff Bridges is in all honesty one of my favorite actors; he may even break top ten for me.  He just always sells it, even when he's not mind-blowing he has that consistency about his work to where it is always solid.  His performance here is not only solid, but it is mind-blowing.  Comedic-wise he just devours this film, becoming this character from this inside out.  He beautifully builds layers of apathy within a character that is deeper than his roots, but most importantly he understands the dialog and `how' his character would sell that dialog, and he soars.<br /><br />`The Big Lebowski' can be labeled another Coen triumph, to rest on the shelf along with `Fargo' and the more recent `No Country for Old Men' as iconic cinematic experiences that one shall not soon forget.vorite scenes in the film.  Tara Reid plays a variation of herself as Bunny, and Peter Storemare is hilarious as the Nihilist member of the techno pop band `Autobahn'.  The character of `The Big' Lebowski is a tad clich&eacute;d, but David Huddleston is hilarious enough to make up for that.  Julianne Moore is fantastic, and I mean that, as Maude.  I seriously am starting to change my opinion of this actress.  She has been lauded over and over and seriously up until this past week I didn't understand why, but her performance here (and more notable in `Short Cuts') is starting to change my mind.  Everything about her character play here is hilariously on point.<br /><br />But nothing compares to `The Dude'...nothing.  Jeff Bridges is in all honesty one of my favorite actors; he may even break top ten for me.  He just always sells it, even when he's not mind-blowing he has that consistency about his work to where it is always solid.  His performance here is not only solid, but it is mind-blowing.  Comedic-wise he just devours this film, becoming this character from this inside out.  He beautifully builds layers of apathy within a character that is deeper than his roots, but most importantly he understands the dialog and `how' his character would sell that dialog, and he soars.<br /><br />`The Big Lebowski' can be labeled another Coen triumph, to rest on the shelf along with `Fargo' and the more recent `No Country for Old Men' as iconic cinematic experiences that one shall not soon forget.
B00003E43J|4.0|This album of 12 (not 18) songs was released in 1960 following Elvis's discharge from the US Army. It was intended to showcase his talent and serve as a \\"come back\\". B000002UAU|5.0|From its elaborate cover (the most expensive in LP history), to its printed back-cover lyrics, to its (in the original LP issue, anyway) toy insignia cutouts, to its complete lack of 45-r.p.m. singles, \\"Sgt. Pepper\\", from the summer of 1967, was groundbreaking in many ways.  The Beatles, already the most famous musical entity in the world, had retreated from touring the previous year and devoted themselves to the recording studio full-time.  This was the result.  The idea of an alter-ego to the group was originally Paul McCartney's; the other Beatles joined in the concept, creating a loose framework for a wide variety of material.  Paul indulged his penchant for music hall ditties with \\"When I'm Sixty-Four\\"; John Lennon got both ethereal, with \\"Lucy In the Sky With Diamonds\\", and earthy, in \\"Good Morning, Good Morning\\"; George Harrison's Indian absorption is reflected in \\"Within You Without You\\"; and Ringo, who usually got at least one song to sing, sallies forth bravely as Billy Shears with a little help from his friends.  It should be noted that \\"Pepper\\" was produced with the aid of hallucinogens, so the record, given its brilliance, can't really be used as an anti-drug argument.  The rock album was born.

B00180R06I|5.0|Carl Theodor Dreyer's VAMPYR has long been one of my favorite early horror films but until just a few years ago it was impossible to see it in a decent print. The old Image DVD had the best picture quality but was marred by black box subtitles in Gothic script. Still it was the best there was until now. This new Criterion transfer is not only the best so far it will probably be the best from now on as I can't see anyone else wanting to redo it. It's not everyone's idea of a horror film especially today when poetry and atmosphere are not high on the list of priorities for most horror movies (or most movies in general). The film was not a success in 1932 causing the director to abandon filmmaking for 11 years although it quickly developed a cult following.<br /><br />The scenario inspired by Irish Huguenot writer Sheridan Le Fanu's novella CARMILLA and influenced by F.W. Murnau's NOSFERATU is probably the closest cinematic equivalent of a dream captured on film. It certainly influenced Cocteau's BEAUTY AND THE BEAST which was 14 years later. The film is actually more of a nightmare as it follows a young protagonist through village inns and country estates on the trail of a female vampire who against conventional tradition is old and wizened rather than young and beautiful. Strange things happen. Shadows have a life of their own, the hero watches himself from above as he is buried alive, and it contains one of the strangest death scenes ever filmed which was borrowed from D.W. Griffith's A CORNER IN WHEAT. The entire film was designed to be pale with lots of fog and scenes shot through gauze over the camera lens. It was photographed by Rudolph Mate' who had done Dreyer's previous film THE PASSION OF JOAN OF ARC. Once seen it cannot be forgotten. Like most vivid dreams you remember it whether you want to or not.<br /><br />This new transfer of the German version (there were French and English ones as well) looks as good as any restoration I have ever seen and the cleaning up of Wolfgang Zeller's music score, so essential to the overall mood, is nothing less than astonishing. Like most Criterion releases it comes with a plethora of extras including the original shooting script and a complete copy of Le Fanu's story CARMILLA so that you can see how much they varied from it. There is alao a second disc containing deleted scenes, a detailed analysis of the film and a radio interview with the director. Yes it's expensive and no it's not for everyone but if you appreciate cinema as poetry and are seduced by black and white images than this is the movie for you. Be advised though that Dreyer shot this film as a silent and added the music and effects later. There is less than 10 minutes worth of dialogue overall and no one says more than a few words each time they speak.ng up of Wolfgang Zeller's music score, so essential to the overall mood, is nothing less than astonishing. Like most Criterion releases it comes with a plethora of extras including the original shooting script and a complete copy of Le Fanu's story CARMILLA so that you can see how much they varied from it. There is alao a second disc containing deleted scenes, a detailed analysis of the film and a radio interview with the director. Yes it's expensive and no it's not for everyone but if you appreciate cinema as poetry and are seduced by black and white images than this is the movie for you. Be advised though that Dreyer shot this film as a silent and added the music and effects later. There is less than 10 minutes worth of dialogue overall and no one says more than a few words each time they speak.

0316666343|5.0|In the hands of a lesser author, The Lovely Bones could have been a clich-peppered melodrama with a tale of a young, murdered girl looking down from heaven full of despair and woe.   But Alice Sebold presents the familiar setup with the right amounts of reflection and often heartbreaking poignancy, giving more life to her deceased heroine than is found in most people walking among us on earth.      Susie Salmon is already in her heaven at the beginning of The Lovely Bones.  With frustrating curiosity, she's able to watch the fallout of her murder, as her family and town work to deal with the horror and shock of her death.  The novel's strength lies in the opening chapters, as Susie's omniscient heavenly power allows her to hear the thoughts and memories of the important people in her life, seeing them as whole people for the first time, not just the version of themselves they gave to her.  Only after such understanding can she reach the levels of regret and loss she achieves in heaven, wishing she had some of those days to live over...or even just a few lost moments.      One of Sebold's best choices involves sculpting Susie's heaven out of the environment and experiences of her time on earth.  She spends most of her time in a gazebo like the one she coveted in her neighbor's yard when she was alive, and she encounters important people who proceeded her in death, as well as strangers she meets (including a support group of girls whose lives ended like hers).      She's able to see her mother explain to the police the meaning of the charms on her bracelet, something she didn't realize her mother knew.  She's with her father as he destroys the ships-in-a-bottle they made together.  And she listens for her name to make an appearance (as it always does) during important holidays and events.  In her heaven, Susie is torn between wanting those who cared for her to move on with their lives and the giddy excitement she gets when someone mentions her, remembers her, affirms her.  Although she knows it is selfish, she (like all of us) wants to know she mattered and wants to know she is missed.       Listening to Susie as she watches her friends and family deal with her death creates one of the more charming and irresistible first halves of a novel I have read in years.  The honesty, vulnerability and reflection tiptoe the line of sentimentality without falling over too often.  The pebble-in-the-ocean ripples of a child's death remind me of the fractured family in John Irving's The World According To Garp, and Sebold seems to match that master's insight into the hearts of the modern American family.      Sadly, the novel can't maintain the early brilliance and gets bogged down toward the middle with an unfortunate tangent involving the mother and completely gets sideways at the end with some supernatural (and all too sweet) conclusions.  But Sebold's mistakes at the end should not prevent anyone from introducing themselves to Susie Salmon, the lovely character in the lovely book about the lovely bones.
B000002GQG|5.0|I love all of the Moody Blues Albums up until the Seventh Sojourn.I have yet to further explore anything after that.Obviousley Days of Future Passed was the masterpiece that got them started,but if I had to pick a favorite this would be the one.It has a very natural feel to it as if the whole band was on the same page with what the finished product would be.Very very mellow music.I was only 18 when i first heard this one and I have very fond memories of that time.As a matter of fact it is hard to look back around that time in my life and not think of this album.You can press play and listen to it all the way thru so it is hard to pick out highlights.My favorite part of the album is from \\"Voices in the Sky\\" up until \\"The Actor\\".It is impossible for me to listen to these four songs and not feel somewhat nostalgic about the place I was at when I first heard them.Not that it doesn't work as a whole album,the second half just seems to have some extra mellow sixties magic to it.Highly recommended for those of you whose ears bleed when they hear death metal or gangster rap(In other words bad music)Long live the Moody Blues.

B000059T00|5.0|Kinda hard to beat this album.Blind Faith released in 69 was the only album they ever released and thats allright because if Clapton and Winwood attempted to follow this up with a better album chances are they would have killed themselves in doing so.This doesn't sound like music by men living on the edge.It sounds like music made by men who actually jumped off over the edge and somehow made it back alive.CLASSIC stuff here.No surprise this was the first music project Clapton did after hearing Music from Big PInk by \\"The Band\\".He was inspired by them to make an album that meant more than being a guitar king.You can here the soul in the music.Although Clapton had not yet found confidence in his voice yet,I probably would trust Steve Winwood to get the job done too,ha ha.And he sure did.His vocal on \\"Had to Cry Today\\" nearly outshines the brilliant guitar interplay by himself and Clapton.\\"Prescence of the Lord\\" may be the best song Eric ever wrote besides maybe\\"Layla\\" the next year.The guitar solo on it is insane.All and all a great album with even Ginger Bakers drum solo and Rick Gretch's violin solo contributing greatly to Eric and Stevies vision.Better than Cream,better than Beatles,better than a lot of stuff.But than again thats just my opinion.Watch Clapton's 2007 guitar festival if you want to see him and Stevie take another trip to the edge of existence by performing these timeless songs nearly 40 years later.Could not have been done better.I truly hope Clapton and Winwood will continue to play together and maybe record some more,they are an unbeatable duo.
0345349571|3.0|Tuchman builds a wonderful mental picture of the 14th century, and what it must have been like to live back then.  She follows the 14th century through the life of a French nobleman (but not a king).  This led to a book that isn't a great story - she purposely picks someone who has some historical info, but not a king or queen whose life would be too far removed from the \\"common\\" life.  Unfortunately, that means there isn't a lot of detail about this guy's life, and she is too much of a historian to make anything up.  So the story is kind of sketchy. And (this is probably endemic in any 14th century booK) she spends a lot of time talking about relationships between royalty across Europe, which for some reason bores me silly.  All that said, I have a completely different view of medieval Farnce and England than previously, and I learned a lot.  A worthwhile read that sometimes bogs down.

B000069HKH|5.0|This record is nothing less than Springsteen at his best.  It's like I woke up to the Boss in his heyday again.  It's hard to believe that the cataclysmic events of September 11, 2001 have channeled one of rock's greatest voices in such a mesmerizing way.  How fortunate we are that his rededication to passionate musicmaking, along with the band that helped make him famous, have coincided with an urgent need to rebuild a city.    Like a missile honing in on its target, The Rising begins with distant allusions to the event and progressively builds in verisimilitude until the ashes of Ground Zero are staring you in the face.  Intensity rises, too, as more playful tunes adroitly give way to those with dramatic fury.  I love the way images of faith infuse the record as well, giving the downcast, as Springsteen does like no other, something to hold on to when things are very black.    Clarence Clemons' saxophone has never been more uplifting, and the tunes with his solos are some of the record's catchiest.  In the last third of the album, the ballads \\"You're Missing\\", which encapsulates the unspeakable misery of a grieving family, and \\"Paradise\\", which I interpret as the reflections of a suicide bomber in the moments before his death, are stunning lyrical foils on either side of the title track; they beg us to broaden our sympathy for our fellow man and feel how even when at war, we are really one.  The album closer, \\"My City of Ruins,\\" is a rousing call to action in the form of an impassioned gospel-tinged power ballad; it's a poetic missile to my heart.

Overall, I found the book to be a horrible read.  It was painful just to finish.
1400034205|4.0|This, my second exposure to Maugham's work (the first being `The Moon and Sixpence'), has been once again quite satisfactory and I may even add - delightful. True, one loses oneself in the beginning, amidst the overwhelming introduction of what seems meaningless characterization, until one realizes this is very much necessary. By laying out the nature, emotions, environment and aspirations of the characters first, the author can freely move from one actor to another without exhausting the reader.<br />Two individualities stand out in particular amidst this abundant narrative. The first one of socially challenged yet eagerly seeking the meaning of life, knowledge and the nature of God and the second, of the aristocracy, arrogant, snobbish, yet pitifully plain and bleak. The reader quickly becomes attracted to the first with its rich experiences in the far East and wealth of moral lessons. Maugham's story is full with the colors of the 1920's as flamboyance, old money and basic human nature come together to form the substance of what will become the generation of the Great Depression. A truly remarkable experience. If you like his narrative, try `The Moon and Sixpence'.<br /><br />by Simon Cleveland

031606792X|1.0|... would have been a better title in my opinion.       SPOILERS AFTER THIS POINT! YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED!    Beware, this is a review full of personal opinions.    Over the course of the last three novels in the Twilight Saga, we have been introduced to Bella, a rather pretty girl who is taken from her Phoenix home and dropped into the mystery and intrigue of the ever rainy Forks.     I have never been able to get into the books. Bella has always felt rather brain- and spineless to me, Edward like an idealized hero and their \\"love\\" like a dangerously-close-to-abusive dependent relationship. Honesty, maturity and emotional closeness (apart from the ubiquitous \\"I love you\\") have been missing for me. I soldiered on through all three novels since I actually wanted to be able to drop in my two cents at dinner, but I grew more and more disappointed at the lack of development and personality in the series' heroine.    Breaking Dawn started out as New Moon ended, with a happy, exuberant feeling. Every girl's dream wedding has taken place and it's off for the honeymoon.    A few complications from the first time they make love result in Bella begging Edward for sex. Moreover, that sex seems to be the only reason she would want to stay human. I thought I had left reading the book behind and had dropped to somewhere in the Twilight Zone, but eventually Edward caves in, and more horizontal gymnastics ensue, complete with mysterious dreams about a child, which turn out to not be confined to the dreamscape after all.    I really didn't get past Bella's exultation at the news that she was pregnant. As someone who is preparing to go to college (and writing her OWN applications, thank you very much! I like having a brain of my own!) I just sat there staring at the page for close to ten minutes. \\"My heart had grown, swollen to twice its size...\\" and I was expecting something like \\"and I felt like I was going to faint any moment. What about my plans? My future?\\" Instead, you get happywaffling.     I know I'm maybe a little too immature here (but hey, I'm the target demographic!) but for me, having a child at my age would mean the end of the world as I know it. It would pretty much ruin everything I have worked hard for. SM seems to think the most important thing in life is marriage, a beautiful husband, a kid (which you get after only a month of pregnancy, angsty though that month may be) and cottage of your own. This reminds me of the song \\"Somewhere that's green\\" from Little Shop of Horrors, but while that song is satirical, Breaking Dawn means it. For me, this book utterly sank at this point.     Anyway, once the pregnancy-scare-that-isn't is over we have the predictable conversion scene, once again complete with angsting all around. What really struck me was that even though Bella had tons of other things to be worried about, like the possibility of being a danger to humans even though she's got supreme control, or not being a good mother to her baby (which skips all the annoying first development stages and just starts walking and talking a few chapters after its conception), or a psycho werewolf imprinting on a baby, or injuring a third party she is worried about not having good sex anymore.     The final confrontation with the Volturi goes off without a hitch, and to me read little more than lukewarm. The intense feelings the old vampires incited in even a sceptic like me are not rekindled, instead, the scene reads like the n-th rehearsal of a movie script where the actors have already become tired.     One miraculous save later, all is prepared for the happy ending, which of course comes in spades. I normally like happy endings, even when they're sweet to the point of being overly saccharinely happy, but Breaking Dawn just left a stale taste in my mouth. The most important thing I took away from this book was the message that utter subservience (she doesn't even voice her opinion about keeping her child to her husband who wants her to get rid of the risk to her health) and eternal devotion to your husband will make everything turn out alright. Forget developing as a person, forget having your own personality, life or future. A Fifties housewife, that is what you should aspire to be.    I think this message is somewhat dangerous for other teenagers. I have read a lot, and through discussions am somewhat able to place my reactions to this book, but I still teeter between outrage and acceptance. Accepting an unequal relationship- is that really what we female teens are supposed to learn?
031606792X|5.0|I was shocked to see this book was only at 3 stars - so when I looked at the reviews and see all the 1 stars weighing it down - with completely twisted and/or lame logic to their disappointments, I had to take a sec and vote - YES!    ***spoiler alert***    How can it be a bad message for young girls to have a happy ending?! I'm GLAD we didn't have to go through a bunch of angst and remorse over her \\"choice\\" to become one, as some of those 1-star people were looking forward to.  There were much bigger and better things going on for pete's sake!  And let me say I'm doubly glad we didn't have more Jacob angst, as some 1-stars were hoping for.  Enough of that already.    And for those looking for a \\"message\\" - there are PLENTY of great messages in this story - AS LONG AS IT DOESN'T HAVE TO BE \\"life sucks and then you die.\\"  (ha ha Jake)    How 'bout - we all have greater potential than we realize, just like Bella?    How 'bout - never give up?    How 'bout - love and family really are the things worth fighting for in life?    How 'bout - the good guys really can and do win?    How 'bout - Bella and Alice save the day? (Now there's a \\"women are weak\\" message for you -  as the 1-stars are touting)   How 'bout - there really is someone out there for everyone - if we're honest, we all believe that - and that is a GOOD thing - not a\\"women are weak\\" conspiracy.  How 'bout - selflessness is possibly the greatest virtue?    For me, the real sign of Stehenie M.'s gift as a writer is that I - and lot's of other people - truly love Bella, and Edward, and Jake, and Alice, etc.  It feels like they're out there somewhere.  And I am SO GLAD THEY'RE OK!!!

031606792X|5.0|Wrapping up all of the loose ends of the Twilight series would not have been a task that I would have willed onto myself. Yet, every obsessed and irrationally devoted fan, myself in that category, expected Stephenie Meyer to do this with minimum surprises. We all predicted what we foresaw in the final installment in the Twilight series, allowing our minds to deal with every imperfection that we dreamed up. We dealt with the loose ends because our minds did not come up with perfect ways to explain the unexplainables.<br /><br />Stephenie Meyer did. Perhaps she was planning this ending all along, or she sat up endless nights concocting, not the most acceptable, but the most ideal conclusion for her bestselling saga. This idealness was not in the minds of her fans, but in her characters'.<br /><br />The fact that Bella had a baby girl, a daughter that her best friend Jacob imprinted on was THE way to explain the books. It made Bella's infatuation with Jacob after Edward returned in New Moon fathomable. She needed him around so that her unborn daughter's destiny would be fulfilled. And, although her pregnancy was possibly the most unexpected situation that could have occured within the minds of the Twilight fandom, it was right. And, by the way, as a sixteen year old girl, I do not feel the sudden need to run out and become pregnant, although some readers believe that this is the first action that a person my age will take after reading Breaking Dawn.<br /><br />Now, I was undecided about the novel after the first read. The surprise, the shock and the fact that my body was running on two hours of sleep until I finished the 754 pages of the book were certainly factors in my lack of confidence in Stephenie Meyer. Yet, minutes ago I finished the book again, and I am absolutely convinced that this ending that all are screaming about was the most solid ending that Meyer could give her books.<br /><br />So my advice is to read this book again before passing judgement. Read it from a perspective that is incapable of being surprised. Savor the humor and romance that we all loved in the last three installments. You will be surprised.<br /><br />I love this book, but I am not saying that it is without flaw, despite my five star rating. The thing that propelled me the most to read the series was the scenes of Edward and Bella in solitude; the span of pages where nothing happened but conversation and passion from the two soulmates. These scenes were almost nonapparent in Breaking Dawn; there was simply so much plot for one book that something so uneventful would be able to take up space. I truly missed Edward in this book, although his name was apparent on almost every page.<br /><br />The first time through, the book is too weird to be beautiful. However, after the second read, at least for me, it became gratifying. Stephenie Meyer was ultimately successful in wrapping up her series without being too corny, the main complaint within these reviews. She did not ruin the book, and I will not burn it OR return it.<br /><br />Meyer concluded the series as best as was possible, and I think that all that happened simply needed to happen. Besides, the last two and a half pages, where Edward is able to read Bella's mind, is the most undeniably incredible and perfect ending to the series.capable of being surprised. Savor the humor and romance that we all loved in the last three installments. You will be surprised.    I love this book, but I am not saying that it is without flaw, despite my five star rating. The thing that propelled me the most to read the series was the scenes of Edward and Bella in solitude; the span of pages where nothing happened but conversation and passion from the two soulmates. These scenes were almost nonapparent in Breaking Dawn; there was simply so much plot for one book that something so uneventful would be able to take up space. I truly missed Edward in this book, although his name was apparent on almost every page.     The first time through, the book is too weird to be beautiful. However, after the second read, at least for me, it became gratifying. Stephenie Meyer was ultimately successful in wrapping up her series without being too corny, the main complaint within these reviews. She did not ruin the book, and I will not burn it OR return it.     Meyer concluded the series as best as was possible, and I think that all that happened simply needed to happen. Besides, the last two and a half pages, where Edward is able to read Bella's mind, is the most undeniably incredible and perfect ending to the series.

0810993139|4.0|If there was an \\"IT\\" book of 2008 in the school where I teach 5th grade, forget about Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows; it had to be Jeff Kinney's Diary of a Wimpy Kid. Book orders could not send copies fast enough. Book stores could not restock their shelves quickly enough. Everywhere I turned I was met by a student with his or her nose buried in its pages. So naturally, I had to see what all the fuss was about.<br /><br />Greg Heffley is your everyday, run-of-the-mill, middle school \\"wimp\\". Sure, someday he's going to amount to something big, but for now, he's \\"stuck in middle school with a bunch of morons.\\" Greg's journal, not \\"diary\\", but \\"journal\\", takes us through the hilarious events that make up Greg's days in his first year of middle school. Lucky for us, whether it's avoiding his older brother Rodrick, or abusing his best friend Rowley, Greg's days are never short on laughs.<br /><br />I can't remember the last time I laughed this hard when reading a book. There are laughs on every page, literally. Greg's mudslinging student council posters, Greg and Rowley's failed attempt at a haunted house, the students' wrestling unit in PE (\\"muscles are gross\\"), and Christmas time at the Heffley home. Situations like these that Greg finds himself in are comical enough, but it's his voice and commentary that sets this book apart. Jeff Kinney has cleverly captured the inner workings of a middle school student, and because of this book's popularity, it's obvious that students connect with Greg.<br /><br />However, that's also what scares me about this book. I'm afraid that Kinney is too smart for his own good and without realizing it, has created a lovable character that advocates laziness and using your best friend for his family's money and his video games. Beneath all the laughs, Greg is a deceitful, selfish, jerk of a boy and the fact that students relate to him so easily doesn't sit well with me. I admit, I laughed hysterically at Kinney's tongue-in-cheek irony, but I'm an adult. I can tell the difference between Greg the character being serious and Jeff the author being sarcastic. I'm not so sure all the kids reading this will be able to.<br /><br />I'm torn though. This book is funny and relevant and I guess if children are excited about reading it, then who am I to complain. Any time children WANT to read, it's a good thing, and I commend Kinney for this. He's discovered a great medium to tell his stories. The pictures only add to the humor and the journal format makes for an easy read. I think most of my students would be able to distinguish between Greg's selfish behavior and acceptable, respectful behavior, and if they don't, eh . . . kids will be kids. Either way, I have a feeling that Kinney is going to be around for a while. I may be better off enjoying the laughs.tell the difference between Greg the character being serious and Jeff the author being sarcastic. I'm not so sure all the kids reading this will be able to.    I'm torn though. This book is funny and relevant and I guess if children are excited about reading it, then who am I to complain. Any time children WANT to read, it's a good thing, and I commend Kinney for this. He's discovered a great medium to tell his stories. The pictures only add to the humor and the journal format makes for an easy read. I think most of my students would be able to distinguish between Greg's selfish behavior and acceptable, respectful behavior, and if they don't, eh . . . kids will be kids. Either way, I have a feeling that Kinney is going to be around for a while. I may be better off enjoying the laughs.
