0385340990|5.0|Well, because I rarely read fiction, I am both surprised and delighted to give this volume 5 stars!  I normally would not have bought it, but I had just arrived home from a trip that included Guernsey and was enchanted by the island.  (I just wish that the book had been published before my visit, because I would have looked at Guernsey with quite different eyes, considering more the historical and imaginary facets pertaining thereto.)<br /><br />Written as a series of letters all dated in 1946, the protagonist Juliet--a 33-year-old literary wit living alone in London--begins an unlikely correspondence with an obscure book club in the English Channel, recovering from their Nazi occupation during WW II.  She hopes to use their input as material for an article or a book, and so she coaxes from a motley crew their remarkable stories hewn from an infamous time in history.  Juliet's humor and angst sparkle, as does her compassion.  Without giving the story away, I will say that her collection of letters is endearing and finally call her to move to Guernsey, where the plot thickens.  There is a romantic interest or two, a witch, a gay editor, a child, a heroine who died in a concentration camp, much discussion about books and reading, a village shrew, and so forth.  I couldn't put it down!  My only carps about the book are that it ended rather predictably but abruptly, out of pace with the rest of the book, and that there was no recipe included for a potato peel pie . . .
031606792X|5.0|I loved it! Everything works out the way I would have done it myself, almost all the loose strings are tied off.  I felt closure, and I got an emotional roller-coaster ride on the way there.  You people who are upset because you think everything worked out too perfectly and that's not realistic; if you're looking for realism what are you doing reading a book about vampires and warewolves, excuse me, shape shifters?  Isn't real life depressing enough that you want to read stuff that makes you more depressed? I would rather read something that is uplifting, like this book.  Good job Stephenie Meyer.  The only thing that bugs me is, what happens to Leah?

B00004R7X5|4.0|The Scheherezade is still one of my favorite pieces - easy to listen to and it keeps your interest.  It has more brass than a lot of classical pieces, and a catchy violin theme.    Capriccio Italien bounces around the same way Scheherezade does, with a lot of nice melodies and a constantly changing tempo.  Well executed and conducted, this piece makes me smile every time I hear it.    Now, the stinker: the choir for the Ouverture Solennelle does a deplorable job.  Anyone who praises this CD and doesn't mention this clearly has not actually listened to it.  The orchestra is masterful as always, but the brass players are clearly out of their league near the finale.  A fart covers up roses every time.

For many of us, things and events that we were hoping for were left hanging, at times. There were times that I wanted to rewrite scenes to fit my own agenda but that would, ultimately, take the fun out of reading the book in the first place.    Finally, as usual, I found myself emotionally exhausted at the end of the book. For me, I use that measure as a tool to determine if a story is worth telling a friend about. And so, I will continue to talk about the Twilight series.     If I were a parent of children under the age of 15, I would have concerns about them reading this book. The sexuality in it is more explicit then the others but still not so much that can't be discussed between parent and child. Harry finds this to be like listening to fingernail scratches on a chalkboard. He's also having house problems: His stilt-based house with a great view has been condemned by the city after the big earthquake. The earthquake also shook his girlfriend so much that she left town.<br /><br />Frustrated that he can't work, Harry decides to take a look at the file on his mother's death. From there, he begins to work the case. It's a tremendous opportunity for readers to understand Harry's youthful years much better. As you might expect, not all things are as they seemed at the time of the murder. Uncovering the truth is difficult and painful. But in the end, justice is done.<br /><br />One of the beauties of this book is how much it shows about a range of emotions and motives that people employ to look out for themselves. In a way, Harry is an aficionado of depravity, it's part of being human. It's just that he has to stop it when it goes too far . . . or arrange for justice when the eggs cannot be unscrambled any more.<br /><br />I don't recall a more bittersweet story in this series. 031606792X|4.0|First of all, I want to say that before I read any of Meyer's books I was deathly afraid of vampires.  Yes, I knew they didn't exist, but after watching a vampire movie, I would be haunted for weeks with horrible thoughts of demons lurking in shadows.  I was leary about reading the books because of this fear.  But, my views on vampires have changed dramatically since reading the Twilight Saga.  I went from fearing vampires to being in love with one (yes I'm happily married to a human), and now, after reading #4, I want to be a vampire.  Seriously, Meyer just makes it sound like so much fun!    Now to my review  (there are some spoilers).  I'm a little shocked and annoyed at all the negative low star givers out there.  Lets remember a few things here: First, this is young-adult fiction; second, it's NOT REAL- it's a FAIRLY-TALE, things are supposed to end happily-ever-after!  Third, what's wrong with Bella choosing marriage and family over education and a career?  Someone said she was being selfish by doing that.  I fail to see how choosing to give her life so she could have her baby was selfish.  Also, you may say \\"Well, she really didn't choose family because she gave up Charlie and her mom.\\"  But that all worked out too (hence, the 'happily-ever-after' part of the story).  If you want to read a boring, pointless book about a girl who had a chance to have joy and happiness with those she loved but gave it up to go to college and \\"have a life\\" go ahead.  By the way, remember that she has eternity to educate herself.  It's not like she's going to just sit around forever staring into space.  Since when is choosing to be a mom and wife a bad thing?  Yes, she didn't think she wanted those things, but I'm very glad that she was pleasantly surprised to find that she did.  And, who cares if the ending is too \\"happily-ever-after\\"!  That's the point in a fairy-tale! Whew, I said my piece on that and feel much better.    A few other things.  I have to admit that through the other books I wasn't sure how felt about Bella.  I wanted to like her but wasn't sure.  But now, after reading the final story, I really like her.  I almost think that Meyer wanted readers to be unsure about Bella because she was unsure about herself too.  But she finally becomes who she is meant to be, and I really enjoyed discovering that with her.  She makes an awesome vampire!      Yes, I really enjoyed this book.  There were some things that happened that I predicted before the book came out, but there were things that I did not expect at all, so that was fun.  I also enjoyed Jacob's point of view, mostly for the sarcasm.  But, it's not my favorite book out of all of them, although I love them all.  There were a few slow moving parts where I kind of wanted to say, \\"Okay, lets get on with it.\\"  And, I think I have to agree with most people and say what is up with that name?  Renesmee?  Couldn't there have been anything better than that?  I'm just glad it wasn't a boy because EJ was worse.    I was a little nervous that I wouldn't be happy with the book's ending.  I just couldn't see how it could end in a way where so many loose ends would be neatly tied up.  But Meyer did it, and did it well, I thought.  I feel perfectly content with it.  Some people don't like that it's too happily-ever-after, but ignore them.  Go read a depressing book if that's what you're after or go read a memior full of real life drama.  I prefer to endulge in a nice, happy fairy tale that makes me feel good.  One reason I love these books is they remind me of the things that I love about my life so much.  They make me remember falling in love with my husband, all of our firsts we had together, and the happily-ever-after we have waiting (sorry, I'm cheesy- it's just how I am).  So, just remember this is ficion and a fairy-tale.  It's supposed to end happily-ever-after.    Oh, I just thought of another thing that bugs me about some reviews.  Jacob imprinting on Nessie is not gross.  Whoeverthinks that- you're the gross one.  Jacob and Quil make that clear that's not what it's about.  So, grow up people.

031606792X|1.0|WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD!     First, I have to mention that I loved the first three books. I have read and re-read them more times than I care to count. Like millions of others, I anticipated the release of BD to finally see the conclusion of Bella and Edward's story.     I was disappointed.    It wasn't the fact that BD didn't stick to average YA novels that bothered me. I'm 22, and mature enough for any adult concepts. I have never considered the series to be teeny-targeted anyway. It was a flat plot line and completely unexpected--in a bad way-- plot twists that made me dislike this book so much.     Like many other readers, I felt like I was reading fanfiction--a well-written piece of fanfiction, mind you, but not SM's creation nevertheless. The characters didn't seem true to themselves, and the carefully built-up Twilight universe was shattered upon creation of Renesmee. (I'll try to refrain from any scathing remarks about the name choice. Albus Severus, I want even you back!)     Of course, there were some moments/issues that I loved. For example, I didn't mind loads of physical intimacy during the honeymoon (I actually half-cheered them to go for it) , and Bella not wanting to give up her humanity for physical love. They are newlyweds after all, for heaven's sake. Furthermore, I loved finally seeing Jacob and Edward reconcile, and for the werewolf to find his happy ending. Even imprinting on Bella's daughter makes sense in a twisted, grotesque kind of way.    However, there are hundreds of plot turns and moments I hated about this book.   First, the mere existence of Renesmee (sp?). In all the previous novels there hasn't been a single hint about male vampires containing their fertility. We were told that fluids were absent from their bodies and were replaced by venom. Frankly, I felt cheated by the loophole Stephenie left herself with: \\"most\\" fluids were absent. Not all.     Second, Bella's pregnancy. It freaked me out that Cullens had a mini hospital in their house to keep Bella alive. It did make sense plot-wise, but made my reading very uncomfortable. Then, of course, the birth scene, which was gross and disturbing. And it wasn't blood, or spine breaking, or even Edward \\"chewing the baby out\\" that disturbed me---ridiculously, I was perverted by the image of Bella trashing like a fish on the table, completely vulnerable and naked, and Jacob (despite himself) getting a good glimpse of her.     Thrid, Bella as a newborn. I would have expected for her to experience the world through the red haze of thirst, but no. She was in perfect control of her senses. I half-wanted her to be clumsy for vampire standards, but, of course, she was more graceful than an average vampire.     I could go on and on. I didn't like Mary Sue aka Renesmee, which everyone found adorable except for me. I would have loved to see Volturi in action--not like a meaningless threat in billowing grey cloaks. Or at least for someone to kill of Jane and Alec. And what about Renee? And Bella's human friends?     I guess what bothered me the most in this book is Bella getting everything she has ever wanted without any price to pay. Admittedly, these series play in the fantasy world, but there has to be some sense of reality interweaving the fairy tale. You can't get what you want without sacrificing a part of yourself, this isn't how the world works.     Alas, I feel no sense of closure or satisfaction after completing the book. The Twilight Saga had so much potential for a truly breathtaking ending, but this fiasco ruined it for me completely. I'll just live in an illusion that the series concluded with Eclipse.
031606792X|5.0|I understand why some people would think that Breaking Dawn is a let down but for me it was positively addicting. OK, sure, I'll give it to the minority that hated it that the whole book seemed rushed and the pace in general was very quick but I'm not complaining! Call me a sucker for happy endings. I was on an emotional high ride. All time high, might I add. Stephenie kept surprising me all the way through and even though it seems like she's trying to tie every loose end without thinking about it (what with, the introduction to many new characters/vampires) and all, I think it was absolutely necessary. She wrote Twilight for her own pleasure, continued with New Moon and Eclipse and completed the saga with this epic finale the way she always intended for it to be finished. I don't think it's for any of us to judge. It's entirely subjective and if Stephenie is happy with it then  I am ... because to be honest, I felt closure too. That's all I have to say. Here's to an eternity of lifetime happiness for Bella, Edward, Renesmee and the family.

If Bella just turned into a vampire, people would be angry. If she didn't they would be angry. Even though most people hate to admit it, they were looking for a happy ending. I couldn't predict a thing about this book, and I loved it. It has been a while since I haven't been able to do that. She knows how happy it makes her now, the future is unknown. I would totally do what Bella did, sex is such a special emotional experience. There are no bad morals in this tale in my eyes, just silly people blowing things out of proportions saying there is. I can not wait until Meyer writes a different book, I have the Host, but I am waiting for the next one. She writes with such passion, and I find that addicting.
031606792X|4.0|When I checked Amazon on Saturday 8/2 to see if anyone read BD I was shocked to see how many bad reviews it received.  I didn't read all the comments because I hadn't finished and didn't want to spoil the book for myself.  Even though I can understand and agree with a few of the complaints, I decided to just let myself enjoy the final book in this amazing series with my favorite characters.      From what I've seen we seem to agree that the pregnancy and the imprinting was too weird or convenient.  I was surprised that Bella had a baby with a vampire but any fan of \\"Angel\\" can tell you this is not the first time a vampire has had a child.  Maybe that is why I was able to accept this a little better than some.  In mythology anything can happen and even though it is hard to swallow in the Twilight universe a baby can be conceived by a human and vampire.  If everyone was able to suspend their belief that  a teenage girl can love a vampire then I hope everyone can go back to BD with an open mind.  I can't however explain Jacob imprinting on Nessie.  I felt that was a way of trying to appease all the Jacob fans; if Jacob can't have Bella what is the next best thing?  Her daughter.....that was too much for me.  I was pushing for Leah and was upset that avenue was given to us just to take it away.    I really did enjoy seeing Edward and Bella's relationship evolve.  I read somewhere that someone was upset that all they had was sex.  Well being honeymooners and exploring their relationship to me is a natural progression.  I think Stephenie Meyer handled it very well.  Of course they are going to be intimate whenever they can.  They are married and when Edward is finally able to not hold back that was the final piece that cemented their union.  I'm glad SM acknowledged it  and wasn't scared of the fact that this book is a YA novel.  Let's face it girls at 16(even younger) know sex is out there.  SM handled this very maturely: Bella was 18, married and in love with the man she knew she was going to be with forever.       Great moments in the book: the wedding, the honeymoon, Alice, whenever Jacob and Edward spoke to each other, Nessie showing everyone how she speaks, the cottage and finally having the Volturi back.  That was exhilarating.  I couldn't put the book down when they showed up.      Some will agree with what I said and some won't.  All I want to really say is keep an open mind.  We all had expectations and some were met, some went in totally strange directions but in the end we were witness to the great love story between an average teenage girl and her not so average vampire boyfriend.  I personally enjoyed the journey.
031606792X|4.0|A breakdown of my opinion:  *there are lots of spoilers here*    The Good:  -A happy ending. I know, i know, life doesn't work out like that, there should be consequences for marrying and having a kid at 18 and blah blah blah, but its nice sometimes to read fun, unrealistic fantasies where the characters you love get everything they ever wanted and none of them have to die for it. Maybe thats 'trite' or whatever, but I've always been a sucker for fairy tales and happily ever afters.   -Bella having a kid. yeah, she was young, but Bella has been trying to be a mother to everyone since Twilight (taking care of Renee, cooking and cleaning for Charlie, constantly trying to protect *everyone* etc etc) and it was just sad to me that she would never have a kid. and, better yet, she got to have Edward's kid!  -the wedding. I especially loved that Bella *finally* saw herself as beautiful for once.   -Bella's transformation: exactly as I thought it would be. Her trying her hardest to keep quiet so Edward wouldn't do his overly guilty thing.   -Bella's self-control as a new vampire. I liked that *finally*, after being the weak link in everything always, Bella gets to show off her strength a little and amaze everyone. and shes graceful too. :)  -Jacob's imprinting on Bella's daughter. some people seem to have a problem with this, thinking that its pedophilia or a cop out or sort of twisted that he can just forget about Bella when he loved her and all that. But all this was explained in Eclipse. Why is it fine to accept that Sam could have forgotten Leah, and that Quil could imprint on Claire, but not that Jacob could imprint on Bella's baby. There isn't anything sexual about the whole imprinting thing on babies, so no pedophilia. I liked that it was the eyes, Bella's eyes, that he noticed first about the baby...  -getting into Jake's head a little. it was fun to see his struggle with the pack, and interesting to see Edward-Bella from his point of view.  -Bella's Shield power. Throughout the whole series, her strongest instinct has been to protect the people she loves. It was nice to see that played out.   -Edward *finally* being able to get into her head, if only briefly. :)    The Bad:  -the dialogue!!! some of the things the characters say in this book seem very out of character to me. For instance they started calling Jasper Jazz when they never had before. And I definitely made a face at Bella telling Edward he was killing her buzz. ugh.   -most of the honeymoon, aside from the first night. Even Bella's thoughts during that seemed a little off. She wasn't getting angry or annoyed or making snarky comments like she always does. it was weird. maybe it was supposed to be because of her pregnancy...  -The overall feel of the end of the first book, and beginning of the second. It seemed different from the other books. I think because it was more plot driven rather than character-driven. Too much on what was happening and not enough of what Bella (and Jake) thought about what was happening. doesn't make it terrible writing, it was just a departure from the rest of the books. It was back to normal once we get back to Bella in book 3.   -her telling Charlie but not Renee. I didn't get how that would work exactly. what would keep her away, if they didn't tell her Bella was dead? and I didn't get what had kept her from coming to the hospital she thought Bella was in.   -Renesmee. the name, not the character. Edward didn't even *try* to talk her out of it. ugh. Carlie Renesmee would have been far, *far* better. Nessie was ok though. sort of. I guess.     Other comments:  -I have read reviews that say that the book is anti-feminist, and that Bella is always looking to be taken care of. I want to disagree with that. Bella has always wanted to take care of everybody, often at her own expense. And she hates when people have to take care of her (like running around her house in the rain) and when they have to fight to protect her. I also don't thinkthat the fact that Edward is so damnably overprotective is a knock against feminism. She rebels against his overprotection in what ways she can. Refusing to drop the subject of what he was in Twilight, going to Volterra, and going over his head with the transformation thing in New Moon, sneaking out to La Push in Eclipse.       anyway, thats my two cents. or fifty...

031606792X|5.0|I thought Breaking Dawn was a great ending to a wonderful series.  New Moon will always be my favorite, but Breaking Dawn answers questions, ties up loose ends, and gives a happy ending to Bella and Edward's story.    From Bella's pre-wedding jitters to the alternately romantic and hilarious honeymoon to all the shock and fear and excitement that comes next, Stephenie Meyer takes the reader on a rollercoaster of emotions.  I was gripping the book so tightly in some parts that my fingers cramped, and for the last few pages I had to stop reading periodically to wipe away tears and blow my nose.      I've read complaints about people being out of character in this book which I don't understand.  They all seemed spot on to me.  Of course there are changes from Twilight but then Bella and Edward have been through a lot since that fateful biology class.  They aren't the same people they were then, so they aren't going to act the same.  Even Edward's seemingly reprehensible request of Jacob early in the second part of the book is in character, because that's how he is -- anguished, blaming himself for Bella's plight, he'll do anything to save her life, even if it means asking the unthinkable.  Look at what he did in New Moon.  When it comes to Bella, Edward would rather cut off his own arm than hurt her.    And really, people, Renesmee is freaking adorable.  And the name sorta grows on you.  It's no worse than people naming their kids Kayden and Jayelle and all the other weird made-up names you hear these days.

B0018AK9RA|5.0|As amazing as \\"Angel Of Retribution\\", the reunion album for the classic line-up of Judas Priest, the metal masters from the U.K., is; this album is actually a great follow-up to it. The band really shows their professional and sophisticated sides with this album. There are so many very clever, original, unique, and catchy guitar riffs and solos throughout the whole entire album. K.K. Downig and Glenn Tipton really prove what guitar legends they are once again. The same goes for the excellent bass work from Ian Hill. The drum tempos from Scott Travis are very awesome and lively without losing a beat even once. Rob Halford also brings out each track perfectly with his awesome unique vocals and with the right depth and emotions throughout the whole album. There are also so many great clever unique mixings of the rhythms and melodies with the vocals and different instruments all going together perfectly to create a great unique art to the album.    As the title suggests, the album is based on \\"The Book Of Nostradamus\\". The band even mentions on the inside cover:    \\"Intrigue continues to surround the mystery of Nostradamus. Five hundred years since his passing Judas Priest undertake what is considered to be our most ambitious musical adventure to date.\\"    Their little written introduction covers a decent-lengthed summary of Nostradamus's life and concludes with:    \\"All of us in Judas Priest have enjoyed an extraordinary experience making our metal form into this man's life and we hope that you, our fans, derive the same feelings now as you listen and let your mind escape with 'Nostradamus'\\".    The song titles even suggest that the album covers his philosophies on the dawn of creation, his prophecy, his awakening, his revelations, the four horsemen, war, sands of time, pestilence and plague, death, peace, conquest, lost love, persecution, solitude, exiled, alone, shadows in the flame, visions, hope, new beginnings, calm before the storm, and even his predictions on the future of mankind. The lyrics are well thought out and in very good detail. Rob Halford brings each and every one of those tracks out perfectly with the right depth and emotions to add on to his unique vocals. The music also backs him up perfectly with the right sounds, beats, rhythms, tones, and moods. There are no dull moments to this album with no getting sloppy even once and nobody missing a beat even once either.    This album is a true masterpiece and definitely one of the better Judas Priest albums ever. Rob Halford is already expecting a Grammy Award for this album, due to all the hype from a lot of people about it, the many people who pre-ordered their copies before it was released, as well as the great sales and high profits it is continuing to make with spots on different music charts.

B00000DOY9|3.0|More obsessive Zeppelin fans than I have sort of claimed this album as their own. They can keep it, far as I'm concerned. It's not bad or anything, but there's not much to really recommend here, either.<br />Still, the record does contain two great songs. Their names are... \\"Candy Store Rock\\" and \\"Tea for One!\\" Whoo! No, actually, those songs suck. \\"Candy Store Rock\\" is stiff, ham-fisted rockabilly, and \\"Tea for One\\" is one of the worst songs I've ever heard in my life. It's a nine-minute blues so similar to \\"Since I've Been Loving You\\" (only with guitars replacing the organ and without the big emotional release), that it might as well be a remix. Plant's lyrics are cliched as ever, and Page's lengthy solo is just him taking a bunch of trite blues licks and stringing them together. No good.<br />No, the best songs on this album are \\"Achilles Last Stand\\" and \\"Nobody's Fault but Mine.\\" On \\"Achilles,\\" Page goes insane with the guitar overdubs, letting loose a career's worth of brilliant riffs in ten minutes. It's got time signature changes, guitar solos, galloping bass parts, and sections where the band morphs into a jackhammer. \\"Nobody's Fault But Mine,\\" meanwhile, is a Blind Willie Johnson blues that lets Page and Plant show off their skills on guitar and harmonica, respectively. But the real appeal of the tune is in the pauses. which make the heavy parts of the song sound even heavier.<br />The remaining three songs I could do without. There's some interesting guitar stuff on both \\"For Your Life\\" and \\"Royal Orleans\\" (both concerning the group's assorted misadventures with decadence), and I appreciate how they kinda change things up on \\"Orleans\\" with odd drumming, but neither of them are impressive. I would hesitate to even call them \\"good.\\" Mediocre, maybe. I actually kind of like \\"Hots on for Nowhere.\\" It's moderately funky, and has a catchy nonsense chorus. But it's by no means great.<br />So there you have it. \\"Achilles\\" and \\"Nobody's Fault\\" rule, \\"Tea for One\\" and \\"Candy Store Rock\\" suck, and the rest is in the middle. I can't think of any reason to buy it, seeing that both the great songs always make it onto compilations. And did you know \\"Candy Store Rock\\" was released as a single? Yikes...Rock\\" suck, and the rest is in the middle. I can't think of any reason to buy it, seeing that both the great songs always make it onto compilations. And did you know \\"Candy Store Rock\\" was released as a single? Yikes...

031606792X|5.0|----SPOILERS BELOW----    Breaking Dawn is the best book in the Twilight Saga. Period. Ignore what people say about what the author's message was. Who cares? There's nothing wrong with writing a book where everyone is happy in the end. Nothing wrong at all.    Of course, having everyone so happy in the end and having everything work out so perfectly is probably not very realistic. But thats why its FICTION! Its the perfect fairy tale story where everyone finds happiness, sometimes where they least expect it.     I was very impressed with how Stephenie covered after wedding events. I was also impressed with how Stephenie brought everyone together in the end, particularly when vampires from around the world banded together to protect something unheard of and very different, Edward and Bella's child. And don't forget that the werewolves also put aside their sometimes hard feelings for vampires and banded with them.    Bella and her father, Charlie, also work out a way that they can still be close family without endangering his life. That's not something I expected but was happy to see work out. It shows that families can work through even the toughest of circumstances.    And while I certainly would never get married and have a baby at the age of 18, its definitely not a crime or something worth judging a person over. Especially when the parents take responsibility. End of story.    You will laugh, smile, be angry, sad and you just might shed a tear during a few tender moments. This book is a great escape into a touching fairy tale filled with life's problems, issues and surprisingly happy endings.
031606792X|1.0|*spoilers*    The choice to inexplicably change the perspective of the story by telling a large portion of this final book from Jacob's point of view, especially during a crucial (and shocking) development for Bella (who's story this has been all along) dismays me. It creates such distance between the reader and Bella to have her entire pregnancy told in someone else's voice. From that point on I had trouble investing in the story because I was staggered as to how we as readers were supposed to be accepting of so many abrupt changes that didn't seem to phase any the characters themselves. There was so much emphasis on a galloping plot, that little time was used to show the characters reflecting on the massive changes happening around them.     I'm disheartened by the drastic way this series lurches to an end with Breaking Dawn.

031606792X|5.0|***CONTAINS SPOILERS***<br />I'm actually glad I read some of the other reviews before posting mine because I feel like it gave me a basis for several arguments as to why I believed this book to be amazing.  So many people are complaining about the fact that it was \\"tied up in a bow\\", but remember people - This is a fairy tale.  Fairy tales are SUPPOSED to have fairy tale endings.<br /><br />Now, this is not to say that I wasn't shocked when Bella discovered she was pregnant.  I was.  But, I believe it added more depth to the story and, ultimately, to the characters of both Bella and Edward.  People are saying that Meyer's messages regarding sacrifice were lost because \\"Bella got everything she wanted\\".  But, did anyone stop to think about all the things Bella was WILLING to lose to save Renesmee?  That's still sacrifice, guys, even if the follow-through didn't have to happen.<br /><br />As for \\"losing Edward\\" - I did find that his character was not the forefront of this novel so much as in the others.  And, I'd be lying if I didn't admit that I missed some of his old romantic antics (which I felt peaked in Eclipse).  BUT, that being said, this book was meant to be about Bella's feelings as a newborn.  She CHANGED, people.  You can't expect that everything about their relationship, or the way the couple acted, would be the same.  Bella became a stronger entity by becoming a vampire, so it's only natural that Edward would APPEAR to be weaker in a sense.  Also, the focus for both PARENTS was the protection of their daughter.  They couldn't rightfully think only of themselves anymore - That just makes sense.<br /><br />As for Jacob, while I do think the minutes leading up to his imprinting on Renesmee were a little obvious, I don't find it obsurd that this is the approach that Meyer took with the story.  It tied in really well with the notion that Jacob and Bella's lives were fated to be linked in some way.  AND, it provided a WEALTH of potential story material for novels in the future.  And let's face it - I think we'd ALL like to see that.<br /><br />OK - So now that I'm happy with my rebuttals to the arguments I was reading a minute ago, I'd like to make a couple outside observations of why I think this was another great example of Meyer's talent as a writer and story teller.<br /><br />By using Jacob's perspective for the second book in the novel, it gave the reader a real sense of transition.  When we left Bella on the island, we knew she would never be the same.  And when we met her again in book three, it was as the vampire she was always destined to be.  Genius.<br /><br />I also LOVED Bella's \\"super power\\" of the shield and the fact that Meyer didn't waste time portraying Bella as a \\"typical\\" newborn.  Nothing about Bella has ever been \\"normal\\", so it would've weakened the story (and made it really tedious to read) if she had gone against that grain now.<br /><br />AND, I really liked the messages Meyer told about what lengths a mother is willing to go to, to protect her child.  Bella's allegiance with Rosalie, Leah's conversation with Jacob defending the behavior, Bella's belief in Alice's plans for their future...  All of those things are just supporting that message.<br /><br />I could go on for a good long while about the great things about this book.  I thought it was absolutely fantastic!<br /><br />My only complaint now is that it's over...s face it - I think we'd ALL like to see that.    OK - So now that I'm happy with my rebuttals to the arguments I was reading a minute ago, I'd like to make a couple outside observations of why I think this was another great example of Meyer's talent as a writer and story teller.      By using Jacob's perspective for the second book in the novel, it gave the reader a real sense of transition.  When we left Bella on the island, we knew she would never be the same.  And when we met her again in book three, it was as the vampire she was always destined to be.  Genius.    I also LOVED Bella's \\"super power\\" of the shield and the fact that Meyer didn't waste time portraying Bella as a \\"typical\\" newborn.  Nothing about Bella has ever been \\"normal\\", so it would've weakened the story (and made it really tedious to read) if she had gone against that grain now.    AND, I really liked the messages Meyer told about what lengths a mother is willing to go to, to protect her child.  Bella's allegiance with Rosalie, Leah's conversation with Jacob defending the behavior, Bella's belief in Alice's plans for their future...  All of those things are just supporting that message.    I could go on for a good long while about the great things about this book.  I thought it was absolutely fantastic!      My only complaint now is that it's over...

031606792X|4.0|...which was to be entertained.    Reading the Twilight series in the last three years, I have learned not to expect \\"great literature\\" from Meyer. I'm not raving about her writing, nor do I think she's a particularly thought-provoking author who can stir deep emotions or questions about values and such. If I wanted those things, I would pick a different book or author (Ian McEwan comes to mind). But I think Meyer can spin a good story--one that is fantastic, at times ludicrous, but thoroughly entertaining. In this sense, she has her own gift as a storyteller.    Breaking Dawn is not different from the rest of the series, though perhaps darker, more gruesome, more sexual, more transitions for the characters. There was also more Jacob, which put me off a bit, as I felt disconnected from Bella and Edward in his Book. But how much more fantastic is the idea of a \\"monster spawn\\" than a high school girl cavorting with vampires and werewolves? In Meyer's world it is just as fantastic, and therefore just as plausible. I suspended all disbelief and went along for the ride.    And quite a ride it was. I laughed, cried a bit, was shocked at some parts, felt thrilled, felt romantic, and was kept up all night reading it. In other words, I enjoyed it. I don't love it, but neither do I hate it. But I was engaged while reading it, which was what I was hoping and expecting. Therefore, my rating of 4 stars.

031606792X|1.0|This book is such a disappointment.  And that's putting it lightly.    The author has a huge fan base; this much is clear. Before this book, I thought the strongest book in this series was the 3rd book, for the simple reason that the stakes were higher and Bella seemed to finally realize that in order for her to become a vampire and be with Edward forever, she had to make choices that would involve sacrifice on her part - for example, having to be away from her father and other humans for her \\"newborn\\" years and giving up so many human experiences.  For these reasons, I looked forward to Breaking Dawn.  I wanted to see how Bella would react to the transformation or if it would even happen overall.  I wanted to see her struggle with the new life she chose and have her come to terms with what she gave up and decide if it was worth it.    Sadly, this was not to be.  And therein lies the basic problem with this book.    One thing that constantly annoyed me about Bella in previous books was how eager she was to become a vampire and be with Edward forever, but she was so reluctant to marry him.  I failed to see how marrying someone is more of a commitment than becoming immortal and being with the person for all of eternity.  To be perfectly honest, there were many things I didn't like about the previous books; I simply overlooked them in favor of the greater story.  Sure, plenty of editing should have been done, but that was okay because the story was still interesting.    In Breaking Dawn, Bella and Edward marry very soon after the book opens, and it just goes downhill from there.  Plot twists were completely unbelievable and came out of nowhere; other parts were foreshadowed so much that I figured them out way before our main character did.  I have never hated fictional characters as much as I hated the people within this book's pages.  When Bella gets pregnant (which didn't surprise me all that much because it was a plot so common in bad fan-fiction, which is what this book read like), the baby grows ridiculously fast inside her and is literally killing her, draining everything out of her.  And yet Bella refuses to let anyone help her and wants nothing more in the world than the baby.  I hated this because it seemed like the author wanted to beat us over the head with this pro-life message of \\"your baby's life is more important than yours - even if you might die!\\"  Of course, Bella can't die because she can easily be saved by being turned into a vampire!  So the excitement factor there was low.  And the plot uninteresting.  Bella was so selfish too, thinking of names for the baby and planning the future out without talking about it with Edward.  And then Jacob made so many stupid moves as well!  I can't even begin to describe how frustrated I grew the more I read.    Another overall problem with this book is that the stakes were non-existent.  I expected - I WANTED - a great battle at the end.  I wanted to see conflict as Bella transformed into a vampire.  I wanted to see something that made me wonder how it would work out, how everything would end.  But nothing happened!  Everything just kind of worked out. (Some general spoilers follow this!!!)  Instead of Bella having a hard time cutting contact with her father, Charlie is okay with Bella's new state and just accepts that there are things he won't/can't know.  Bella doesn't have a difficult time controlling her thirst as a newborn, she's just that special.  And at the end, instead of a big battle, a stand of good vs. evil, or even something to show how much the characters have grown... they sort of talk it out and walk away.  The end!  What the...?      I like a happy ending as well as the next person, but I want to feel like I earned the happy ending!  I want to feel like the book took me through a whirlwind of emotions and kept me guessing until the last moment.  That's when a happy ending is a big payoff.  This was more like, Bella is perfect!  Everything works out perfectly!  Everyone lives happily ever after!  Think of it like Cinderella getting happily ever after as soon as she met the prince, without going through all the drama of the shoe in the middle.  Not much of a payoff because not much drama.  Sigh.    I wanted to like this book.  But the author made it so difficult by giving me virtually nothing to like!  Granted, there are a few amusing lines, but the book overall is so bad that it negates any parts I liked.  I don't want to reread this.  I don't want anyone else to be subjected to this mess.  I want the time I spent reading this back!      The sad thing is, I've read fan-fiction better than this.  I'm guessing you have to write bad fan-fiction to enjoy this!  I'm very disappointed that this book was so poor and wonder why no one let the author know what a mess this was before it got published.  I'm just glad I checked it out of the library and didn't waste money on the book!!

0743289692|5.0|I first learned about the author on a news program.  Her message, though forced into sound bites, was riveting.  After ordering and reading \\"Infidel\\" I sent additional copies to my liberally educated daughters.  I am only sorry that the book does not include the rest of her life, but we must wait for her to live it!  Ali's book has many messages, but it never says \\"this is the message,\\" because it is embedded in her story.  The glimpses into her childhood years look so strange to our eyes, like a look into a medieval time.  Her maltreatment, much of it at the hands of those who should have been nurturing and encouraging her, is truly tragic.  Her escape from the self-serving control of her proud father and would-be husband is both suspenseful and triumphant.  While Ali's initial acceptance by her European hosts is laudatory, their inability to perceive the threat to their own  generous and accepting culture by uncontrolled immigration of people with totally different values is troubling.  An autobiography contains inarguable truth - it is simply an account of what happened.  Ali does not attempt to boast or preach.  Her journey was made a step at a time without any clear idea of where it would lead.  She only did what was necessary to survive with her integrity and identity intact.  Coming from a culture where she was not considered a person of free will and value, she had the fortitude to risk everything to live a life of her choosing and not to compromise or give in to intolerable pressure to conform and be controlled.  May we all have such strength of character!
031606792X|1.0|I am an English teacher who began reading the Twilight saga this summer in order to find books to recommend to my students. I never expected to fall in love with Bella's story and the characters within. Stephenie Meyer created a secondary world where love to the highest degree was explored and captivated. Even though I knew Edward and the Cullens weren't real, Stephenie brought them to life so much that we all had to question \\"Maybe?\\" I have been eagerly awaiting Breaking Dawn, read it in a 24 hour period, only to find myself staring at the last page going \\"What just happened here?\\"  There are several questions that I want to ask Stephenie. The first is, \\"Knowing how much you care about your characters, why are they suddenly 2-dimensional?\\" Edward, the apple of every young girl's eye, is suddenly portrayed as a distant father who wants to sex it up with Bella and takes a backseat to the story. Bella, the insecure girl whom ALL female readers can somehow identify with, who never wanted marriage or a child, suddenly becomes Supermom who is no longer clumsy and has the superpower of being....(gasp) not a crazy newborn. Jacob, a character who had so much room to grow in this book, is now like a tamed dog given a biscuit.  The second question is \\"Why start a completely new plot instead of finishing the ones you have already started?\\" I feel that with the Volturi, the treaty with the werewolves (excuse me, shape-shifters), and Bella's transformation, that is plenty to write about. Instead, the plot seemed like miles and miles of fan fiction. At one point I wondered if Meyer had really hired someone else to write the book while she finished up The Host.   Finally, I want to look her in the eye and say, \\"I know you began writing these stories for yourself...but it's too late for that. What about us?\\" When you write something that touches people, you have to keep them in mind when you are writing about characters they too care about. My mother always said that she disciplined me because she loved me. That translates to writing...sometimes, the characters must go through pain for the greater good. We saw that in Harry Potter. I know it's not the same, but still. Wouldn't it have been a great message for Jacob to realize that there are other kinds of love than the Edward/Bella kind, and he and Leah could have really been companions for each other? Wouldn't it be great to see Bella really want to get married for the right reasons?   Right now I just want Stephenie Meyer to know that she did more than lose sales with this book. She has affected readers deeply with this lack of a satisfying ending for Breaking Dawn.

0380713802|5.0|Bryson brings his characteristic humor to his explorations of Europe.  While his observations can sometimes be a bit mean-spirited, he also pokes fun at himself, and many of his observations are quite funny, if clearly exaggerated.  Starting in the artic north of Norway, and continuing in a zigzag pattern across the continent, Bryson explores many of the most famous of Europe's cities, as well as some more obscure locals.  While he notes the changes in Sofia that occurred after his visit, his descriptions of Yugoslavia are even more dated (starting with the fact that Yugoslavia doesn't exist anymore!).  Fans of Bryson's humor won't be disappointed, but if you're looking for a guide to traveling in Europe, this probably won't be your best resource.

031606792X|3.0|I have to say that Breaking Dawn was certainly a compelling read. I definitely would have to admit that I couldn't put it down. 031606792X|5.0|*Spoilers*    Alright. Let me start by saying that I am a fan of the Twilight saga and have been a loyal follower since four months after Twilight was released.    Now, let me also say that I have not let that fact affect my judgment of Breaking Dawn, of which I had many qualms.    For the sake of being oxymoronic, I'll start with the conclusion.     Stephenie Meyer has said before that she loves happy endings and will always write them. While I too am a fan of such endings, I feel that it is only logical to have a realistic sense of loss, or perhaps struggle, before we get there.    So it was that upon hearing the newest title, \\"Breaking Dawn\\", I theorized that the said title was some kind of pretty metaphor for the fact that the morning sunshine has to break through clouds before its light can reach, and subsequently warm, the Earth.      I was wrong.    In a sense, Stephenie Meyer \\"copped out\\", giving most of her characters the happy endings they all wanted and dreamed of, even if it meant defying some of her own logic and notions to get there. 98 parts dread and just 2 parts struggle defined the simple and impractical formula of her (anti?)climax. This particular ray of sunlight encountered no clouds in its voyage to Earth (paradoxical considering the setting of the novel in the cloud-covered Forks, WA!).     Also bothersome was the addition of a vampire-human-hybrid-baby into the story. If you don't know who the baby's parents are, I won't spoil, though you must be living under a rock if you're reading this review and yet are still unaware.    With the baby came many questions as to why Stephenie would blatantly defy the rules which SHE defined in favor of a story arc reminiscent of fanfiction. While I can't answer that, or try and reason why THAT was the direction in which Stephenie choose to direct her story, I can say this: any qualms *I* personally had with this issue were resolved easily with the 754-page mammoth (I guess the saying is true that time healsall wounds!). By the time I got to Book 3 (Stephenie had the novel partitioned into three \\"books\\"), my earlier resentment was all but vanished.    Which was beneficial, as if the book had been any shorter, my temper would've stopped me from continuing!    Jacob Black, a character I have always, if not liked, sympathized for, got a chance to tell his story in the second 'book' of Breaking Dawn, and in the process, my appreciation increased ten fold. However, all positive feelings for him were completely and utterly eradicated in book three, when an imprinting-gone-awry gave Jacob a completely false sense of entitlement to the aforementioned vamp-baby. He was so irritating as to argue against the baby's rightful mother holding her, and later to endow the poor child with a nickname 'Nessie', shared only by the widely known Loch Ness Monster. I am strongly against animal abuse, but in this case, I was willing to make an exception.    Another factor in 'Breaking Dawn' that threw me for a loop was the presence of sex. Bella and Edward kissed less than a dozen times in Twilight. Their lack of ability to let loose physically has always added a tense-yet-enjoyable aspect to their relationship, one I always wished against but enjoyed anyway. Meyer threw this aspect out the window in Breaking Dawn, making Bella a complete nymphomaniac (Bella actually wakes up in sobs after she is roused from a dream of her doing the deed with Edward!). Sex is good when those participating are married. However, when one wishes to retain their mortality for the sole reason that they can CONTINUE having sex, it gets ridiculous and uncomfortable.    Issues regarding Bella's unavoidable change to an immortal and how she will subsequently deal with her parents are handled in an offhand, unusual way. Events which I expected to take the forefront, like her wedding, are put on the back burner in favor of more seemingly unimportant things, i.e. the honeymoon. I almost expected this, however, when I read the first chapter and already issues that I thought would be major plot points in the story, like how her parents would handle her acceptance to Edward's proposal, were solved completely. It still threw me into a whirlwind of emotions, though.    The Volturi, of course, is brought into the story (albeit several hundred pages in). The method through which they are introduced and eventually dispersed is completely unexpected and anticlimactic. Though this is a staple of a Stephenie Meyer novel, I *was* expecting something a bit different for the conclusion that was billed as \\"breathtaking\\".     It certainly took my breath away, though I am not sure if its method was positive or a negative.    And though my rant has so far seemed negative, I give the book *tentatively* four stars. Oddly, I had a hard time deciding on whether or not to give it five.     Because, in retrospection, the book was smashing. It was epic in the most unexpected of ways, and though I had so many problems and complaints and confusions and surprises whilst reading, when I finally read the very last page, I was, simply, a whirlwind of emotions. A day later and I am still not quite sure how I feel.     When I finished New Moon years back, I was mad. Upon a recent reread in preparation of the finale, I realized just how much I loved it. A similar situation happened with Eclipse. Twilight was a book I loved automatically.    Yet neither of the sequels left me in the haze Breaking Dawn has. Unlike with Harry Potter 7, I don't feel angrily and disappointedly robbed with the ending of a favorite series (which says a lot, as I hold the Twilight Saga a fair amount higher in regards!). Sure, I feel sad and depressed that it is over, but I can honestly say that we've all been given our fair go.    I love Bella and the Cullens, and all of the others in the Twilight universe, and I think Breaking Dawn put them through the last loop of their literary journey. I am content and utterly joyous to know that theyall can now get and retain their happily ever afters.     People may say otherwise, but I am utterly certain in my conviction that Stephenie Meyer has given us all of the closure we could ever require from our favorite bookshelf pals.    Maybe Breaking Dawn itself was the cloud in the sky. I am pleased to say that the sunlight has battled itself through flawlessly.    And what do you know? I started this review by giving the book four stars.    I have thoroughly convinced myself now that it is worthy of five.    In conclusion, and in summation of all of the wonderful, confusing, content, and downright joyous feelings this *breathtaking* series has given me, I only have one thing left to say to Stephenie Meyer. One thing which I think *ALL* readers of this series should say.    Thank you, Stephenie Meyer.
031606792X|1.0|I am quite surprised at how many people actually liked this book.  I have been a huge fan ever since the twilight series came out in 2005.  I have followed the series very closely and have been to a couple of Meyer's book signings etc.  I have been a VERY big fan.  Once I read Eclipse last year I have been excited beyond all reason to see how everything would unfold in the last book, but then I read Breaking Dawn... and I did not know what to feel at first.  But then I began reading reviews and I began leaning more toward the people that rated it with one star rather than with five stars.    In Eclipse it is evident that Bella needs to pick either to be with Edward or Jacob and we all knew that she loved Edward unconditionally, but loved Jacob in another.  In Breaking Dawn somehow she got everything.  That's just not fair!  Every great series something compltely tragic happens, but NOTHING happened to Bella.  She got everything!!!  Why did couldn't she lose SOMETHING!?!!? And ultimately the story line because lost within the mess that Stephenie Meyer wrote in Breaking Dawn.  The book was so different compared to the other three and it was just an utter disappointment.      I'm sorry Stephenie Meyer you are still amazing on your own level that you became extremely famous within just a matter of three short years, but I feel that you may have lost your touch at making a fantasy stay alive

031606792X|2.0|This review contains spoilers. I'm very sorry to give this book such a low rating, because I enjoyed the previous three books, and loved The Host even more. Having greatly anticipated, then inhaled this 750-page book as quickly as I could, I was highly disappointed in the ending.    There were many things that I liked about the book, especially how the Edward/Jacob issue was resolved, but I had really hoped that something in the DNA would have happened between the wolves and the vampires to completely eradicate both traits and make everyone human. (Maybe this will happen in a future book if the Jacob-Renesmee DNA combines?) There's no happily ever after if you've defeated the volturi but you know they're angry and will eventually come after you again (and they know where you live). During the weeks they were preparing, their friends hunted many times, although they respected the Covens' wishes to stay outside of a 300-mile radius of the area so none of Bella's human friends and family would be murdered. While Bella says that thinking about this made her \\"uncomfortable\\" she was still willing to sacrifice many innocent human lives to save the life of HER daughter and HER immediate family. Any good mother I know would not willingly allow this.    It also really bugged me that even after she became a mother she said several times that if Edward died she would have to die also. Again, incredibly selfish to leave your child.    There were many creative and innovative aspects to this story but these moral issues really grated on me. I could see there could be room for another book in terms of the werewolf/human/vampire DNA issues but basically I can't see any moral value in being or associating with a human-killing vampire--if I were one (and we KNOW that it's possible for a vampire to be killed) and I knew I was a danger to humans, I would arrange for myself to be killed rather than harm anyone else.

031606792X|5.0|I honestly don' understand all of this negative feedback for this book. I really enjoyed it...actually, I liked it much better than I liked any of the previous books. True, it was a bit easy to figure out from the begining, the main plot points. The journey through them, however, was fascinating to me.    True, some people say that this book was a \\"cop out\\", that Meyer just convienitly made everything work out in the end. SO WHAT? Life isn't like that most of the time, we all know that. Life rarely works out so perfefctly that we get everything that we have always wanted. But...THIS IS FICTION. This is NOT reality. She wasn't writing a birography about the life and times of Miss Bella Swan. She was writing a FAKE story about FAKE characters, is it so awful that she wants everything to turn out right? That all of these characters we have all grown to know and love, get to have their happy ending. Life isn't perfect...why must she shove this fact into the faces of the millions of teenaged girls who read this book? Why must she force them to have a doom and gloom outlook on life? That would be pointless. The point of a FICTIONAL NOVEL is escapist. You read a book to take a journey that you couldn't take in real life.     The only thing that I was really disappointed about is the way that Meyer tends to cop out when it comes to the action scenes. Sure she can describe a grusome \\"birth\\" to perfection...but a single fight scene? Not generally her thing. The actual action tends to take place \\"off camera\\" or is resolved with some heavy dialouge. I wish that she would take more time in describing a battle of some sort.    I also don't understand how its such a far leap to some people that Bella didn't want kids and then decided, when she found out she was pregnant, that she wanted to have the baby. I can't see how you could react any other way in her position. She is pregnant (no matter how unlikely), by her husband, the man that she loves more than anything on this earth. Sure, she has some growing up to do, but as I have witnessed with friends who had children young, you grow up pretty fast when a child is involved. Most of the time anyway, there are of course the exceptions to that.    Anyway, I found the book highly entertaining. Sure it sends a few messages that aren't the greatest, but what Twilight book doesn't? Does nobody remember Edward blatanly STALKING Bella in the first book, and her being ok with that. What was that? I didn't let it deter me from enjoying the rest of the book/series.

But now I want to find those people and ask them if they've ever read any of either woman's work. Rowling isn't perfect. But where she succeeds as one of the preeminent writers of children's fiction is that she was willing to do what was right for her story, whether it difficult or not. She had battles because they were NECESSARY. She killed off characters because that's what happens when battles occur. She took the risks and it paid off. Meyer didn't even give her characters a chance to prove themselves. Harry and friends fought for their lives at the age of 11. Bella and her companions couldn't do that when most of them were a century old?    Pathetic.

B000GG4XJM|5.0|Springsteen mines the roots of his own music and produces quite a gem.      You knew that Springsteen must have looked up to guys like Pete Seeger, just based on the strong populist message that flows through everything he has written.   This album serves as the definitive missing link between Springsteen's inspiration and everything he has produced.       If 'Bruce!' fans are disappointed here, it's cause they aren't looking past the surface.  This is a vanity project, but it's much more similar to Springsteen's own music than it first appears.    This is also a valid history lesson.  The songs on this CD pretty much all originate as spirituals (slave music) or at least have origins that date back to the 19th Century.      Lucky for us, this history lesson comes in an aurally beautiful package.  The music is great.   It's approachable, but the only thing lost from the 60+ year old performances is all the crackle and fuzz in the background.   There is nothing like listening to this classic American music and being able to crank it up.....actually enjoy it like any other modern music.    Usually these 'extra track' CD's don't offer much, but this is not the case here.  'How Can a Poor Man...' alone makes the few extra bucks worth it, and none of the extra's are throw away.   They really kind of shafted the people who bought this CD early.

031606792X|5.0|I found this to be the most exciting, humorous and romantic book of the series.      Some books I've read have been so intense that I've had to skip ahead to see what happens just so I can relax and enjoy the book (i.e. in Harry Potter 7 I couldn't focus on the story until I knew if he lived or died, so I cheated).  Breaking Dawn was one of those books.  I had to peek at the ending because my heart was racing so much - there was so much action/suspense through different parts of the book!  Never a dull moment.      Stephenie Meyer said in an interview somewhere that a lot more of her humor would be in this book since her editor finally gets her sense of humor, and I saw that a lot.  So many funny interactions between the characters: Bella & Emmett, Rosalie & Jacob, Jacob & Charlie, Bella & Edward, Jacob & Alice, Bella & Jasper.  Jacob's chapter titles...hilarious.  A lot of sarcasm.  Lots of humor!  In several of the negative reviews I've read one of the complaints is that the person couldn't hear Stephenie in the book at all, like it was someone else who wrote it.  I completely disagree - the humor in this book brought her out even more I thought.      As for the romance, there were plenty of Bella/Edward scenes in this book that equal or surpass scenes from her other books.  The wedding was beautiful, their wedding night was tender yet passionate, and everything builds from there.  Several things happen in the book that give you a better idea of how deep their love goes and what they are willing to do for each other.      I admit, as a book cheater, I looked for a few spoilers Saturday morning before I bought the book.  The things I read made me a little sad and perplexed - some of the excitement of buying the book was diminished.  HOWEVER...there is a huge difference between reading some random and non-detailed spoiler and hearing it presented by Stephenie herself.  I bought the book later that day and could not put it down.  Everything was perfectly plausible tome (as far as fiction goes!) and she did not disappoint!

First of all let me just say that I still believe that Stephenie Meyer is a gifted story teller. Unfortunately Breaking Dawn didn't hold the same magic as its predecessors. Yes there were some disturbing scenes but that didn't bother me as much as the portrayal of the characters. To me the Twilight Series has always been more character than plot driven anyway and when the writer betrays her characters in the way that she did at some points in Breaking Dawn they lose their breath and the story dies. Still,her story telling talents shone through as true as ever because I enjoyed the book just as much as i was saddened by it.    I am not a published writer and I could not have written Breaking Dawn any  better than what it was but I do believe that Stephenie Meyer could have.

B000ZOXDFA|3.0|But boy what a shame. The splendid (no, unbelievable) costumes and glorious scenery do indeed disguise a limp story, with stale dialogue that sounds like Oprah. Clive Owen, while indeed handsome and dashing (though somehow without an Errol Flynn gleam in his eye) drops his innumerable bad lines as if they are hot bricks. Compare Elizabeth's way too Henryesque battle speech with Will's to see how flaccid this is. Not even poetry with a lower case p.<br /><br />Too many stories going on simultaneously, each of them plenty sufficient to drive the plot, means that the whole thing becomes a confused and wild mess. But the shame comes in the lost opportunities. The execution of Mary, one of the most bizarre and terrifying events in English history, is really untouched. (Maybe they wanted to keep the Elizabeth as guilty and torn and the Elizabeth unsullied by this.) But for a graphic and visually compelling film such as this, the site of her head dropping from the exectioner's hand would have been rather startling.<br /><br />And the love stuff, while maybe historically accurate (Raleigh did enjoy the queen's favor to a remarkable degree) just sunk this tale. We know she doesn't get the man, we also know she doesn't seem to want to. Showing her as an emotional and flighty female, while more in line with current sensibilities, just doesn't seem authentic. She was queen for a long time, and ruled with a resolve this script misses.<br /><br />Worth a watch. But not one for the ages. Nope--unlike Elizabeth, this is soon to be forgotten.

055358894X|4.0|Locke Lamora is orphaned at the age of 5 where he is taken up by a Thiefmaker. Thieving in the city of Camorr is a regulated activity under the auspices of the brutal Capa (read:Godfather) Barsavi. Thieves can steal from commoners but can't steal from nobility, a practice known as The Secret Peace. At the tender age of 5, Locke is a gifted thief, actor and inveterate schemer. He also manages to break the secret peace much to the dismay of the thiefmaker. He is sold to a blind priest named Chains (who is neither blind nor a priest). Chains is the leader of a small gang known as The Gentlemen Bastards.    Under Chains, Locke learns a lot more than simple petty thievery. He undergoes a whole new type of training that allows his own personal skills to flourish. Over time Locke becomes the leader of the Gentlemen Bastards and creates elaborate long cons that bilk the nobility of thousands and makes the Gentlemen Bastards very rich. This breaking of the secret peace remains very covert. The nobility who are bilked do not report their losses for fear of looking stupid. And Locke has created just as elaborate of a cover for the Gentlemen Bastards. In the thieving community, they are considered unimportant, low level break in artists who are unworthy of real notice of the Capa.    But a new player named The Grey King has entered the game and is killing off high level thieves in Barsavi's organization. Although he is counseled to get out of town until The Grey King is caught, Locke refuses. First he believes his cover as an low level thief will be beneath the Grey King's notice and second he is in the middle of one the biggest and best cons of his career. Sadly, Locke is mistaken. He is most definitely on the Grey King's list and things that have been going so very, very right start to go impossibly wrong....    I did not know what to expect when I picked up this book. I got it because someone in one of my reading groups rattled it off as a recommendation and others secondedit enthusiastically. I LOVED it the minute I started reading it. I was quickly immersed in the setting (feels like Renaissance Italy) and the words and voice of Scott Lynch. The writing is exquisite and the tone takes just takes one captive.    The architecture of the story is well done. It starts out when Locke is five years old, introduces you to this engaging little scamp through a comically woeful retelling of his exploits by the Thiefmaker who is trying to sell him to Chains. Then the story leaps forward to \\"present\\" time where Locke is the leader of the Bastards and he and his band are right at the beginning of their latest caper. Every few chapters or so, we go back and revisit young Locke and watch him progress in what can only be considered a finishing school of thievery where he and the other Bastards learn other languages, accent, make-up, mummery, cooking, society manner etc. I know some people dislike this structure but it served to keep the story interesting on two fronts,imo, moreso than a simple linear narrative would have done. And it allows some suspense and character development in what is otherwise a strongly plot-driven narrative.    And at the start, you feel like you are along for the ride on a rollicking, effervescent adventure. The Gentlemen Bastards are fun and funny. They engage in quick and witty repartee. You can't help but be reminded of George Clooney/Brad Pitt in Oceans 11, complete with the dry raillery and practice scenarios. Or while reading about the fabulously twisty con being pulled on the Count and his wife, I couldn't help but be reminded of the complex theatre that played out each week on Mission Impossible. Or during the scenes with Capa Barsavi of picturing Marlon Brando's Don Corleone from the Godfather. This book is like all of these things and none really. Lynch has built a complete world and describes the city of Camorr and the various populations and parts very well. Again, his language and ability to draw in the reader is brilliant.    So if I loved it so much why did it take me forever to read it (I started this book like a frigging Month ago!)? I honestly don't know. This books is not a deep or thought provoking book, it is high fun for the most part. And I can usually bang out a book I like in about three days or less. But this one took me a while. I do ascribe a bit of my malaise to the fact that the bite and wit of the story falters with the advent of the Grey King. Strangely enough I was enjoying a fantasy book that did not include magic and sorcery. But it was introduced with the Grey King along with what I felt was some clunky motivation, some plot points that made me truly regretful and sad, and an ending that was a bit bittersweet. Not enough to make me dislike the novel by a long shot, but enough to slow down the momentum a bit.    No matter, really. Just smallish quibbles in what is otherwise a very well written, nicely plotted, purely enjoyable book. And I am looking forward to reading the next installment.
031606792X|5.0|Look everyone. I have seen plenty of reviews on this book, the good and the bad. I am seeing some recurring complaints though- the writing is bad, the ending was too cheesy, some characters were barely mentioned- but you need to think a little before you go ranting away about wanting your money back. First of all, this is her FIRST SERIES. She had never written before and had no direct writing education. Lets see you right a book on a whim and watch it soar to number one on the NY bestseller list (obviously, that takes something). Remember as well that Meyer wrote this book, as I said, on a whim. The idea came from a dream (that dream being the scene in the meadow where Bella first sees Edward in the sun), and she wrote these books just to figure out what would happen. Thats right, everyone. You are critizicing a women who wrote hundreds of pages just for that reason, not to be a star writer (hint: why the high expectations?). I'm not too sure about what you would think,but I think you are one depressing person if you decide that you want anything but perfection for the characters in the dream that you wanted so much to be happy that you wrote FOUR BOOKS for that to happen.Personally, the events of this book were the first in a long time that made me happy. I am sick of authors feeling like they need to kill off some character you loved, or have the ending be unhappy, or adding so many twists that there is no way all the loose ends could be tied up. The way Meyer ended her series seemed rushed, but at the same time it was skillful. Everyone is happy, Bella didn't have \\"newborn\\" issues, etc. etc.-- sure it seems Mary Sueish, but so many people would have hated to see Bella, Edward, Jacob, etc. struggle. Yet, though there was a happy ending, it left plenty to think about. What would happen in the future with the volturi? What would Bella and Edward do with their eternal life? Will vampire society change because of the discovery of the hybrids? What happens to Bella's family? See? You are satisfied knowing in general that all is well, but Meyer leaves you to imagine the rest of Bella's world.      Some characters were not mentioned a whole lot because the story was so intensely around other characters, and they weren't important. Sure, Esme is a Cullen, buy Meyer knew that she didn't have to have every vampire in every conversation and scene. I didn't care about Esme too much anyway- she wasn't too central to the story. Another complaint I have to shoot down-- the stuff about Edward being able to have a baby? And contradictions in \\"vampire facts?\\" Come on, people. Once again, have some imagination and think out an explanation yourself. It is a fantasy, not a scientific textbook. Unless you think vampires are real... but if you did that might explain some of your negative outlooks on this book. Meyer mentions that vampires have no bodily fluids (through one of the vampire's dialogue), but she also shows how little the vampires know about themselves. They dont know exactly how the transformation works,they didnt know about hybrids, they dont understand abilities fully, why a mix between a 23 chromosome and a 25 chromosome didnt make a 24 chromosome shapeshifter (aka the Quilete \\"werewolves\\")... so many things. Meyer made an decision that an explanation was not necessary.      The book had some symbolism that made it have to end Mary Sueish. Meyer is LDS, as many know, and the Mormon religion believes in a plan of salvation where a married couple can exist in bliss forever. It wouldn't really fit Meyer's good outlook on life and after death if the characters in the book DIDNT live in peace together forever, and get a child out of their love.      Overall, the book is a good read. Definitely has some skillful, unexpected twists (what was that some of you cynics said about predictable storylines?). The writing is great, especially at Meyers low experience level. The characters changed only because the settings changed. The cheesiness made me happy, instead of making me want to kill myself because it was a tragic/stupid/unclear/ ending (ahem* Series of Unfortunate Events). Meyer has a unique writing style, it's fun to read and predict,she has ended the series at a good time without going crazy into detail but still giving enough, and if you have read the other books you need to know what happens anyway! I RECOMMEND HIGHLY

She lucked out ---that's the irony!!!!  A girl with no luck in life finally finds both luck and love and a true life in her transformation but she still had to die in the end to get there....

031606792X|4.0|When I read the objections several one-star reviews gave \\"Breaking Dawn\\" I wanted to yell, \\"It's FICTION/FANTASY, enjoy it.\\" One thing I figured out years ago, and taught my children, is that you don't look to fictional characters for role models! I don't care how nobel they are - they're FICTION. You want role models, look at real people and real life.    Another objection was that the book wasn't for young teens. I have felt that ever since reading \\"Twilight\\". I knew then, that only older teens who have a good grasp on reality should read the series. You have to have the ability to separate fiction from reality. Some teens may not be ready for that and be disappointed that real-life romances aren't like Edward. He's Fiction. You need to read for the fun of it.    Some were upset that Bella gets a fairy tale ending and everything she wants. I say, more power to her. I'm almost 50 and still hope there will be a happily-ever-after for me, but I love my life now and hope, and work for the best.    Some complained there wasn't sacrifice in this book. When I see a mother willing to give her life for a child - born/or unborn - what greater sacrifice is there. Other values I found in the book were: joy and desire in a marriage, love and strength of family ties, and the blessing of friendship. I was glad to see them, but I don't determine my values from fiction either. Artemis Fowl is a series many young teens read and that is about a young criminal mastermind. No role model there but a delightful read.    This book is fiction and an enjoyable read. When it comes to role models, I will look to my parents' 55 year marriage, my dad's love and grace as my mom goes through Alzheimers, my family and friends who face trials with dignity and grace. Breaking Dawn is fiction - it is fun, intriguing, and has a fairy tale ending - YEA!
