0743277708|2.0|This strikes me as definitiely a \\"book of its time\\". First published in 1972 (after being rejected by 13, count 'em, 13 publishers), it is written on a \\"young adult\\" reader level and is basically a formalized cobbling together of stories the author told his children on tedious car trips. Each chapter is preceded by a literary quote, which after the first 20 or so becomes a bit precious and eventually pretentious. Obviously, it has quite a following, but it seems to me to fall into the same category as books as diverse as \\"A Wrinkle in Time\\", \\"Stranger in a Strange Land\\", \\"Atlas Shrugged\\", or perhaps less complimentary, \\"Jonathan Livingston Seagull\\" (which itself was published 2 years before this). All have their fans, most of whom first read their book at an impressionable age, and who seem more passionate than the material objectively deserves, because the story has some resonance for those readers. Those fans all find some sort of inspiration, or really self-confirmation, and tend to get irate if YOU don't \\"get it\\" too. Frankly, it struck me as an overly-twee cross between \\"The Hobbit\\" and Beatrix Potter. (And please, I *did* enjoy \\"The Wind in the Willows\\".) The female rabbits (\\"does\\") are essentially non-existant in the first third of the book, and are much-sought-after non-entities in the rest, useful only for perpetuating rabbithood (didn't know THAT was a problem....) The \\"lupine dictionary\\" ought to be a litmus test for potential readers: if this strikes you as charming, or clever, or creative, give the book a try. If you think that is just a mite affectatious, and have a hard time with rabbits having \\"names\\" like Hazel, Buckthorn, Pipkin, and Dandelion, I think you'll be happier with a \\"pass\\".

0345495004|4.0|Loving Frank is an unsentimental and nuanced fictionalization of the real-life extramarital affair between well-known architect Frank Lloyd Wright and Mamah Borthwick Cheney. Horan confronts the moral issues implicated by the affair head-on and with intelligence and objectivity. Mamah and Frank are rich, three-dimensional characters surrounded by many other fully developed characters. Informative descriptions of Wright's architecture and discussions of contemporary feminist ideology are nicely interwoven into the personal narrative. These nonfiction elements support and enrich the narrative without overpowering the primary storyline. The novel concludes shortly after a shocking event. Had this event not actually occurred in real life, it would have been an unsatisfactory ending--a disappointing deux ex machina. Recommended, especially for those readers interested in architecture or feminist theory.

0375758992|4.0|In Don't Let's Go to the Dogs Tonight, Alexandra Fuller describes her childhood in Africa. Fuller's story, told in graceful prose, is brutal and touching and never overly sentimental. I enjoyed many of the stories Fuller includes in this memoir, but I found certain aspects tedious. Fuller's family moves through many different living situations in numerous countries and confronts various unstable political regimes. After awhile, these places and politics run together and became repetitive. The tedium borne of this repetition somewhat lessens the overall power of this memoir, but Don't Let's Go to the Dogs Tonight remains a worthwhile read.

0385340990|3.0|The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society is a lighthearted epistolary novel about an author who travels to Guernsey, a British island in the English Channel off the coast of Normandy. The protagonist, Juliet Ashton, is a writer with a warm personality and an adventurous spirit. As Juliet researches her next book about the German occupation of Guernsey during WWII, she befriends the quirky members of a book group on the island. Although The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society is charming at times, this book is mostly lacking in substance. The characters are formulaic, and the plot is entirely predictable. A quick and forgettable read.

0143038419|3.0|For the same reason I read The Da Vinci Code (namely, peer pressure), I finally read Eat, Pray, Love, Elizabeth Gilbert's bestselling memoir about her culinary and spiritual journey following a messy divorce. I have no major complaints about this book, but I also have nothing particularly positive to say. It's exactly what you'd expect: typical and predictable but also easy to read and somewhat entertaining. As Gilbert traipses across Italy, India, and Indonesia, her lighthearted tone keeps her story from wallowing in seriousness, but it also introduces a veneer of superficiality. If you like these kinds of books (thirty-something woman rediscovers the joys of life), you'll probably enjoy Eat, Pray, Love. Personally, I'd rather spend my time reading something more unique.

B00000016Z|5.0|A very under-rated, intense swampy-bluesy, album which I appreciate now even more than when it was first released. An intense, brooding, swampy - occasionally even slinky - masterpiece with scowling vocals that John Fogerty does better than any other man alive.  Play it loud and get into the mood of the song.  Magnificent.  One of the greatest songs of the era.<br /><br />Bootleg is an excellent, catchy tune which also is typically swampy while being laid back and ultra cool. Very under-rated; few people have heard it but when they do for the first time it is an instant success.  I'm surprised they didn't promote that song better.  Is noteworthy that JF still does it in his concerts - he knows the good lesser known ones! Keep on Chooglin' (a term Fogerty says he made up himself) is also a great addition to the album.<br /><br />Penthouse Pauper reveals some fine Fogerty blues guitar and is an interesting mood change.  Speaking of guitar, Fogerty does some neat work on Good Golly Miss Molly, which rolls along at pace compared to the slow, harp orientated, blues number Graveyard Train, which adds some darkness and tension to an excellent and varied album.  I've bought a DCC version because the fine collection deserves to be heard at its best.  A must have.
B00005JNJV|5.0|This movie is not the batman seen on the old TV series.  I think the old movies attempted to darken that old theme and came up with something in between.  I did enjoy the old movies with that quasi-dark drama/action and plenty of tounge-in-cheek moments.  Well, the first couple anyway.  The new movie though just fits the character so much better.  We knew his motivations for being Batman, but now finally Bruce Wayne acts like the product of his childhood.      Without discussing plot, this movie is superior to all other Batman films.  Those who say it is slow maybe just want to watch 90 minutes of explosions and car chases.  I think this movie has the right amount of action mixed in with pretty deep character development.  It isn't just Bruce Wayne, all the characters are important.  That is a rarity for movies now.  I was reading an interview by the director about shooting of the sequel and he talked about not using a second team for \\"unimportant shots\\".  He replied that if a shot/scene is truly unimportant, than it should not be in the movie.  He's right, watching the movie again just recently, there wasn't a single time where I tuned out due to a scene I didn't like.    The acting was top notch across the board.  The script was good as well.  The League of Shadows was a bit over the top and cliche at times, but it needs to stay true to Batman now.    Blu-ray looks great.  I did not notice any grainy shots.  It isn't the bright vivid HD experience you may see in other movies, but pausing the disk as looking at the detail on the bricks in the background or the swirling smoke really gives you a sense of the picture.  When I first put 300 into my HD-DVD player I was dissapointed that they kept it so blurry for the HD transfer.  In this film they were able to give detail and sharp edges without loosing that dark feeling.  Very good video transfer.    The sound is good.  I've heard better sound effects in action movies, but I didn't end the film thinking that the soundwas lacking here either.  The explosions were not overpowering and it was mixed well so you weren't struggling to hear the quiet dialog one scene then trying to keep your glass from shaking off of the table the next. Too often in action movies today the explosions are too loud for those quiet scenes and you have to artificially crank that center channel to make it watchable in a home environment.  The music was well done and added to the movie without it taking center stage.    Overall, this is a movie where you can watch it realize that it is complete.  No \\"director's cut\\" is needed.  There are no extra shots.  Everything just fits well together.   From a movie lover's standpoint, this movie should be appreciated for that even if you don't like the plot or premise.

031606792X|2.0|When I purchased Breaking Dawn (at Midnight with a horde of fellow fans), I expected a continuation to the excellent series that SM began with Twilight. Instead, I found that Breaking Dawn was more of a separate story; an entirely different novel with an entirely different style of writing and an incongruent plot. While the book does follow the same characters that we have grown to love (or hate, with reason), the story that we have been eagerly awaiting a conclusion to has disappeared. The characters act in uncharacteristic ways, the plot has major and pointless tangents, and the perspective of the book changes from Bella to Jacob for nearly half of the story. (I admire Jacob, to be sure, but how long can I be expected to read about his not-so-intricate \\"pack\\" dynamics and his love/frustrations with Bella? Sure, it was interesting to see what he was thinking, but it was over-done.)          The conflicts within and between characters are limited, and in the end, everyone seems to get exactly what it is that they most want. A fairy tale ending is satisfying in some cases, but this is simply not how the rest of the series is set up. We are conditioned to beleive that there will be hard choices and sacrifices. We expect that Bella cannot please both Edward and Jacob, and that someone will get hurt. There are multiple sacfrifices that Bella has made in her decision to become a vampire (having children is one of those) that makes her devotion to Edward that much more powerful. I, at least, expected that some things would not turn out perfectly, and that's what gives the plot a greater impact. Bella's love for Edward is more intense if we can believe that she would give up her desires to be with him. The fact that everything turn out peachy-keen makes the plot flimsy. A fairy-tale ending is sweet, but must EVERYTHING be so perfect? People compare SM to J.K. Rowling, which is undeserved in my opinion. At least J.K. Rowling had the courage to dissapoint some of her fans in order to deliver the necessary story that she envisioned. I beleive SM was just afraid of displeasing any of her fans by not offering whatever it was that she thought they wanted.  Though it may not sound like it, I did enjoy the book, to a point, but moslty this is because I no longer feel the need to end the series. In fact, I think it did an excellent job of satiating any desire I had for the continuation of the series. SM did a suburb job of pointing out all of the flaws of here characters to the extent of them becoming less likable. Bella is immature, impractical, and too grey-toned to be a heroine; Edward transformed from a breathtaking admirer to a fretting goose; Jacob lost almost all of his sincerity as a character; and the Cullens suddenly lost their flawless composure.         To sum it up, I can't honestly imagine what SM was thinking when she was writing some of those obtruse plot twists, other than to please everyone. If you are expecting an epic tale in continuation of the series, look perhaps to fanfiction. If you would rather dismiss all plot that may turn out badly and make anyone unhappy, well then, read on.

031606792X|4.0|*This includes spoilers throughout!*    I feel compelled to respond to the first review of Breaking Dawn, which is a negative one.  I feel that the author's intentions are not to suggest that at 18 people should simply have babies, get married, and forget about themselves entirely.  Suggestions such as these ignore completely any underlying themes to the novel and focus on the simple, literal events which occur in the novel.  However, to humor the reviewer, let's focus on the literal, apparently most irritating event:  not going to college.  I am sad that I must point out the obvious here:  Bella is now a vampire.  She will live forever.  One would assume that would be enough time to go to every college in the world fifty times over, possibly more than that.      Also, another point was Bella's acceptance of her pregnancy.  It is true that earlier in the novel, she does not want to have children.  This is not hard to understand because, at the time, she believes that in order to have Edward she could not have children.  Because she loves Edward so much, she chooses him over children.  When she finds she is pregnant, she realizes for the first time, that having Edward's child is not impossible.  The point here, is that it is possible that should would have wanted a baby with Edward before had she known it could happen.  When it does, she accepts it.  That does not seem so impossible.  Also, her pregnancy is entirely consistent with Meyer's mythical world.  In the previous books, none of the vampires thought it possible.  It is such a rare occurrence that they believed it would never happen.  Of course a female vampire could not carry a baby, but it is not far fetched to go along with the idea that a human female could have one.  The vampire venom repairs the body to a perfect state.  Anything \\"abnormal\\" would be less than perfect.  Pregnancy would be a less than perfect state for the body.  The baby's \\"host\\" would have to use its stores to support the baby, hence itis imperfect.  The vampire venom would \\"repair\\" this, much like it repaired Bella's broken back.  A male, however, would not have this problem.  The sperm could still exist in liquid form and would not harden like the skin of the body because the venom itself is in liquid form.  Hence, it is not a far leap to conclude that that would still exist.  Sperm in a male is constantly there, but eggs in a female's ovaries are not.  If a vampire is frozen into a perfect state unchanging, there is no way a female vampire could become pregnant.  I do not see why some would find this so far fetched.  Plus, the idea of a mythical beast  impregnating a human female is a myth that can be traced throughout time, and I think that Meyer was clever in introducing another known superstition into her novels and then shaping it into her story.    Also, I think it is wonderful that Bella finally does not have to sacrifice too much in this particular story.  To me, it is more important that throughout the novel, she is more than willing to sacrifice everything.  The fact that she's willing to do so for others makes her who she is:  the shield. This power fits in well with her personality throughout all of the novels, and it's nice that she can be prepared to sacrifice it all, including her very \\"life,\\" without having to do so in the end.  Her willingness is what matters.  It takes a highly cynical view on life to suggest that not having to actually sacrifice anything could never happen.  Besides, just because she ends up with Edward, Renesme, Jacob happy, and her dad in her life doesn't mean complications could never arise to where she would need to sacrifice something eventually.  After all, she gains those things toward the middle of the book and complications arise that threaten to destroy the happiness of all.    Overall, I just had to put in a few arguments of my own.  The novel, I thought, was a good one.  I wasn't expecting it to go in the direction it went, but I was pleasantly surprised.  It was a bit obvious, though, that the Volturi would arrive, but that was a small set-back for me.  I still love all the books and I feel that Stephenie Meyer did a wonderful job of ending the saga.  Plus, the ending leaves enough open that if she ever feels like returning to Edward and Bella, more stories could follow.
B00007KWHG|5.0|This is a real score for both fans of Franki Valli and for Rhino records. This best of gathers songs from all phases of the band's career and Valli's solo albums, from various labels and multiple decades. From those first memorable singles \\"Sherry\\" and \\"Big Girls Don't Cry\\" on Vee-Jay (a label that was an early US host of The Beatles) to Valli scoring a number one with the [[ASIN:B000001FDK Grease Soundtrack]] theme song, you can follow pop styles and trends through Valli's falsetto.<br /><br />While those coming to this CD via the success of the [[ASIN:B000BFH2QY Jersey Boys Broadway show]] will be taken aback by the primitive sound of the early records, the production was still very pristine for the times. The horse-clops on \\"Walk Like a Man\\" or the chimes on \\"Dawn (Go Away)\\" show savvy, and the 70's comeback of \\"Who Loves You\\" or \\"Swearin' To God\\" hail the omnipotence of the disco era. Add some great liner notes, and you have the best Four Seasons comp available. Take a little stroll down the Jersey Boardwalk with Sherry, Candy, Ronnie, Dawn and Marrianne...and Franki Valli.
031606792X|5.0|I want to buy Stephenie Meyer a present.  As much as I adored Twilight, New Moon and Eclipse, I wasn't prepared for the artistry of Breaking Dawn.  Any passionate reader of fiction understands the importance of the perfect conclusion to a book or a series.  A. S. Byatt's Possession had such an ending.  So did J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.  And now, so does Stephenie Meyer.  The Twilight series was so wildly popular not just because Stephenie Meyer created a perfect romantic hero in Edward Cullen (she did) or an equally perfect alternative hero in Jacob Black (yes, again) or a uniquely strong heroine in Bella Swan (who is most assuredly not passive) a heroine who is happy with herself both before and after she meets her soulmate, but because Ms. Meyer set up an impossible situation where each outcome was painful to contemplate: the potential loss of Bella's soul versus her growing rapidly old and dying while Edward never did.  How could Bella live without Edward and he without her?  And how could she live in the manner that he was forced to live?  Every seed Stephenie Meyer planted in the first three books of this series blooms in Breaking Dawn.  Every idea comes to fruition.  And her theme, which seems to be misinterpreted by some readers more eager to publicly denigrate Ms, Meyer than they are to engage in thoughtful discourse, is not the damaging idea that a girl isn't complete without a baby and a man and a picket fence.  The idea behind all the books is love is important.  Love of one another.  Love of community.  Love of family: parent, siblings, children.  Love of friends.  And most importantly, romantic love, life partner love.  And this ideal is illustrated in Breaking Dawn, in ways I wouldn't have imagined, in ways that made me cry, in ways that made me feel the exhilaration I feel whenever I read something true, the way only fiction and poetry can be true.   The series blossomed upward and outward; from a deeply compelling connection between two unlikely lovers to a grand and life affirming story of the importance and power of love among all people.  I wish I could buy Stephenie Meyer a present because Breaking Dawn felt like a gift to me.

031606792X|3.0|I have always been a huge Twilight fan, and still am.  However Breaking Dawn was for me one of the biggest let downs.  I've never been a fan of New Moon, but the story there was, at least, realistic.  This one was not!  After the initial 'high' of finally getting my hands on the book, seeing there were three books in one, and staying up all night to read, wore off, I started really analyzing how the plot was laid out.  I came to the conclusion that the book reads like a fanfic, NOT something that came from the same author of Eclipse.  The characters where flat and empty with no real emotion.  They didn't even seem like themselves.  Bella was Bella until after the wedding.  Then her personality was gone, as were everyone else's.  I couldn't understand all the changes in her writing.  To be perfectly honest, I've never considered Stephenie Meyer, and amazing author with an exceptional plot.  She just creates fun, relatable characters that are fun to read about.  I, as much as anyone, love sitting down with one of the books and getting lost in the world that she's created.  I couldn't do that with this book.  I couldn't see myself at the wedding, or on the island, or with Bella and her baby.  Stephenie Meyer has in my opinion always relied on descriptive details to help her books along.  Once Bella was pregnant there were no details, and that made it hard to read.  Of course I loved reading about Bella and Edward on the island, I screamed when I found out she was pregnant, and I loved reading about cute Renesmee, but I couldn't relate to any of it.  Especially her daughter.  Why should Renesmee grow unnaturally fast?  I suppose that Bella drank the blood willingly because her fetus was half vampire, but why was there not explation for that?  I understand more or less how she got pregnant, but it wasn't explained very well like so many other things.  Stephenie Meyer made a lot of assumptions that we could figure out strange, unheard of, things, with no help or clues.Another problem with the writing: The first-middle part of the book dragged on, while the middle-end, went on at the speed of light.  I got so bored reading Jacob's book.  NO emotion!  I think it would have been better written from Edward's point of view.  Then when it was back to Bella, everything started happening at once!  She had the baby and two seconds later, Edward jabs her with a needle of venom.  Very unromantic.  I understand the necessity of the timing, but it was (like so many other things), not well explained at all.  We just see him bite her - not pain on his face, no thirst, no wondering if she's alive, just bite, bite, bite.   Again, Stephenie Meyer would have put emotion with him.  And Renesmee... I loved reading about Bella's adorable half human, half vampire daughter, but again it was un-relatable.  Who has a perfect child who can show you perfectly what she wants, all the time, no crying, sleeping when you need her too, and you never get tired?!  Honestly!!  I will read it again, but I can't have an open mind again.  I will always wish it had been different - maybe that Bella stays human until the last page, and the Volturi fight because she's still human and they actually fight!!  She changes at the end, and we get to see Edward restrain her as a newborn.  What - we're supposed to believe she never drinks human blood as a newborn, has the perfect child and husband, and gets to see her human family immediately?  And what's with the rest of the Cullens?  We never see Esme; and Alice - Bella's best friend -  is gone throughout the whole book sulking about being 'blind'.  'Em' and 'Jazz'?  What's up with that?  And Carlisle didn't seem himself either.  Rosalie was the one with the most personality and importance -  that's just sad.  Also, it was a little too convieniant, that her love problems with Jacob could be fixed by her half vampire daughter.  And of course, there's the whole faux-fight scene.  It's just too happily ever after.  We're all geared up for some huge battle and then Bella and Renesmee save the day before it starts.  All in all, it seems Stephenie Meyer was writing to please the public.  Ironic, when the public seems to like it when she's writing for herself.

1931559317|5.0|The authors of this guide did almost everything right.<br /><br />It's just the right size; at 9 X 6, it's large enough to be legible and small enough to be easy to handle. The paper seems very durable, but it's not coated.  I bought a piece of clear Lucite the size of the opened book to shield it from the heavier moisture.<br /><br />If I had to choose just one sky guide for regular use, this would be the one.  I'm very happy I bought it, and I'd do it again.

0061537934|5.0|I first saw this book at Starbucks and picked it up to find out what it was all about.  A book about car racing, told from the perspective of a dog?  Now, I like car racing a lot and I like dogs a lot, but that just sounded far too hokey to me; after all, I read serious stuff, right?    Then, my mother told me she read the book and that she thought I might enjoy it.  That was the final straw.  I had to read the book just to prove to myself that it couldn't possibly be good.  (An admittedly odd reason to read a book, but given the result, one I may pursue again).    I loved it.    Garth Stein obviously knows dogs and racing.  The whole book is filled with details about both that show his understanding of his subjects on a fairly deep level.  Further, he knows something about life, and that's where this book really shines.  Stein has - in a completely non-hokey way - used car racing metaphors to illustrate truisms about life.  As a fan of racing, I particularly enjoyed the analogies, but I think the metaphors are just as accessible to non-fans.  Stein keeps the ideas simple and explains them well, there isn't any jargon that would cause non-fans to lose anything in translation.    Stein also uses the unique access of a \\"stupid dog\\" to situations his human characters don't get to witness as a great story-telling hook.  Our canine narrator, Enzo, gets to go places his master, Denny, doesn't, hearing and seeing things for the reader that move the story along quite nicely.  Again, it's an aspect of the book that could have gone over the top, but is instead used effectively by Stein and turned into a really good book.    Take it from a skeptic turned believer.  This is a book with some really good insights into life that is also a very enjoyable read.  Highly recommended.

One example is that for quite a bit of the first part of the book Bella has to drink human blood. The blood is from a blood bank, but Bella is still human.  In my opinion that is just too gross and way over the top.  There are other parts but I don't want to spoil. If you have young people who want to read this book I strongly suggest you read it first and be sure that you are ok with your kids reading this material.
031606792X|5.0|I have made it through the anticipation of Breaking Dawn without actually reading any of the reviews for it myself (I got my copy yesterday). I have, however, heard about what was being said in certain reviews. I can only give my own opinion of this book. Before I do so, I must say that I am certainly able to criticize or simply just dislike a person's work, even when I have loved all their other work.<br /><br />However, those kind of thoughts are not necessary this time. I loved Breaking Dawn from the first page until it's last. I think some people might have expected the course of the final book to be different and I know a lot of people were surprised to see the path that Stephenie Meyer took. Nothing in this book really shocked me though. The speed of it was quick, but whether it is simply how I tend to experience things or what have you, I did not think that it's speed diminished the story. We were told Bella's choice in Eclipse, and everything mentioned in the book has been explained to us or introduced to us in someway as well. As for Bella and what happens to her (I don't really want to spoil everything for anyone who hasn't read this book), it was my belief (and I assumed others and Meyer's) that we knew the extraordinary being of Bella. This was not just a book about a girl, her vampire boyfriend, her werewolf best friend and the love triangle that ensued. This series, and this book especially, is about family, connection, love and the meaning of one seemingly ordinary yet unique woman being who she truly was meant to be. With that said, I took the story for what it was and not what it was expected to be.<br /><br />I want to add that this book is mature, not just with situations, but with emotions as well.
031606792X|3.0|***SPOILERS AHEAD***    I felt a LOT was missing or explained weakily or accepted easily. Why does he accept so easily that Rosalie is helping Bella and doesn't fight back? His wife, the love of his life, the one who he would do anything for, is dying in front of him...and yet, he sits next to her and watches her fade slowly (and painfully) away. Nice.   One more thing: how about Bella freaking out because she got pregnant and doesn't understand how?  (because, hello, vampires can't have children. They're dead, remember?). It's Edward who freaks out! when he's the one who was wishing Charlie's assumptions were correct just because he wished he could have what he knew he couldn't!!. Yes, he did what Ross on Friends did when Rachel told him he was having a baby: froze. Bella, on the other hand, didn't even cry. Let's not forget she freaked out when she realized Edward was taking her to the prom on Twilight, or with her birthday party...or with so many other unimportant things. Now, she's only 18, just married and a teenager mother.     Next, how about Jacob finding a nice girl to fall in love with or imprint on? or maybe not to fall in love with but to like enough to forget about Bella and move on. I even thought that was Leah's purpose to the novel. Oh how i was mistaken!. And was chapter 18 necessary? I suddenly felt i was reading some Hitchcock's book. I was far more than shocked. I could imagine Bella lying on a metal table, blood everywhere, hearing the bones breaking (i almost puked when her spine broke)...and then it got worse: Jacob helping to deliver the baby!, giving Bella CPR and having to blow in her mouth filled with blood...and OMG EDWARD EATING THROUGH BELLA'S BELLY to have the baby out. Repulsed anyone? *raises hand*. Imagine how shocked and disgusted i was that i didn't understand what happened when Jacob saw Renesmee for the first time. I didn't pay attention to that part. I was scared of continuing reading. How more painful could it get? right?    OOOH i was mistaken again!. When Bella realized Jacob had imprinted on Renesmee, that's when i did too. And i jumped up, holding my book, and started yelling \\"WHAAAT? NO!! NO NO NO NOOO!!!\\". Sick. Wrong. At so many levels. Not only because she's just a baby, but because she's the daughter of the woman he loves with all his heart and of the man he hates so much. Ugh.    And then, Bella became a vampire and Edward escaped from the guilt. He HAD to do it, otherwise she'd be dead.  And everything was beautiful after that!: she was able to control herself from minute one, she still felt the desire for Edward, she could control the thirst and managed not to kill Jacob and Renesmee. And her father (which parent would've accepted becoming a grandfather so easily when the mother is just a teen?! Don't even get me started on accepting the supernatural stuff...). Bella even got a cottage in the woods!. The complete fairy tale. Jacob and Edward also got along (let me say here that Edward was absolutely out of character!! calling Jacob \\"son\\"???. That was pushing the limits Steph). Sam forgave Jacob from night to day and all the werevolves started protecting the vampires, Jacob accepted his imprinting on Renesmee with open arms and didn't try to fight it. Leah was forgotten in the story.    The epic battle with the Volturi never happened, no one important died. What was the purpose of so many vampires with so many different talents? Why did they all believe Alice had abandoned them? that's crazy! Don't they know her at all?? Of course she was on a secret mission!!. DUH.   The only time i didnt know what was going to happen was when Bella started saying goodbye to Renesmee...and i wished the ending was that Renesmee had to run with Jacob and the rest of them had to stay and fight and die in the process. The end.    NO.    Nothing happened. Renesmee wasn't so unique after all and they got their happy ending.    Congrats.        All in all, i enjoyed it mainly because i wanted to know how it would end and couldn't stop reading, not because the plot was so great.
0307237702|4.0|Barack Obama has changed politics. Regardless of your social, economic, or political beliefs, he has altered the way many think of a presidential candidate. In \\"The Audacity of Hope\\" Barack catalogs his rise to become the presumptive nominee of the Democrat Party. He explains each step by organizing categories such as, our constitution, faith, opportunity, politics, and family. He presents and explains his beliefs on many important issues that face modern voters. He recalls his failures, elucidates the present, and sets his future goals. \\"The Audacity of Hope\\" is all that it claims to be (do not expect a numbered game plan to solve war and global poverty). The nostalgia and love of his family members alongside politics is interesting to read of and I recommend this book to both Democrats and Republicans. It will help you become more knowledgeable of Barack's plans or prepare you to defend your own. Plus, his writing is as moving as his speeches can be!<br />Thanks for reading,<br />C.K.

0679720200|5.0|Meursault's story begins with his mother's death; \\"Maman died today.Or yesterday maybe, I don't know.\\" In first person perspective, he introduces his neighbor and best friend.He explains his world to you, all the while showing minimal emotion toward the tragedies that encroach upon his life. You begin to feel a bond to Meursault as much as you feel his distance. Each event pulls you closer to him, but pushes away correspondingly. As you read the book, you will know Meursault but become only a visitor to his soul as he gets drawn into a murder. Albert Camus has written a novel that crosses the nonsensical with catastrophe.I am unhesitant to propose that this story be read by all who have seen this review. 031606792X|4.0|I just recently read the Twilight Saga. (I'm 25, and like a lot of other fans, I felt I was no longer interested in the YA genre.) But curiosity got the best of me, and I decided to see what all the fuss was about.  I, too, fell in love with SM's story and characters, and truly cared what happened to them in the final book.  That said, I was surprised at how much I enjoyed Breaking Dawn, and even more surprised at all the negative responses to it.        ::CAUTION -- SPOILERS BELOW::      Anyone and everyone should have known that Bella was eventually going to be a vampire. It was a suprise that she adapted so well, but completely believable. I was actually glad that it turned out that way, because I would have gotten bored if she was constantly thinking about killing people and couldn't focus on anything else.  As for the Jacob/Renesmee scandal, since the moment SM introduced \\"imprinting,\\" it was obvious that Jacob was going to imprint on someone...eventually.  It was the only way to clean up the Edward/Bella/Jacob love triangle, and it needed to be resolved. The fact that he imprinted on Bella's daughter was definitely a twist, but not all that shocking once you got used to it.  It kind of made sense that he would imprint on her daughter, because he loved Bella so much...or thought he did.  I honestly didn't find it all that weird or gross -- I mean, this IS a fantasy novel!  As for Renesmee herself, I didn't see that coming, but should have after the conversation Rosalie has with Bella in book three. A lot of people have complained that Bella never even wanted to have a child, but having a family was one of the perks she saw of being with Jacob -- they could have children, whereas she couldn't once she became a vamp. I will admit that Bella's pregancy - the broken bones, drinking blood, the belief that the child would have to chew itself out of the womb - was disturbing, but the fact that she was carrying a vampire's child let's you know that it wasn't going to be easy or normal. It made sense that it would be dangerous.       The complaint that the ending sends a bad message to teens: do anything for your guy, marry early, get pregnant early, everything will be perfect -- is completely ridiculous. This honestly didn't cross my mind as I was reading because, one, I'm not a teenager, and two, it's a fantasy - bad things happen enough in every day life; it's nice to have a story every once in a while that ends perfectly, or almost so.  And please, lets give the teenagers a little more credit. I would hope that no sane 16 or 17 year old girl would read this story and think, \\"hey, I wonder if this could happen to me\\" and immediately start taking life lessons from fictional vampires and werewolves.  Sure, even I will admit that it's really easy to fall in love with Edward Cullen, but no more so than Mr. Darcy or Edward Rochester, and they're humans!  Stephenie Meyer said in the interview on this page that she began writing Twilight for herself, and was very surprised at how popular the books had become. She didn't start out writing for a YA audience, so I don't think people should be concerned that the books may or may not send the right message to teenagers.    The only thing I was in any way disappointed about (and I would say more perplexed than disappointed) was Bella's cloudy memories of herself as a human. It was known it would be that way - the audience was set up for that - but I still found it a little sad that everything she had been through with Edward, all the emotions shared with the reader, were reduced to hazy memories. Even though I loved Bella as a vampire, I found myself mourning the old Bella that I had grown to know in the last 3 1/2 books (though I was pretty much fed up with her by the end of Eclipse), and I kind of wished that SM had changed her earlier on in the series. An earlier reviewer made an interesting point -- they said BD was almost like a stand-alone novel. I wouldn't exactly agree with that, but I can definitely understand what was meant: like a whole new story had started. But I'm guessing it was supposed to be like that.  But that's just my two cents. Overall, I thought the book was riveting, and a pretty satisfying conclusion to the saga. It definitely competes with Twilight as my favorite in the series.
031606792X|5.0|(This is not my account I'm using my parent's right now because I lost my old one)    To start off, Breaking Dawn was AMAZING. I could not put it down; it had so many surprises and twists that I was just on edge the whole time. I LOVE THIS BOOK.    Don't let what others say make you shy away from this book or series; some people, it seems, get a little too into a story and forget that this is only a fiction piece. I understand that many readers come to identify with one character throughout the story and don't get the ending they wanted. They claim it's too \\"easy\\" and ending or that it's not realistic. Well, let me be realistic for them: the Twilight series is an AMAZING work of fiction, folks. Like Harry Potter, it's just not real. It has a realistic setting and characters, but face it, vampires and werewolves aren't exactly a realistic norm in society, right? So give the books a break.    (SPOILERS AHEAD)    One review claimed that the story didn't teach good morals. Only... why would you even try to get morals from a fiction book?? I know I keep repeating that about fiction but... why?? Bella and Edward have a baby. They end up together in the end. Jacob finds someone for him, even if it is their baby. It's not like he's a pedophile, he wants to protect her and be there for her. Be anything Renesmee needs him to be. That's just how it is. The ending is satisfying- everyone stays as family. And If you are somehow looking for morals in these books, what more could you ask for? Family protects family; family stays with family no matter what. People not satisfied with that ending would have wanted more death? If Jacob or Edward or Bella or any of the Cullens had died, would more fans have been happy? That just doesn't seem likely.    (END SPOILERS)    Breaking Dawn is a great book. It's simply amazing. It's written wonderfully and creatively through two different perspectives, which made it more interesting to me. It won't let you down, as long as you don't become too intent on your own \\"perfect ending\\" for the story. Don't let the other reviews get you down; they just didn't get what they wanted. READ THIS BOOK!

Its a sad state when people would prefer that there was carnage in the end of what was, at its core, a love story.    I was happy to have not lost anyone that I had grown to care for over 4 books. No.  But is her love story realistic?  No, we can surely agree that its not.    Stephenie Meyer delivered her vision of the end of this story.  I applaud her for being gutsy enough to deliver the ending that noone expected.  I hope that she knows some people do appreciate the happy ending to the Twilight saga.

031606792X|4.0|I have been a fan of this series since Twilight was first released, I have been anxiously awaiting this fourth and final book for three years now, and I was satisfied with the ending.     The first shock for me was to see the table of contents page, only seven chapters were shown. I was a little disapointed that the book was divided up into three books, two from Bella's perspective and one from Jacob. Now, I can see why Stephenie did this, I wouldn't've wanted to read 250 extra pages of Bella's internal whining about the pain she was in due to her surprising pregnancy, but I must admit that being inside Jacob's head was absolutely boring for me. I am not a member of Jacob Black fan club at all, but I see why his point of view was important to the story, especially toward the end of it.    The book starts out wonderfully. Bella's happy, Edward is happy, everyone is happy! We see just how much Edward and Bella love each other, again. It seemed like it was going to be perfect. And then the honeymoon happened. Meyer is good at not revealing too much, and I was thankful for that. She made it seem like Bella and Edward were in paradise, all alone on their little island. The first time Bella went to throw up after eating \\"bad\\" chicken I knew she was pregnant. I couldn't quite wrap my mind around this shocking twist, it seemed so far fetched, so fan-fiction like, that I had to go back to the title page to make sure I had bought a copy of STEPHENIE MEYER's book, and not an imposter. I suddenly felt angry that Meyer had done something like this, had given Bella a child when I thought she had said that vampires can't reproduce (apparently she was mis-quoted.) I had to take a deep breath and move on, and then when you finally realize that Bella and Edward finally realize that she is pregnant you have to read through so many pages of Jacob Black, it was draining!     When we finally return to Bella she is being changed into a vampire. \\"FINALLY!\\" I thought. I had what I wanted, Bella to be immortal and be with Edward forever, how romantic! And then when she finally woke up she was different. So different. Before she was that plain-but-beautiful girl that the beautiful vampire took notice of; now she's that beautiful vampire with gorgeous everything and perfect coordination, she wasn't like all the regular girls out there anymore. She was a mother. A young mother. It all seemed to change. I felt myself hating her daughter, Renesmee, for being born and changing the character that I loved so much. And then as the story progressed, and I got to know the little half-breed more, I learned to love her, I learned that I wanted to know more and more about her, she was still part of Edward and Bella, the fictional characters I love so much.     The book ended on a happy note, a hopeful note. I found myself wiping away tears of joy as I read the last few lines. These characters within these books will always have such a special place in my heart. These books are so vivid, I sometimes feel as if I could reach out and touch the moss covered trees. Stephenie meyer is a truly talented story teller, her novels have brought so much joy to my life, and for that, I am forever gratefull.    While I still wish we could've skipped some of the things that happened in this book-however necessary they were-I think it was overall a wonderful conclusion to a wonderful saga. I did find myself wanting more Edward and Bella time, but I know that they still reside in their little cottage in the woods in that small rainy town of Forks, Washington, and that makes me so happy.

Of all the newbery books I've read so far this one has been the best, and pushed me to read faster than any book I've ever read.<br /><br />The Giver introduces the reader to some interesting subject matter such as communistic living, where everyone has a place and everyone works for the greater good.  While there is benefit to this style of life, you eliminate indiviuality, and the freedom of choice.  Uniqueness is thrown out the window in favor of predictability and stability.<br /><br />What makes the book interesting is how the different characters handle the mode of life, especially Jonas, who is suddenly given a taste of the truth, and finds the world he is living in unbearable.<br /><br />The book reminded me of the movie \\"The Time Machine\\" (the one with Rod Taylor), In the movie when George gets to the distant future the people there live similarly to the way they do in the book, communaly with no thought to emotion, knowledge, or creativity.  There is one scene in the movie that is eerily like a scene in the book where someone falls into the river and drowns.  I can't help but wonder if Lois Lowry watched the Time Machine before she wrote the book.<br /><br />The book is great and Lois Lowry is a brilliant writer, I can't wait to read more of her work.
0060930349|5.0|Maybe I am biased, but in my opinion, one of the good things about being an American is that our history is really interesting.  Sure, other countries have their moments, but it was the United States that went toe-to-toe against the mighty British Empire - and won.  Ours was the only example in world history of a violent revolution bringing about a change in government in which those who engaged in the fighting did not try to maintain their own power, but voluntarily stepped down when voted out.  And although slavery existed for thousands of years over large sections of the planet, it was Americans who voted in a President knowing full well it would probably tear us apart and force a civil war.  Man, this is high drama.    There is, of course, so much to American history that it can be daunting.  If one wants a single, albeit lengthy, book for an excellent overview, it would be hard to top A HISTORY OF THE AMERICAN PEOPLE, by the prolific Paul Johnson.  From pre-Revolutionary times to the near present day, Johnson presents this nation's history in a manner that gives enough of the facts to learn something meaningful without focusing so sharply on any one period or issue as a more focused book would do.  To make it all the better, Johnson is actually a good writer, making the book as interesting as it is informative.    Many of Johnson's critics accuse him of putting a conservative slant on his writing.  I have been around the block enough to know how this argument works.  Conservatives tell America's story warts and all, while liberals tell America's story as all warts.  Liberals then accuse conservatives of being slanted, not because conservatives exclude the bad parts, but because they include the good parts, as well.  And for all the anti-Americanism out there, telling all the bad and all the good of America does not balance the scale.  If one judges a nation not on the amount of problems it has or the amount of injustice within that country, but on the willingness of that country to face such injustice head on and deal with it, then the U.S. deserves its pre-eminent place among world societies.  For all the griping on the left, I am convinced that many on that side of the spectrum know this as well.    A HISTORY OF THE AMERICAN PEOPLE demonstrates this.  Although I think Johnson does show his beliefs a bit too much in those sections on the mid to late 20th Century, the book overall is biased only in its attempt to portray American history accurately.  Although Johnson is obviously fond of Americans, anyone expecting an uncritical cheerleader for U.S policy and history will be sorely disappointed.  As the book is over 1,000 pages, selectively picking passages to demonstrate bias is a bit tough to take.    For anyone who wants to learn about American history, and for those Americans not ashamed of their own country, this book is highly recommended.  Do not let the size of it intimidate you.  I myself picked it up and put it down several times before finally making my way through it.  Like many lengthy endeavors, it will be well worth it when it's done.

Just as behind every great man there stands a great woman, each of the aforementioned males lends both moral support and strong instrumental backing behind the stellar seductresses who front their acts. 031606792X|4.0|I don't usually review books here on Amazon, but I have to write one this time.  The top reviews on the site don't seem to give Meyer a fair shake.<br /><br />On the idea that Bella would choose Jacob: To me it seemed self-evident that she would never choose Jacob over Edward despite how Jacob might feel about it.  It's first and foremost a vampire novel, not a shapeshifter novel.<br /><br />On Bella's pregnancy: Consider what Meyer is trying to do.  First, she needs to end this story.  All stories end, and Bella & Edward's ends here.  She wanted to show us all about the change to being a vampire, so it had to happen early and for a dramatic reason.  Second, she wants to continue writing in the same universe she's spent so much time inventing.  Three, Jacob needs a mate, someone interesting enough to be his equal so that she can tell his character's story, as it's obviously a good subject for her next series. It helps if that person is already important to the characters we know and love. The solution: Bella & Edward's baby is Jacob's mate.  Maybe that is a bit odd, but she's telling the story & we are along for the ride.  The baby's rapid aging is a plot device so that the human characters will still be around when she tells Jacob and Renesme's story.<br /><br />On Renesme's names: They're just names.  I've seen worse.<br /><br />On seeking a deeper \\"message\\" in a teen vampire romance novel: Really?  People are?  Wow.  I'm sorry that this isn't a message-heavy series.  It's an adventure, speculative fiction--a fantasy.  Not all books have to have a big heavy message.  Really!  It can just be for fun.  Give me a happy ending every time, because there are plenty of not-happy stories out there, both fiction and in real life.<br /><br />My advice to anyone on the fence about this book: It's fun!  It's a little predictable, but it's entertaining.  Just enjoy it for what it is.  If you want pain and love and sacrifice in your vampire romance books & you're over 18, try \\"Sunshine\\" by Robin McKinley.

031606792X|1.0|Not so long ago I bought Twilight on a whim (before it became The Next Big Thing) and enjoyed reading from cover to cover. To sum it up for my husband, I said, \\"Think early Anita Blake for the teen set - a girl, a vampire, and a werewolf without all the twisted fetish stuff.\\" It was a fun book that kept the teenage angst at a minimum, and really focused on telling an engaging story.<br /><br />Fast forward to book four, and wow, it's just like an Anita Blake novel in that the heroine turns out to have ridiculous amounts of supernatural power and the universe has worked it out that she can keep her vampire and her werewolf. I'm all for a little suspension of disbelief, but the author might as well have put a little gift bow on top of this since everything ends up packaged so neatly.<br /><br />(BEWARE, here there be SPOILERS.)<br /><br />The two main characters have gone from being a young couple in love, to the world's two largest Mary Sue's (i.e. they fulfill author/reader wishes no matter how outlandish). Granted, Edward has been idealized from the start, but his everlasting love for Bella has become bludgeoning at this point. What Bella wants, Bella gets, so much so that she assures her own death (so much for that humanity of hers he wanted to protect). For her part, Bella must be lobbying for martyr of the year. She takes RAMPANT BRUISING as par for the course of making love to Edward. She then insists on carrying a mutant fetus to term when it is clearly killing her (what's a few cracked ribs and a broken spine, right?). From her point of view, these aren't problems; she'll just let Edward make her a vampire when the baby eats its way out. In the meantime, let's torture Jacob by making him keep her company in the middle of vampire central. While she becomes little more than an animated skeleton and revoltingly sucks blood from a sippy cup, she goes on and on about her love for Edward, the joys of impending motherhood, and how she and Jacob were meant to be BFFs forever.<br /><br />Bad storyline aside, Bella solidifies her status as one of the worst examples for young female readers ever. Love is wonderful, sacrifice can be noble, but what Bella does just feels masochistic and misogynistic. It's as though she has no love for herself. It's all about Edward, and \\"the little nudger\\" which she thinks of as Edward, Jr. She treads a path of self-destruction with little consideration for her own health, or her parents who love her dearly. It's as though their feelings don't merit concern by virtue of her having married.<br /><br />But not to worry, because Meyer ex machina shall make everything alright. Bella dies while giving birth to a daughter, but Edward still manages to turn her into a vampire. Jake decides to \\"handle\\" the problem of the halfling baby, but instead he imprints on her (i.e. they're now soulmates). What a coincidence. Never mind all the love he had for Bella in books 1, 2 & 3 - he's all about Bella, Jr. now. And lucky him, she'll be an \\"adult\\" in approximately five years. Convenient, yes?<br /><br />Speaking of which, letting Charlie in on the secret is no longer problematic. Jake spills the beans, and Charlie - who couldn't stomach Edward when he thought he was just a regular boy - can suddenly cope with werewolves, vampires, and a grandkid who grows and ages at an exponential rate. So Bella gets her vampire, her baby, her werewolf BFF, AND she gets to see her dad on weekends and holidays.<br /><br />The big baddies, the Volturi, will make an appearance by book end, but what can they do when there's a full-on werewolf/vampire love fest going on with the Cullen Coven, the Quileute pack, and every vampire to make their way to the Seattle area? Everyone's so in love with the halfling (who turns out not to be so unique) that they're willing to face down the vampire boogeymen. Of course there's no real danger since Bella - having skipped that whole annoying out-of-one's-mind-with-blood-lust early vampire childhoodthat EVERY OTHER VAMPIRE experienced - is a natural shield who pretty much learns how to manipulate her power in one month, versus the average decade to century it takes everyone else.<br /><br />Nice and neat, no muss, no fuss, happily ever after.<br /><br />The only bright spot is that this is the end to the series (hopefully).pretty much learns how to manipulate her power in one month, versus the average decade to century it takes everyone else. B00005JO5L|3.0|Viewed now, with the benefit of more than 29 years hindsight, what's startling about William Friedkin's \\"Cruising\\" is its foreboding, apocalyptic (and apparently unintentional) pre-AIDS depiction of gay nightlife as it existed in the late 1970's. Though not by any means a masterpiece, \\"Cruising\\" is an intermittently fascinating study of an undercover cop (played by Al Pacino) investigation of a string of brutal murders of local gay men. Filmed in and around several gay bars and hard-core sex clubs located in the heart of New York City's Greenwich Village (with actual patrons--not only extras--and club life serving as the backdrop), the film was quite controversial at the time of its release.  \\"Cruising prompted a good number of protests for the graphic, no-holds-barred nature of its subject matter and also for its sensationalism, with the potential to incite or increase violence against gays (this movie was made at the height of the \\"gay (sexual) liberation\\" movement). \\"Cruising\\" is best seen for Pacino's stirring performance as the sexually ambivalent Steve Burns, who infiltrates the furtive gay underground scene and finds a powerful, addictive environment that has an intoxicating mixture of danger and gutter glamour.     Like \\"The Exorcist\\" and \\"The Boys in the Band\\" (both of which Friedkin directed), \\"Cruising\\" is often heavy-handed and it raises far more questions about sexuality, cultural identity and societal permissiveness than it answers. Yet the film still holds one's attention as it telescopes a specific cultural phenomenon circa 1979. As portrayed here, the gay scene is at once alluring and repugnant.

These are dark days for the Final Empire...if you're a skaa that is. Talent earns them places with the many numerous skaa thieving crews, groups of men who make small-time raids on the noblemen of the<br />Empire. Dragged there by her abusive brother, Vin remained to pay off her and her brother's debt to the Crew Chief after he ran away and left her.<br /><br /> One day however, after a raid gone wrong, Vin meets up with Kelsier, a handsome, scheming Crew Chief who just happens to be an Allomancer. And not just any Allomancer, a Mistborn.<br /><br /> Allomancers use metals such as Iron, Tin, and Pewter to enhance their bodily powers. Most Allomancers can only use one metal, but a select few, Mistborn, can use all of the 10 metals. Once Vin finds out that she is in fact a Mistborn as well, Kelsier offers her a chance to become a member of his crew. This crew however, isn't just going to \\"pull a job,\\" they're going to pull the biggest job in the history of the final empire...<br /><br /> \\"Lord Ruler...\\" That's what I have to say about \\"Mistborn!\\" It was SO GOOD! I understood all of the politics and actually wanted more, surprising even myself.<br /><br /> The only downside is, I fail to see how the second book in the series (\\"Well of Ascension\\") could possibly live up to the greatness of \\"Mistborn.\\" I'll definitely be there to give it a shot however.<br /><br /> In summary, \\"Mistborn\\" was a refreshing book in a world of sub-standard fantasy littering most of the genre nowadays. B0018PH3L0|5.0|I have been a fan since I first read the book and watched it in its premier broadcast on CBS.  When I am asked to name my favorite movie, I always cite Lonesome Dove (even though it is a made-for-television miniseries).  Today I purchased this newly-released Collector's Edition, even though I already own the 2000 Hallmark 2-disc release, and even though I suspected the touted \\"widescreen\\" had been accomplished by cropping/letterboxing.    After reading the handful of reviews here that seemed to contradict each other, I popped both discs in separate players to compare them with each other.  The good news is, the audio is remarkably crystal clear, a definite improvement.  The picture is also markedly superior, very sharp, and the color is brilliant.  On the older Hallmark version, the colors appear pale and washed out compared to the newer version, which has much deeper and richer tones, after remastering.    The bad news is, it is in fact cropped.  When I watched the two discs side by side, it is immediately apparent that part of the picture is missing at the top and at the bottom of the screen, in most scenes.  What is really strange, however, is that in some scenes part of the picture has been cropped from the (left and/or right) sides of the picture, as well.  There are some scenes in which the picture has been cropped on ALL FOUR sides of the picture.  I am not imagining this.  I was able to confirm this by playing/pausing the two versions side by side and noting that characters are sometimes in frame, other times not visible, parts of signs and lettering on signs are sometimes visible, sometimes not visible.  Objects visible in the older version may not be visible in the newer release.    Even stranger, in the new release, in some scenes one side of the frame may show less (on either the left or the ride side of the picture) in the new version (e.g. missing a person, or an object), but the other side of the frame may show people or objects that do not appear inthe \\"original\\" 4:3 aspect.    Bottom line: it would appear that the original production was filmed in some aspect other than what was originally broadcast on network; this newer version ADDS some of the previously unseen aspect in some scenes, but in other scenes OMITS some of what was originally broadcast.  Still, the picture quality is really nice, and if you are as big a fan as I am of this, the greatest story ever told, it probably won't matter to you.  I will keep my older version copy, but I doubt I will ever have a reason to want to watch it instead of this one.

B0002XV30Q|5.0|I've heard Ciccolini's and Hough's sets of these concerti, but this is my favorite by a wide margin. Hough's has been highly praised elsewhere, and I certainly agree that his technique is astounding. He plays these concerti faster than anyone, and that is precisely my complaint. Hough seems so busy moving through these works at warp three hyperdrive that he takes just about NO time to stop and smell the roses--and there are plenty in this music.<br /><br />Not that Collard is slow. He can glitter just well as Hough, but he also knows when to seduce--listen to the second theme of the scherzo of No.2--the way he and Previn teasingly hang on to a note just a microsecond before playfully plunging into the phrase itself. They don't make a big deal of this, and these performances are NOT \\"mannered,\\" but the listener is drawn in, and the sensation is almost physical. This is only one instance of the felicities of agogics and phrasing in these performances.<br /><br />I have not heard the Licad performance so esteemed by another reviewer at the expense of Collard's. Personally, I've never heard anything by Licad I've liked. Her CD of Gottschalk was panned by FANFARE. Of course, that doesn't mean she couldn't be good in No.2, but there's nothing wrong with Collard.<br /><br />It's just a pity this couldn't have been rounded out to a trio of CD's to include the Rapsodie d'Auvergne and Allegro appassionato also recorded by this team. I own both this set and Hough's, but I listen to this one a LOT more. Also, the price is certainly more attractive than Hyperion's, although for me that is NOT the issue.

031606792X|4.0|Stephanie Meyer did a awesome job with this novel. She managed to tie up all loose ends yet still keep the reader interested and on the edge. There were differences in this novel compared to the others, however, and I can see why people would feel differently. For instance, this novel seemed more to concentrate on character development, both individual and interpersonal, rather than plot development. As readers, we get to know Emmett, Rosalie, Jasper, Seth, and Leah much more personally than the other novels allowed. Also, this novel branched out into more than just Jacob-Bella-Edward; it became less of a romance story. I enjoyed it immensely. Meyer used wonderful rhetoric and characterization, especially when writing from Jacob's perspective. She kept it funny while at the same time never letting the reader forget about the weight of the circumstances.   I do agree with the statement that it was almost too good to be true;it's impossible for everything to turn out that perfectly. At the same time, though, I must admit that if the story wasn't as \\"happily ever after\\" as it was, I would have hated it. Meyer developed all of her characters so well that it was impossible not to feel attached to them, and if they suffered or died, there was a very high possibility of me throwing he book across the room and injuring some innocent bystander.   Great read and I highly reccomend it.
031606792X|2.0|*spoilers*    I just thought everything ended up so neatly-too neatly.  It wasn't realistic at all; for even though it's a story with vampires and shape-shifters, characters can still be presented as real people within the story.  These people are decidedly not.      Bella is the very definition of a \\"Mary Sue\\" character.  People automatically like her for little to no reason, she's got super special powers, she looks just like her author (before transformation,) she's got guys fighting over her, etc.  But accepting that, this book, and the others for that matter, are harmless fluff.  If it gets people to read and enjoy their time doing so, then it has a place in the marketplace.     So, basically, read this book if you don't care that it's got an entirely implausible premise, heavy-handed morality, an obsessive and overly simplistic take on love, and a hefty dose of silliness.  I enjoyed reading it for the most part.

031606792X|1.0|BREAKING DAWN was muchly anticipated by all Twilight fans, whether they were teenagers or the Twilight moms. Everybody was waiting for the ending to come, to see what would happen with Bella and Edward, whether she'd change or not, how the wedding would go and much more.<br /><br />Stephenie Meyer attempted to give us the perfect ending to a bestselling saga. But in the end, we lost our main character when she was traded in for a perfect version; a perfect human being. We lost our ability to sympathize with her, to feel that Bella Swan, or Cullen, could be a potential rolemodel.<br /><br />While Breaking Dawn starts exactly as we thought it would, it takes a loop from chapter 7 on, and unfortunately for a lot of us, it didn't suit our tastes at all.<br /><br />Before we go on, I'd like to issue a SPOILER WARNING here. Thank you.<br /><br />The plot was severely lacking. To be quite honest, there was none. It read like an insipid epilogue that was stretched out over 700. Every little thing that happened seemed to be plucked out of thin air in order to fill up the book. Pregnancy? Well sure. Grotesque birth? Well okay. Volturri coming over for a quick visit with the entire group only to leave within an hour or so? Sure.<br /><br />Furthermore, I was a bit confused at some points as I thought over Meyer's personal rules. She stated clearly that she wanted her children to be able to read the books, thus no sex would be included (which, by all means, I don't mind). But then a few chapters later, here we get an incredibly detailed, and to be honest, sick moment in which Bella vomits a fountain of blood, breaks her spine, and has several other things done to her, which includes Edward biting her placenta... and that's okay for children to read? Well that's a first.<br /><br />Also, being a feminist, I was extremely disappointed with the overall anti-feminism thing that was going on in the book. Apparently us women can't be completely happy if we're not married to a perfect guy and have children. Both Rosalie and Leah have been addressed as such and while Rosalie is married, she's more focused on Bella's baby than anything, while Leah is simply miserable because she's missing children. Also, to have Bella beg for sex, even exchanging her humanity for it left a very bad aftertaste in my mouth. But the thing that I found the worst of all was Edward concocting a plan to get Jacob to impregnate his wife again, if she had an abortion. Wow.<br /><br />Which brings me to the next point. Edward and Bella's relationship is the crux to the success of this series, to be honest. Some of us like Jacob & Bella more together, others like the other couples in it, but most fans are Edward and Bella shippers.<br /><br />Then why, during the book, did we get no romantic lines, like in the previous three books? To be honest, the only times we really had Edward around was when he slept with Bella, during the ending, or during the birth. During the rest of the book, he suddenly seemed like a secondary character, replaced by Renesmee and Jacob (both had far more prominent roles, despite the former coming into the book around halfway through).<br /><br />Also, might I add my tremendous disappointment concerning the very hard issues that were dismissed too easily in order for the happy ending to take place? Such as Bella's first year as a newborn, Bella having to let go of her parents and Jacob changing the treaty so easily for her, her being able to be around humans, her new superpower that was mastered so easily. In the end, Bella had to sacrifice nothing. Not even her physical urges towards Edward were lessened, but strengthened.<br /><br />It was a book that was promising and with those 700 pages, Meyer could have pulled off a very succesful ending to a great series. Too bad it's filled up with nonsense, lack-of-action, grotesque births, anti-feminism and loss of our main character. Because Bella, after being changed, is no longer the clumsy, smart kid that she used to be. She's perfect, and therefore, none of us can compare with her.<br /><br />Breaking Dawn proved me wrong about this series. It isn't about sacrifice for those you love and want to be with, or about making choices and becoming a responsible adult. To me, it seems that it's a story that if you're ready to marry and have a child at a young age, abandon your ambitions and education, you'll have a happy life. It's just too bad the real world doesn't always work that way.<br /><br />What a shame..    Breaking Dawn proved me wrong about this series. It isn't about sacrifice for those you love and want to be with, or about making choices and becoming a responsible adult. To me, it seems that it's a story that if you're ready to marry and have a child at a young age, abandon your ambitions and education, you'll have a happy life. It's just too bad the real world doesn't always work that way.    What a shame.

031606792X|5.0|As with the last three books in this series, Stephanie Meyer drew me completely into the world and the emotions of her characters. I really didn't feel that I read a 700 plus page book; but I did feel that I had completely lived this book with its characters. I have always loved a good romance. Did Bella get everything she wanted? Yes. That's what happens in a good romance. But Bella fought hard for everything she got; she earned her happy ending.     I had wondered how Stephanie Meyer would end this vampire story and still stay true to her own beliefs about what constitutes a happy ending. She did a great job. Will everyone be happy? No. Many people (myself included) are drawn to vampires for the glamour -- eternal youth, beauty, wealth, sex without consequence, a carefree life with few or no responsibilities. Well, there was little of that glamour in this book. But those were not the things that Bella ever wanted.     I didn't feel a wrong or false note in the whole story. And I thought Ms. Meyer stayed true to the rules of the world she had created. From reading some of the reviews, I feel there were readers who didn't accept those rules. For instance, imprinting was explained many times throughout the last two books. But there were readers who continued to see imprinting in terms of \\"romantic love\\" despite all the clear evidence that it is something much more than that.     I had worried that the author would not let us actually see Bella become a vampire. But we did get to see it. And there was suffering. But Bella turned in to the vampire we all knew she would be. And she dicovered her own strength. My highest praise for the book would have to be the fact that when Bella finally confronted her adversaries and bared her teeth, prepared to fight for all she loved; I actually found myself growling with her! I was completely with Bella in that moment!    And the author did a great job of building suspense toward the final climax of the book. She made me blink. Even though I knew this romance had to have a happy ending, there were some moments there when the author made me wonder... Mrs. Meyer has always done a great job of building the suspense in her stories. They are definitely page turners.     And, of course, Edward was wonderful as always. I have always loved his character, but in this final installment I really got a sense of how far he would go to protect those he loved. There aren't many men who would be able to make the sacrifices he was willing to make for Bella --or do what he did to help her have all that she wanted. The birthing scene was truly gripping. And for those who feel the author is advocating teen pregnancy, sorry. I just don't feel that many teens are going to rush out to get pregant after reading about that birth. Yes, there was a lot of blood. But who reads a vampire story and complains about blood? It's part of the territory and I loved the gritty realism.    Finally, Mrs. Meyer did an excellent job of portraying the passion between these two young lovers without providing any graphic details. I'm not bothered by graphic details; romance is my favorite genre. But I didn't miss it here at all. And I think that's a true testament to Mrs. Meyer's writing - a gripping romance without any lurid sexual details. I couldn't put it down. And I'm finding it hard to forget even now. I will miss Bella and Edward. But I know they are happy. And so am I.

They generally behaved in uncharacteristic ways, and suddenly began entirely new behaviors which were rather odd(why the sudden nicknames?, for example). Neither parent,nor anyone in the bloodlines, grew or grows at a super fast pace, why would the offspring?) Once Bella discovered she was pregnant,the book really did seem to jump the shark. ANYWAY, this book was not only an action packed page flipper with some creative twists (I have to say I predicted the pregnancy when she threw out the chicken and the imprinting when Jacob was talking about the balloons being let go), but also I loved the way it gave the characters personality and about all the literary ironies and allusions to other works.  It really felt like a cross between the Harry Potter series and the Inheritance (Eragon) series and maybe some Underworld thrown in (Except the werewolves, or I guess shape-shifters, were called lichens.). The chapter titles in book 2 (Jacob) were a cool way to create a distinct personality. I like the one that was like what am I the wizard of oz? But this book was JAMPACKED with ironies! I loved all the connections! For instance how Carlisle would not force Bella to give up Nessie when she was pregnant, which angered Jacob, but Jacob would not force his pack to follow his orders as Alpha. Things like that made me smile because of the irony! Not in all ways, but similar enough. And also a set of twins, which basically held a group together, was in both stories. Jane and Alec in twilight, and those bald headed traitors in Eragon. Aro looking through Edward's mind reminded be of one of those twins probing Eragon. I don't know about anyone else but the consistency with \\"V\\" in this fantasy stories are all connected! Harry Potter has VOLDEMORT, Eragon has VARDEN, and Twilight has VOLTURI. More than that, the almost battle between pretty much good and bad at the end reminded me of the battle of Troy in Greek mythology. Except this was of course a smaller scale version and instead of it being a woman they were fighting over, it was a baby girl! I interpreted the cover a few ways. First I think that the smaller red pawn was the bloodlust Bella had as a vampire, and the white chess piece was her overwhelming goodness and control that dominated her being. Also it could be good against evil, Cullens against the Volturi, with good of course triumphing. Another thing, I am sick of people making a big deal out o the sex in this book! Like seriously, stop being immature and get over it! Everything means something, sex isn't just sex, its really about the beauty of the moment of how despite the odds Bella and Edward belong together and they fit perfectly. It is a symbol of love and happiness, not some perverted thing that people are making it out to be! And more then that, his book is about messages!! I can totally relate this book to the real world in some ways. Like how the werewolves were racist against the vampires and vice versa. It is just like how people act today with difference races.
