B000A6T1KE|5.0|My apologies up front, but my review of this film, and reaction to some of the other reviews present, is more personal and less detached than reviews of this type usually should be. But where Star Trek is concerned, my opinions are more emotional, and even deeply  more personal than usual for TV and film subject matter.  If this will derail you, read no further.  After watching so many people regurgitate their semi-informed views on the state of Trek and recent projects, and this film in particular, I have abandoned my \\"to each their own\\" stance on the subject, and will have my say.  Another reviewer writes: \\"I'm simply amazed at how many Star Trek fans abhor this movie! I guess I'm not enough of a Trekkie to understand the hatred, though I have been a fan since the 1970's.\\"  I was thinking the opposite. I myself have been a fan since the '70's. I believe that makes people like us \\"real\\" fans, and provides sufficient credentials to have an opinion. At first I also wondered why so many bad reviews. Then, I realized, in settings like this, you are not seeing the opinions of Star Trek fans. You are getting the opinions of \\"a majority of the people.\\" Big difference. Star Trek never was truly appreciated by a majority of the people. A majority of the people apparently thought the original series should be cancelled....  Asking people who probably did not truly \\"get\\" Trek, and what made it work to begin with, to rate which movie is the best, is like asking my mom and dad (children of the 50's) if Iron Maiden is a great band, and just taking their word for it. Not the proper audience.  You have people that are too young to appreciate the original, and wish it were more like Babylon 5, or folks that think Sci-Fi should run like a reality show. But, I digress....  Nemesis is, along with Star Trek II, probably one of the best of all Trek films. (As a true cinematic artwork, and excellent overall expression of the \\"Great Bird\\" 's original concept for ST without the limitationsof weekly serial TV, Star Trek: The Motion Picture tops them all, and has not been surpassed. But, it lacked the sting of battle, heat of conflict, and the shrill squeal of phaser fire that fans craved.) Like Star Trek II, Nemesis has its share of flaws and inconsistencies, but like STII these are out shined by the action, drama, and spirit of adventure. These were seriously lacking in TNG episodes and films, and this final TNG piece seems to have been given a major transfusion of TOS blood. Ironic that yet again, when Paramount finally gets it right, they again nip it off at the bud because box office returns weren't exactly what they wanted, after trying this exact formula with newer TNG cast a total of ONE time. Those of us long suffering fans have come to expect nothing less from them.  If it is time to let Star Trek be, it is not because its potential is gone, it is because those to whom the reigns have passed do not know how to utilize it creatively, and refuse to listen to the people who really watch it loyally: Longtime Fans. Not the \\"bloggers\\" online that tune in now and then when taking a break from World of War Craft, or there is nothing good on Sci-Fi Channel. I hate to say it, but: If you don't like this film, you probably just don't like Star Trek anyway, and should just go watch your old episodes of \\"Earth2\\", and leave this fine film, and its fans in peace.

1569242739|5.0|The cupcakes are delicious, moist, and gorgeous; there's a wonderful variety of offerings from the very easy to the uber-fancy, but Isa and Terry make it all very non-threatening. I made a batch of the lemon macadamia nut cupcakes for a party not long ago and they were devoured instantly; only my lactose-intolerant bf knew that they were vegan. The cupcakes I've made have all turned out to be moist (it's worth saying twice) and flavorful, and could stand alone nicely without frosting--strong words from someone who normally ignores the cake entirely in favor of the frosting! The authors pay scrupulous attention to flavor, mouthfeel, and texture in all recipes; the tips on baking and where to find some of the less everyday materials or ingredients are also very helpful.    Some of the ingredients can be hard to find for some of the recipes (I have torn the greater St. Louis area apart trying to find vegan cream cheese, to no avail), but that's sort of to be expected. Bottom line, I'll happily live in any world these ladies decide to take over.
031606792X|3.0|Life after Harry Potter has been rough for adults.  I found Twilight looking for Harry's replacement. I also think that both Meyer's and Bella's inability to let Jacob go lead to that really creepy imprint on Renesmee in Breaking Dawn.   I still don't know why Bella loves Edward (not helped by the sex in BD) and much of that interplay has been edited out for the relationship between Jacob and Bella.  As for Bella herself, she only becomes interesting to me as a vampire, now that we will never hear her point of view again.  May I paraphrase Tupac here, \\"Bella's got a baby, but Bella's hardly got a brain.\\"   In Twilight, I thought that Bella was one of the most endearing characters ever and that continued into New Moon.  But after she realizes she loves Jacob in Eclipse and couldn't let him go in Breaking Dawn, she just became an idiot to me.  So not only is Bella one of the weakest (mentally) characters in literary history she now has the care of any innocent child?  Yikes.    The highlight of Breaking Dawn was the gathering of the vampires, whom I hope we get to hear more about in future books.   I am all for the Carlisle Chronicles, but only if there is better editing.  The negatives--there should have been an epic battle with the Volturi or at least someone should have spanked Jane and Alec for being so rude.    And Jacob imprinting on Nessie, yuck.  Future conversations:  Nessie, \\"Jacob, have you ever been in love before?  Yes, Nessie with your mother, and I kissed her, and imagined her naked, and tried to break her hand after she married your father.\\"   Why couldn't Jacob be better off with Leah?  They were of one mind with broken hearts and were starting to understand each other.  I saw the chance for Jacob's character development, which was lost.  Think, when Nessie is seven and fully developed, he will be 23 and it will still be conceptually gross.     Was this a good book?, well it wasn't as bad as Eclipse.   I think what I was looking for was there, Edward and Bella are together forever.  Has Meyer lost a fan?  In the end, Meyer is a millionaire and I have contributed to that fund.  But, I don't think I will be there at midnight to purchase another one of her books.  I will check it out from the library first, unless she decides to get better editors.  (Read the unedited version of the Rowling's Sorcerer's Stone.)  I am just upset because I think Meyer had the chance to be as great as Tolkien or Rowling with these novels and missed it.  Now, I think the kid who writes the Eragon series might have a better chance at that elusive greatness.
B0000033TE|3.0|There is very little doubt that Emerson, Lake & Palmer were one of the most talented bands in the history of rock. Each individual was among the very best at his respective instrument. It's unfortunate though that, like most of their albums, Brain Salad Surgery is an inconsistent affair. When they got it right it was some of the best stuff ever recorded, but when they didn't get it right it was some dismal stuff. Some of this stems from what they decided to record, in particular, songs they didn't write. Many consider Brain Salad Surgery to be ELP's best album, I disagree, I consider Tarkus to be their best studio album.    Brain Salad Surgery was their fourth studio album & very little that followed was worth having. Don't get me wrong, I'm a big ELP fan, owning every one of their releases through Love Beach, also saw them in concert twice. Brain Salad Surgery peaked at #11 on the charts but didn't have any singles that charted. \\"Still... You Turn Me On\\" was released as a single & is a good Greg Lake ballad but the rhyming triplet in it (sadder..., madder..., someone get me a ladder\\") is one of the most annoying & ill considered rhymes in the annals of rock.    The album opens with \\"Jerusalem\\" which is an okay selection; It's a hymn from the Anglican church done in the ELP way. Next is \\"Toccata\\", another song that they reached outside the group to record. Emerson had wanted to do this piece for a long time, it does feature some drum synthesizers from Carl Palmer but, unfortunately, it's less than good, though it is interesting. Next is the Greg Lake ballad \\"Still... You Turn Me On\\" with the aforementioned triplet. Lake usually included one ballad per album which, to me, was always a highlight of their albums. \\"Still... You Turn Me On\\" isn't any different in that regard from his other ballads; it's a great song except for the annoying triplet. \\"Benny the Bouncer\\" is next. ELP would also include a novelty song on most albums, Brain Salad Surgery isn't any different.But, like every other novelty song they wrote, it's definite filler, definitely below the talent level of this band. I guess that they felt it was necessary because they were such a 'serious' band & needed to lighten the tone, at least for a single song. Next is the centerpiece of the album \\"Karn Evil Nine\\". This song originally encompassed an entire side, & a piece of the other side, of the vinyl release. \\"Karn Evil Nine\\" is done in four movements which reflects some of their classical training. Many consider \\"Karn Evil Nine\\" to be ELP's greatest studio achievement. I consider it to be their second best, \\"Tarkus\\" would be, in my opinion, the pinnacle recording of their studio efforts. Without a doubt, though, \\"Karn Evil Nine\\" is probably their most recognized prog-rock piece. One movement (2nd Impression) is an Emerson solo piece that shows just how good he is on an unadulterated piano (no special effects or electronics).     This particular edition has a bonus track that is an interview with the group. In it they discuss some of the things that were involved in the recording of the album. It's absolutely unnecessary. I never did like so-called bonus tracks that are interview excerpts. This is the sort of thing that shouldn't ever be included on a cd. How many people do you know that play this track when comes on the player? Usually, after a couple of listenings, most people will skip the track or eject the cd.    This is a good ELP effort though not their best. I consider it to be their second best studio album.
031606792X|2.0|Let me first say I loved the first 3 books.  So much so that I've read them all several times and enjoy them each time. 031606792X|4.0|I had been waiting anxiously for my book to arrive from Amazon and was reading reviews in the meantime.  I was kind of shocked by the amount of people who didn't like the book.  After reading the reviews, I prepared myself for disappointment.      Frankly, my expectations were wrong.  After reading the book, I really like it.  I will agree with some other reviewers that it moves too fast, it's a little too neatly packaged, etc.  However, the tenor of this book is more mature, which I really appreciated.  I'm 25 and highly enjoyed the first three books, but I found the melodrama and Bella's lack of maturity and pratical worship of Edward annoying and the endless repetition of certain words (scowl, grimace, beautiful, crooked smile, etc.) distracting.      The things Bella experiences in this book--pregnancy, childbirth, vampire conversion--change her.  She becomes a woman. Her conversion to a vampire puts her on equal footing with Edward, which also brings their relationship to a new level.  They love each other more than ever, but it seemed more realistic now.  The way their relationship is described in the previous books sounds more like infatuation.  In this book, as spouses and parents, their relationship reads more of deep love and respect for each other and their child.    Bottom line--this book was highly entertaining.  Isn't that it's job, anyway? :)    I also couldn't help noticing how some the characters and situations SM creates in this book might lead to spin-offs.  Will the Volturi come again? What will happen to Jake and Nessie? Will the Volturi find the vampire who has created so many vampire-human hybrids?? Hmmm...

031606792X|1.0|Unlike the many Twilight-crazed fans out there, I was never too hung up on the series; to me, it always presented light, if entertaining reading. When I picked up Breaking Dawn, I was looking forward to a book that would tie up the series in a satisfactory way; I was in for a rude surprise.  The problem that Breaking Dawn has is very similar to the 5th Harry Potter book: it is too long, badly edited, and full of anger and resentment cropping up ine the strangest places.  Much ado has been made about the disturbing scenes in this book (and I am not one to deny the fact that they exist). Edward asking the unthinkable from Jake, Bella's violent (and sudden!) pregnancy, and Jake's imprinting on a BABY all make for some queasy reading. But that is not the point.  People talk about how Bella has it too perfect: a loving husband, a baby, Jake, eternity, beauty--everything anyone coul want--but that is not the point either.  What really bothered me about this series was that there was no character development and growth. True, having godlike vampire floating around can do wonders in the way of allowing static charachters, but it doesn't explain everything. All you have is people going witht he flow--everyone listening to each other and doing NOTHING.  And then there is Bella. So much has been made of the arduous transition from human to vampire--the pain, the violence, the searing thirst. And then Bella doesn't even experience it. She doesn't struggle, doesn't fight, doesn't develop as a person. At eighteen she is guaranteed a perfect existense though no merit of her own.  What a horrid message to leave a reader with.

Go read some fan fiction, and pick your favorite ending, and most likely it will be better than this.  Seriously...all of the characters could have died, and I would have felt better about this book.

031606792X|1.0|After a marathon 2 days this week of reading the first 3 books in the Twilight series, I was very satisfied and looking forward to finding out how Meyer would resolve her story.  I enjoyed the build up to the wedding, the wedding, and the honeymoon.  The emotions of the newlyweds and how they handled the physical aspect of their relationship was well presented - since this was not only their first time together,  but also the first time (that anyone knew) that a vampire and a human had come together.  Up to this point, I was still \\"hooked\\".<br /><br />And then, as I read on, I became less and less enchanted with Meyer's story.  It began to feel as if I had read something like it before, and the feeling the book started having on me was one I had experienced with another book series I had enjoyed years before - Jean Auel's Clan of the Cave Bear series - book 5 (Shelters of Stone).  Reading further, I saw more and more similarities between the books:<br /><br />- The ever greater Mary-sueing of Bella.  She goes from being a moody, klutzy teenage girl with plenty of quirky hangups to the most beautiful, uber-newborn Vampire the world had ever seen.<br /><br />- The introduction of a baby with a ridiculous name (Renesmee verses Jondalya), whose powers are so extraordinary that it's like the second coming. Everyone who meets the little imp is awed and worshipful.  The introduction of Renesmee to all the covens also reminded me of the many introductions Ayla and Wolf experienced in Auel's novels - and the similarities of that same worshipful awe were also present.<br /><br />- The introduction of far too many characters who were no more then a name (and usually a superpower).<br /><br />- The reduction of the male hero to merely a stud device.  In Breaking Dawn, Edward attains a very similar status to Jean Auel's male character, Jondalar.  After three books, where he's been presented to the reader as fairly engaging, powerful, and in control (if not a little controlling), here he's really only helpful when he's needed for vampire sex or encouraging the pimping out of his wife to her best friend to make more \\"human\\" babies.  Heck, even his newborn wife can kick his butt now!<br /><br />- The buildup of tension in the form of the Volturi and what they would do to our clan (excuse me...coven) had potential, but it never got realized in the end.  The big showdown turned into nothing more then a chance for the vampires worldwide to come together and oohhh and aaahhh over a little mutant princess.  As someone else noted in their review, no one ended up sacrificing anything.  Jacob and his entire story arc were neatly dealt with by inserting a creepy plot twist with Renesmee.  Not one character died, mainly because the newest member of the coven - that's right - Mary-Sue/Bella - was able to protect all of them with a nifty little mind trick she learned in just a few days of practice!<br /><br />I guess I'm just particularly disgusted with this final installment because 3/4's of the novel didn't ring true in relation with the other three in the series.  It almost felt like someone else had written this one, and all the fears, doubts, tensions and conflicts that made the first three so interesting was greatly lacking in this one.<br /><br />And so, after rambling on far too long, I'd like to wrap up with this:<br />Meyer's books are still overall an engaging series, although in my opinion, Breaking Dawn drags the series down.  Like Jean Auel's Clan of the Cave Bear series, I think Meyer became too much in love with her characters and didn't want anything bad to happen to them, so she took the easy (and boring) route, and gave them all happy endings, to the detriment of the plot.he's needed for vampire sex or encouraging the pimping out of his wife to her best friend to make more \\"human\\" babies.  Heck, even his newborn wife can kick his butt now!    - The buildup of tension in the form of the Volturi and what they would do to our clan (excuse me...coven) had potential, but it never got realized in the end.  The big showdown turned into nothing more then a chance for the vampires worldwide to come together and oohhh and aaahhh over a little mutant princess.  As someone else noted in their review, no one ended up sacrificing anything.  Jacob and his entire story arc were neatly dealt with by inserting a creepy plot twist with Renesmee.  Not one character died, mainly because the newest member of the coven - that's right - Mary-Sue/Bella - was able to protect all of them with a nifty little mind trick she learned in just a few days of practice!    I guess I'm just particularly disgusted with this final installment because 3/4's of the novel didn't ring true in relation with the other three in the series.  It almost felt like someone else had written this one, and all the fears, doubts, tensions and conflicts that made the first three so interesting was greatly lacking in this one.    And so, after rambling on far too long, I'd like to wrap up with this:  Meyer's books are still overall an engaging series, although in my opinion, Breaking Dawn drags the series down.  Like Jean Auel's Clan of the Cave Bear series, I think Meyer became too much in love with her characters and didn't want anything bad to happen to them, so she took the easy (and boring) route, and gave them all happy endings, to the detriment of the plot.

B0016NF06O|5.0|From the category of \\"collaborations I would have never thought of\\" comes a gem of a CD from Willie Nelson and Wynton Marsalis.  However, Two Men With The Blues is going to appeal much more to the Willie Nelson fans out there.  It follows in the tradition of Nelson's 2000 release Milk Cow Blues.  In fact both CDs share the songs \\"Night Life\\" and \\"Ain't Nobody's Business\\".<br /><br />You might think that two legends on the same stage might not work, but these two are more than willing to share the stage not only with each other but also with the musicians such as long time Nelson harmonica player, Mickey Raphael.  The songs on the CD follow a blended format between traditional lyrical and jazz instrumental.  Interspersed among the verses and chorus on the songs are instrumental solos.  I was amazed at how comfortably Marsalis would solo only to hand off to Mickey for a romp on the harmonica.  The chemistry of the musicians was outstanding across the board.  Not to be lost in the instrumental greatness, Willie Nelson delivers at the top of his game as one would expect based on his body of work - especially over the last decade.<br /><br />The real question, though, is when you listen to the CD as a whole, is it greater than the sum of its parts?  Without a doubt, it is.  The lead off track \\"Bright Lights, Big City\\" is a great blues shuffle that highlights both lead musicians equally well.  Next comes a Nelson staple, \\"Night Life\\".  Longtime Nelson fans will enjoy yet another variation on this that is highlighted by Marsalis' trumpet lines that are so bluesy that they could only be described as raunchy.  Other standout songs include \\"Basin Street Blues\\" and \\"That's All\\", a number with rather playful lyrics that fit Willie Nelson's persona and delivery to a tee.<br /><br />All in all, this is a truly great CD that captures one of the many \\"once in a lifetime\\" moments of Willie Nelson's career.  If you enjoyed Milk Cow Blues, this is a must have.<br /><br />Download this:  Night Life

B000068QZK|4.0|Update- April 8th, 2013.<br /><br />Wow my previous review was complete garbage.  Let me make it better!<br /><br />No Rest For the Wicked is, in my opinion at least, a return to form as far as sheer aggression is concerned.  One of the heaviest albums Ozzy ever made (if we ignore Randy Rhoads brilliant guitar playing from Blizzard of Ozz and Diary of a Madman, that is).  Even better- the songwriting and vocal melodies are *incredibly* strong this time around, even though I actually enjoy Ozzy's vocal melodies from the Ultimate Sin exactly as much as the ones here and think that album is seriously underrated (just like No Rest for the Wicked is underrated these days, in fact).<br /><br />\\"Miracle Man\\" is one of the best songs Ozzy Osbourne ever made and... to my knowledge, doesn't get ANY radio exposure.  I've NEVER heard this song on the radio but given the memorable way Ozzy sings the line \\"He don't know where he's going, but we know just where he's been\\" is AMAZINGLY good.  Reminds me of the Never Say Die-era of Black Sabbath (which I consider a MAJOR compliment).  It deserves to be one of Ozzy's most beloved songs.  \\"Devil's Daugther (Holy War)\\" benefits by having an extremely good, chugging verse melody that's almost disco in nature, except the fact that, yes, it rocks *hard*.  It's probably an example of a song that reminds me of disco without actually BEING disco (just in case any heavy metal fans out there take exception to my disco similarity, haha).  \\"Crazy Babies\\" is HORRIBLE though.  I hate the chorus with a passion.  \\"CRAZY!!..... BABIES!!\\"  The sloppy/incomplete way it's written with a pause in between the two words nearly makes me vomit, haha.  Oh well, every artist is allowed one or two missteps.<br /><br />\\"Breaking All the Rules\\" features a strong vocal melody even though 5 minutes is sort of repetitive.  \\"Bloodbath In Paradise\\" is placed in the same category as \\"Miracle Man\\" for me.  Two songs that SHOULD be extremely popular and widely consideredon the same level as \\"Crazy Train\\" but, for whatever reason, it never turned out that way.  A real bummer.  Any Ozzy Osbourne fan will LOVE \\"Bloodbath In Paradise\\".  Oh but what's next?  The best song ever!  \\"Fire In the Sky\\" is probably my personal favorite Ozzy Osbourne song.  What more can be said about it?  Ozzy's practically pouring every emotion he has into the line \\"Fire in the sky, won't you help me now my castles are burning\\".  And Zakk's guitar playing (especially his solo?) Simply FANTASTIC!  \\"Tattoed Dancer\\" and Demon Alcohol\\" continue with the memorable singalong verse melodies and choruses that make them quite underrated since they appear to be somewhat forgotten, and I suppose \\"Hero\\" is a decent song but not one of my favorites.  A MUST own and NOW my review feels complete, haha.  Sorry for the terrible review 5 years ago- an album this good deserves more respect.

031606792X|4.0|Honestly, with as much backlash as the book has gotten, I'm not surprised that it has received bad reviews.  Mrs. Meyer stated that she had this planned out since the beginning, before New Moon and Eclipse.  It was ALWAYS MEANT TO HAPPEN.<br /><br />Not to negate the fact that the plot is wierd, to say the least.  I understand how such a dramatic difference could make even the most dedicated fan scream.  I admit I even threw the book down and stopped (momentarily) to contemplate the plot lines by chapter four.<br /><br />In retrospect, however, this was Bella's ending.  We can't relate to her anymore because she is different now.  She's grown up and matured, no more whiny Bella here.<br /><br />The reactions in the book to various plot points were EXACTLY as I would have imagined it.  She's done her homework for trying to make a plot feasible with this.  She wanted the happily-ever-after ending, just like we wished.  It just came at a different pace and in a long, round-about way.<br /><br />I respect her and applaud her for writing a book for her.  Not because she needed reviews or the fame (neither which is her problem), but because she wanted to invoke a little of herself into this character one last time.  Bella's transformation as a person is amazing and so much more different.  We don't understand fully the changes in her, but we can see them and should appreciate this for what it is.<br /><br />I personally loved the book.  It was the right ending for her story, the closure necessary for the series.  Any other books that may come out as result of this will be completely different. Hint to Midnight Sun, people.<br /><br />So, in my opinion, this book was shocking, yet had the closure I needed to see in Bella's story.  Everyone had their respectable ending and that, my friends, is good enough for me.
031606792X|5.0|Quite a satisfying end to the Twilight Saga. She tied up the loose ends, went more in-depth with mysterious characters, and had a climax at every turn.     So what if it wasn't probable? It's a VAMPIRE book. It's not exactly non-fiction. Who wants to read a book about deep love that has a sad ending? Stephenie Meyer ended it the way she wanted to and that's good enough for me.     Reading the books, I grew to love the characters, even the Volturi. A lot of ending books are just happy conclusions, but this had conflict. Many of them. It kept you on the edge of your seat and feeling all warm and fuzzy inside about Edward and Bella.     Stephenie, congratulations. You made me into an even stronger fanpire then I was before.
031606792X|4.0|Some people seem to have pretty odd expectations from teen fantasy fiction. Sure there were some unexpected turns to this book but it is what it is an entertaining fantasy fiction novel.  With only one book left to give Bella the ending she wanted to give her the author did a great job.  These books are not guides to life they are entertainment with the bonus of good values and people who are so disappointed need to take a step back and think about what they are reviewing.

B00177Y9ZC|4.0|I can only imagine the fantasies of people when they can possess the ability to go anywhere, get anything, do anything and eventually be anything they want to be. Such is the power of Teleportation, the theme of Jumper. The movie has a somewhat slow start but once things are in place there's no looking back. Hayden Christens with his piercing gaze  does a good job. But his jumper partner, with the Irish accent was both sick and snobbish. Although the movie does not explicitly reveal it Hayden does have a strong connection  with his father at home and his mother who had abandoned him long ago. When he enquires about the same of his jumper partner (the guy with the accent) check out the answer the latter gives. Only a heartless snob would reply like that. Rachel Bilser was sweet and charming. Samuel L Jackson adds sparkle. One scene, the killing of a Jumper was brutal.     4 stars for all the excitement.
B0001XALTG|4.0|i wasn't old enough to know this existed when it came out, but after hearing some good things about it i gave it a shot, and it was a pretty good film. i can see how it could have a cultish affect on people, it's one of those films.<br /><br />it's about this guy who's a heroine addict and how he struggles with his addiction, but it isn't a depressing movie. it can be kind of funny, a sick kind of funny. it isn't a movie about how drugs are bad and how they can destroy your family and mess up your life, just about how they can mess up your life. and this is passed off as both something to pity and something to laugh at... but it is also not a light hearted movie fluffing off the issue. it is a raw look at the life of a guy who goes in and out of heroine addictions.. but doesn't really care. in his eyes it's just another aspect of his life at the moment. worth the watch.

B0010X745K|2.0|I thought 90% of the movie was excellent and hewed very closely to Stephen King's novella about a military experiment gone bad. I was all set to give it four stars. And then...there was that ending. I was very disappointed by the disturbing final scene of the movie, which, I believe, was gratuitously unnecessary. It changed a story that had an open-ended yet hopeful ending to a big screen episode of the Twilight Zone. While Rod Serling is one of my favorite writers, this film's ending did not jibe with what came before it. What was the rush? There were no monsters near by and, had they waited, the soldiers may have appeared and saved them all. It seems to make the film a vindication of Mrs. Carmody and gives credence to her religious rants. Should Frank Darabont decide to re-release this film at some future time with an ending more in tune with the novella, I believe it I would rate it a four star film.

0446402389|5.0|First book in quite a while that was both sit-on-the-edge-of-your-chair exciting and had an interesting story and characters as well. I found it very realistic except for one unbelievable detail that I'm going to overlook in my rating because I still enjoyed this read a lot. Quite unpredictable and surprising from cover to cover. The stories of people in 1950's Russia under Stalin's rule were fascinating: struggling to survive extreme poverty and hardships, the power, control, and manipulation of the police state, the pervasive mistrust, suspicion, and paranoia permeating every aspect of daily life from highest politician to lowliest peasant, all woven around the central plot of a serial killer. For me, A Complete Treat.
031606792X|5.0|I'm not one to review a lot of books on here but I had to review because the top reviews on here are so negative, and I wanted to present a positive opinion. I jumped on this series' bandwagon relatively recently, but I was immediately a fan, telling friends/family about the series.     This book really stays true to the rest of the series, I think, which is what I was hoping it would. I was worried how the Jacob/Bella/Edward triangle would resolve itself, and yet at the end of this book I was very satisfied. Several of the characters, especially Bella, come a long way both physically and emotionally.     I think this book will please fans of the series because there's tons of fabulous Edward/Bella scenes, as well as more insight into the Cullens!
